   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Mexico</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="contentSub2"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav"></div> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a> 
    <div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">
       Country in North America
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       This article is about the federal republic in North America. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Mexico_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Mexico (disambiguation)">Mexico (disambiguation)</a>.
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       "United Mexican States" redirects here. For the historical states, see <a href="/wiki/First_Mexican_Republic" title="First Mexican Republic">First Mexican Republic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Second_Federal_Republic_of_Mexico" title="Second Federal Republic of Mexico">Second Federal Republic of Mexico</a>.
      </div> 
      <p> <span style="font-size: small;"><span id="coordinates"><a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">Coordinates</a>: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r994658806">.mw-parser-output .geo-default,.mw-parser-output .geo-dms,.mw-parser-output .geo-dec{display:inline}.mw-parser-output .geo-nondefault,.mw-parser-output .geo-multi-punct{display:none}.mw-parser-output .longitude,.mw-parser-output .latitude{white-space:nowrap}</style><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Mexico&amp;params=23_N_102_W_"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">23°N</span> <span class="longitude">102°W</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">﻿ / ﻿</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">23°N 102°W</span><span style="display:none">﻿ / <span class="geo">23; -102</span></span></span></a></span></span></span> </p>

         <td><a href="/wiki/Chamber_of_Deputies_(Mexico)" title="Chamber of Deputies (Mexico)">Chamber of Deputies</a></td>
        </tr>
        <tr class="mergedtoprow">

           from <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a>
          </div></th>
        </tr>

         <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
          <div style="text-align:left;margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;">
           <ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha; margin-left: 1em;"> 
            <li value="1"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_iboxa"><b><a href="#ref_iboxa">^</a></b></span> Article 4.° of the <a href="/wiki/General_Law_of_Linguistic_Rights_of_the_Indigenous_Peoples" class="mw-redirect" title="General Law of Linguistic Rights of the Indigenous Peoples">General Law of Linguistic Rights of the Indigenous Peoples</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup></li>
            <li value="2"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_iboxb"><b><a href="#ref_iboxb">^</a></b></span> Spanish is <i><a href="/wiki/De_facto" title="De facto">de facto</a></i> the official language in the Mexican federal government.</li> 
           </ol>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p><b>Mexico</b> (<a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a>: <i lang="es">México</i> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish" title="Help:IPA/Spanish">[ˈmexiko]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Es-mx-M%C3%A9xico.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20"></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/cf/Es-mx-M%C3%A9xico.ogg" class="internal" title="Es-mx-México.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span>; <a href="/wiki/Nahuan_languages" title="Nahuan languages">Nahuan languages</a>: <i lang="nah" title="Nahuatl languages collective text">Mēxihco</i>), officially the <b>United Mexican States</b> (<i lang="es" title="Spanish-language text">Estados Unidos Mexicanos</i>; EUM <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish" title="Help:IPA/Spanish">[esˈtaðos uˈniðoz mexiˈkanos]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Es-mx-Estados_Unidos_Mexicanos.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20"></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b9/Es-mx-Estados_Unidos_Mexicanos.ogg" class="internal" title="Es-mx-Estados Unidos Mexicanos.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span>), is a <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states" title="List of sovereign states">country</a> in the southern portion of <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North America</a>. It is <a href="/wiki/Borders_of_Mexico" title="Borders of Mexico">bordered</a> to the north by the United States; to the south and west by the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a>; to the southeast by <a href="/wiki/Guatemala" title="Guatemala">Guatemala</a>, <a href="/wiki/Belize" title="Belize">Belize</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_Sea" title="Caribbean Sea">Caribbean Sea</a>; and to the east by the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico" title="Gulf of Mexico">Gulf of Mexico</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> Mexico covers 1,972,550 square kilometers (761,610&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi),<sup id="cite_ref-cia.gov_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia.gov-11">[11]</a></sup> making it the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_area" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by area">13th-largest country</a> by area; with approximately 126,014,024 inhabitants,<sup id="cite_ref-2020_Census_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2020_Census-4">[4]</a></sup> it is <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by population">10th-most-populous</a> country and <a href="/wiki/Hispanophone#Hispanosphere" title="Hispanophone">most Spanish-speakers</a>. Mexico is organized as a <a href="/wiki/Federation" title="Federation">federation</a> comprising 31 <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_of_Mexico" title="List of states of Mexico">states</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> its <a href="/wiki/Capital_city" title="Capital city">capital</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Mexico" title="List of cities in Mexico">largest metropolis</a>. Other <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_areas_of_Mexico" title="Metropolitan areas of Mexico">major urban areas</a> include <a href="/wiki/Guadalajara" title="Guadalajara">Guadalajara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Monterrey" title="Monterrey">Monterrey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Puebla_City" class="mw-redirect" title="Puebla City">Puebla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Toluca" title="Toluca">Toluca</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tijuana" title="Tijuana">Tijuana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ciudad_Ju%C3%A1rez" title="Ciudad Juárez">Ciudad Juárez</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Le%C3%B3n,_Guanajuato" title="León, Guanajuato">León</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Pre-Columbian_Mexico" title="Pre-Columbian Mexico">Pre-Columbian Mexico</a> traces its origins to 8,000 BC and is identified as one of six <a href="/wiki/Cradle_of_civilization" title="Cradle of civilization">cradles of civilization</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> it was home to many advanced <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerica" title="Mesoamerica">Mesoamerican</a> civilizations, most notably the <a href="/wiki/Maya_civilization" title="Maya civilization">Maya</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Aztec" class="mw-redirect" title="Aztec">Aztecs</a>. In 1521, the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish Empire</a> <a href="/wiki/Spanish_conquest_of_the_Aztec_Empire" title="Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire">conquered and colonized</a> the region from its base in <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a>, establishing the colony of <a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">New Spain</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic Church</a> played an important role in spreading Christianity and the Spanish language, while also preserving some indigenous cultures.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup> Native populations were heavily exploited to mine rich deposits of precious metals, which contributed to Spain's status as a major world power for the next three centuries.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> Over time, a distinct <a href="/wiki/Mexican_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Mexican culture">Mexican identity</a> formed, based on a fusion indigenous and Europeans customs; this contributed to the successful <a href="/wiki/Mexican_War_of_Independence" title="Mexican War of Independence">Mexican War of Independence</a> against Spain in 1821.<sup id="cite_ref-hist_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hist-17">[17]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Mexico's early history as a <a href="/wiki/Nation_state" title="Nation state">nation state</a> was marked by political and socioeconomic upheaval. The <a href="/wiki/Texas_Revolution" title="Texas Revolution">Texas Revolution</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Mexican%E2%80%93American_War" title="Mexican–American War">Mexican–American War</a> in the mid 19th century led to huge <a href="/wiki/Territorial_evolution_of_Mexico" title="Territorial evolution of Mexico">territorial losses</a> to the United States. The newly instituted <a href="/wiki/La_Reforma" title="La Reforma">reforms</a> that granted protection to indigenous communities, and curtailed the power of the military and the church, were enshrined in the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_1857" class="mw-redirect" title="Constitution of 1857">Constitution of 1857</a>. This triggered the <a href="/wiki/War_of_the_Reform" class="mw-redirect" title="War of the Reform">War of the Reform</a> and <a href="/wiki/French_Intervention_in_Mexico" class="mw-redirect" title="French Intervention in Mexico">French intervention</a>, which installed <a href="/wiki/Maximilian_I_of_Mexico" title="Maximilian I of Mexico">Maximilian Habsburg</a> as <a href="/wiki/Emperor_of_Mexico" title="Emperor of Mexico">emperor</a> against resistance by republican forces led <a href="/wiki/Benito_Ju%C3%A1rez" title="Benito Juárez">Benito Juárez</a>. The following decades were marked by instability and dictatorship of <a href="/wiki/Porfirio_D%C3%ADaz" title="Porfirio Díaz">Porfirio Díaz</a>, who sought to modernize Mexico and restore order.<sup id="cite_ref-hist_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hist-17">[17]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Porfiriato" title="Porfiriato"><i>Porfiriato</i> era</a> ended with the decade-long <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Revolution" title="Mexican Revolution">Mexican Revolution</a> in 1910, after which the victorious <a href="/wiki/Constitutionalist_Army" class="mw-redirect" title="Constitutionalist Army">Constitutionalist faction</a> drafted a new <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Mexico" title="Constitution of Mexico">1917 Constitution</a>, which remains in effect to this day. The revolutionary generals ruled as a succession of presidents until the assassination of <a href="/wiki/Alvaro_Obreg%C3%B3n" class="mw-redirect" title="Alvaro Obregón">Alvaro Obregón</a> in 1928, which led to the formation of the <a href="/wiki/Institutional_Revolutionary_Party" title="Institutional Revolutionary Party">Institutional Revolutionary Party</a> the following year, under which Mexico was <i>a de facto</i> <a href="/wiki/One-party_state" title="One-party state">one-party state</a> until <a href="/wiki/2000_Mexican_general_election" title="2000 Mexican general election">2000</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Mexico is a <a href="/wiki/Developing_country" title="Developing country">developing country</a>, ranking 74th on the <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>, but has the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">15th-largest economy by nominal GDP</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">11th-largest by PPP</a>, with the United States being its largest economic partner.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> Its large economy and population, global cultural influence, and steady democratization make Mexico a <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional</a> and <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle power</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> it is often identified as an <a href="/wiki/Emerging_Powers" class="mw-redirect" title="Emerging Powers">emerging power</a> but is considered a <a href="/wiki/Newly_industrialized_country" title="Newly industrialized country">newly industrialized state</a> by several analysts.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Globalization2_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Globalization2-29">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Limits2_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Limits2-30">[30]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-AIA2_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AIA2-31">[31]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Principles2_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Principles2-32">[32]</a></sup> However, the country continues to struggle with social inequalities, poverty and extensive crime; it ranks poorly on the <a href="/wiki/Global_Peace_Index" title="Global Peace Index">Global Peace Index</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> due in large part to ongoing conflict between the government and <a href="/wiki/Drug_trafficking" class="mw-redirect" title="Drug trafficking">drug trafficking</a> syndicates that led to over 120,000 deaths since 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-cfrdeaths_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cfrdeaths-34">[34]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Mexico ranks <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Mexico" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Mexico">first in the Americas and seventh in the world</a> for the number of <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Sites</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> It is also one of the world's 17 <a href="/wiki/Megadiverse_countries" title="Megadiverse countries">megadiverse countries</a>, ranking fiftth in natural <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity" title="Biodiversity">biodiversity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> Mexico's rich cultural and biological heritage, as well as varied climate and geography, makes it major tourist destination: as of 2018, it was the sixth most-visited country in the world, with 39 million international arrivals.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup> Mexico is a member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> (UN), the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> (WTO), the <a href="/wiki/G8%2B5" title="G8+5">G8+5</a>, the <a href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" class="mw-redirect" title="G-20 major economies">G20</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Uniting_for_Consensus" title="Uniting for Consensus">Uniting for Consensus</a> group, and the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Alliance" title="Pacific Alliance">Pacific Alliance</a> <a href="/wiki/Trade_bloc" title="Trade bloc">trade bloc</a>. </p> 
      <div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading">

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Mexico" title="Name of Mexico">Name of Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:CodexMendoza01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/CodexMendoza01.jpg/220px-CodexMendoza01.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="260" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/CodexMendoza01.jpg/330px-CodexMendoza01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/CodexMendoza01.jpg/440px-CodexMendoza01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="622" data-file-height="735"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:CodexMendoza01.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Depiction of the founding myth of <a href="/wiki/Tenochtitlan" title="Tenochtitlan">Mexico-Tenochtitlan</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Codex_Mendoza" title="Codex Mendoza">Codex Mendoza</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><i lang="nah" title="Nahuatl languages collective text"><a href="/wiki/Name_of_Mexico" title="Name of Mexico">Mēxihco</a></i> is the <a href="/wiki/Nahuatl" title="Nahuatl">Nahuatl</a> term for the heartland of the <a href="/wiki/Aztec_Empire" title="Aztec Empire">Aztec Empire</a>, namely the <a href="/wiki/Valley_of_Mexico" title="Valley of Mexico">Valley of Mexico</a> and surrounding territories, with its people being known as the <a href="/wiki/Mexica" title="Mexica">Mexica</a>. The terms are plainly linked; it is generally believed that the <a href="/wiki/Toponym" class="mw-redirect" title="Toponym">toponym</a> for the valley was the origin of the primary <a href="/wiki/Ethnonym" title="Ethnonym">ethnonym</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Aztec_Triple_Alliance" class="mw-redirect" title="Aztec Triple Alliance">Aztec Triple Alliance</a>, but it may have been the other way around.<sup id="cite_ref-Bright2004_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bright2004-40">[40]</a></sup> In the colonial era, when Mexico was called <a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">New Spain</a>, this central region became the <a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">Intendency of Mexico</a>, during the eighteenth-century reorganization of the empire, the <a href="/wiki/Bourbon_Reforms" title="Bourbon Reforms">Bourbon Reforms</a>. After the colony achieved independence from the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish Empire</a> in 1821, said territory came to be known as the <a href="/wiki/State_of_Mexico" title="State of Mexico">State of Mexico</a>, with the new country being named after its capital: <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a>, which itself was founded in 1524 on the site of the ancient Mexica capital of <a href="/wiki/Mexico-Tenochtitlan" class="mw-redirect" title="Mexico-Tenochtitlan">Mexico-Tenochtitlan</a>. </p>
      <p>The official name of the country has changed as the <a href="/wiki/Form_of_government" class="mw-redirect" title="Form of government">form of government</a> has changed. The declaration of independence signed on 6 November 1813 by the deputies of the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_An%C3%A1huac" class="mw-redirect" title="Congress of Anáhuac">Congress of Anáhuac</a> called the territory <i><a href="/wiki/Solemn_Act_of_the_Declaration_of_Independence_of_Northern_America" title="Solemn Act of the Declaration of Independence of Northern America">América Septentrional</a></i> (Northern America); the 1821 <a href="/wiki/Plan_of_Iguala" title="Plan of Iguala">Plan of Iguala</a> also used América Septentrional. On two occasions (1821–1823 and 1863–1867), the country was known as <i lang="es" title="Spanish-language text">Imperio Mexicano</i> (<a href="/wiki/Mexican_Empire_(disambiguation)" class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" title="Mexican Empire (disambiguation)">Mexican Empire</a>). All three federal constitutions (1824, 1857 and 1917, the current constitution) used the name <i lang="es" title="Spanish-language text">Estados Unidos Mexicanos</i><sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup>—or the variant <i lang="es" title="Spanish-language text">Estados-Unidos Mexicanos</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> all of which have been translated as "United Mexican States". The phrase <i lang="es" title="Spanish-language text">República Mexicana</i>, "Mexican Republic", was used in the 1836 <a href="/wiki/Siete_Leyes" title="Siete Leyes">Constitutional Laws</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Mexico" title="History of Mexico">History of Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Catholic_Church_in_Mexico" title="History of the Catholic Church in Mexico">History of the Catholic Church in Mexico</a>, <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_Mexico" title="Economic history of Mexico">Economic history of Mexico</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_democracy_in_Mexico" title="History of democracy in Mexico">History of democracy in Mexico</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Mexico_City" title="History of Mexico City">History of Mexico City</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Mexico" title="Military history of Mexico">Military history of Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Indigenous_civilizations">Indigenous civilizations</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Pre-Columbian_Mexico" title="Pre-Columbian Mexico">Pre-Columbian Mexico</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerican_chronology" title="Mesoamerican chronology">Mesoamerican chronology</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Teotihuac%C3%A1n-5954.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Teotihuac%C3%A1n-5954.JPG/220px-Teotihuac%C3%A1n-5954.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Teotihuac%C3%A1n-5954.JPG/330px-Teotihuac%C3%A1n-5954.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Teotihuac%C3%A1n-5954.JPG/440px-Teotihuac%C3%A1n-5954.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3684" data-file-height="2456"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Teotihuac%C3%A1n-5954.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Pyramid_of_the_Sun" title="Pyramid of the Sun">Pyramid of the Sun</a> of <a href="/wiki/Teotihuacan" title="Teotihuacan">Teotihuacan</a> with first human establishment in the area dating back to 600 BC
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The earliest <a href="/wiki/Human" title="Human">human</a> artifacts in Mexico are chips of <a href="/wiki/Stone_tool" title="Stone tool">stone tools</a> found near campfire remains in the Valley of Mexico and radiocarbon-dated to circa 10,000 years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWerner2001386–_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWerner2001386–-44">[44]</a></sup> Mexico is the site of the domestication of maize, tomato, and <a href="/wiki/Phaseolus" title="Phaseolus">beans</a>, which produced an agricultural surplus. This enabled the transition from <a href="/wiki/Paleo-Indians" title="Paleo-Indians">paleo-Indian</a> hunter-gatherers to sedentary agricultural villages beginning around 5000 BC.<sup id="cite_ref-EvansWebster2013_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EvansWebster2013-45">[45]</a></sup> In the subsequent formative eras, maize cultivation and cultural traits such as a mythological and religious complex, and a <a href="/wiki/Vigesimal" title="Vigesimal">vigesimal</a> (base 20) numeric system, were diffused from the Mexican cultures to the rest of the <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerica" title="Mesoamerica">Mesoamerican</a> culture area.<sup id="cite_ref-MacLachlan_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MacLachlan-46">[46]</a></sup> In this period, villages became more dense in terms of population, becoming socially stratified with an artisan class, and developing into <a href="/wiki/Chiefdom" title="Chiefdom">chiefdoms</a>. The most powerful rulers had religious and political power, organizing the construction of large ceremonial centers developed.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:The_Florentine_Codex-_Agriculture.tiff" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/The_Florentine_Codex-_Agriculture.tiff/lossy-page1-180px-The_Florentine_Codex-_Agriculture.tiff.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="274" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/The_Florentine_Codex-_Agriculture.tiff/lossy-page1-270px-The_Florentine_Codex-_Agriculture.tiff.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/The_Florentine_Codex-_Agriculture.tiff/lossy-page1-360px-The_Florentine_Codex-_Agriculture.tiff.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2364" data-file-height="3593"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:The_Florentine_Codex-_Agriculture.tiff" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Cultivation of maize, shown in the <a href="/wiki/Florentine_Codex" title="Florentine Codex">Florentine Codex</a> (1576) drawn by an indigenous scribe, with text in Nahuatl on this folio
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The earliest complex civilization in Mexico was the <a href="/wiki/Olmec" class="mw-redirect" title="Olmec">Olmec</a> culture, which flourished on the Gulf Coast from around 1500 BC. Olmec cultural traits diffused through Mexico into other formative-era cultures in Chiapas, Oaxaca and the Valley of Mexico. The formative period saw the spread of distinct religious and symbolic traditions, as well as artistic and architectural complexes.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup> The formative-era of Mesoamerica is considered one of the six independent <a href="/wiki/Cradles_of_civilization" class="mw-redirect" title="Cradles of civilization">cradles of civilization</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> In the subsequent <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerican_chronology" title="Mesoamerican chronology">pre-classical period</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Maya_civilization" title="Maya civilization">Maya</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zapotec_civilization" title="Zapotec civilization">Zapotec</a> civilizations developed complex centers at <a href="/wiki/Calakmul" title="Calakmul">Calakmul</a> and <a href="/wiki/Monte_Alb%C3%A1n" title="Monte Albán">Monte Albán</a>, respectively. During this period the first true <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerican_writing_systems" title="Mesoamerican writing systems">Mesoamerican writing systems</a> were developed in the <a href="/wiki/Epi-Olmec_culture" title="Epi-Olmec culture">Epi-Olmec</a> and the Zapotec cultures. The Mesoamerican writing tradition reached its height in the Classic <a href="/wiki/Maya_Script" class="mw-redirect" title="Maya Script">Maya Hieroglyphic script</a>. The earliest written histories date from this era. The tradition of writing was important after the Spanish conquest in 1521.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In Central Mexico, the height of the classic period saw the ascendancy of <a href="/wiki/Teotihuacan" title="Teotihuacan">Teotihuacán</a>, which formed a military and commercial empire whose political influence stretched south into the Maya area as well as north. Teotihuacan, with a population of more than 150,000 people, had some of the largest <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerican_pyramid" class="mw-redirect" title="Mesoamerican pyramid">pyramidal structures</a> in the pre-Columbian Americas.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> After the collapse of Teotihuacán around 600 AD, competition ensued between several important political centers in central Mexico such as <a href="/wiki/Xochicalco" title="Xochicalco">Xochicalco</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cholula_(Mesoamerican_site)" title="Cholula (Mesoamerican site)">Cholula</a>. At this time, during the Epi-Classic, <a href="/wiki/Nahua_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Nahua people">Nahua peoples</a> began moving south into Mesoamerica from the North, and became politically and culturally dominant in central Mexico, as they displaced speakers of <a href="/wiki/Oto-Manguean_languages" title="Oto-Manguean languages">Oto-Manguean languages</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Murales_Rivera_-_Markt_in_Tlatelolco_3.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Murales_Rivera_-_Markt_in_Tlatelolco_3.jpg/220px-Murales_Rivera_-_Markt_in_Tlatelolco_3.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Murales_Rivera_-_Markt_in_Tlatelolco_3.jpg/330px-Murales_Rivera_-_Markt_in_Tlatelolco_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Murales_Rivera_-_Markt_in_Tlatelolco_3.jpg/440px-Murales_Rivera_-_Markt_in_Tlatelolco_3.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2560" data-file-height="1920"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Murales_Rivera_-_Markt_in_Tlatelolco_3.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>1945 Mural by Diego Rivera depicting the view from the <a href="/wiki/Tlatelolco_(altepetl)" title="Tlatelolco (altepetl)">Tlatelolco</a> markets into Mexico-Tenochtitlan, the largest city in the Americas at the time.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>During the early post-classic era (ca. 1000–1519 CE), Central Mexico was dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Toltec" title="Toltec">Toltec</a> culture, <a href="/wiki/Oaxaca" title="Oaxaca">Oaxaca</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Mixtec_civilization" class="mw-redirect" title="Mixtec civilization">Mixtec</a>, and the lowland Maya area had important centers at <a href="/wiki/Chich%C3%A9n_Itz%C3%A1" class="mw-redirect" title="Chichén Itzá">Chichén Itzá</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mayap%C3%A1n" class="mw-redirect" title="Mayapán">Mayapán</a>. Toward the end of the post-Classic period, the Mexica established dominance, establishing a political and economic empire based in the city of Tenochtitlan (modern Mexico City), extending from central Mexico to the border with Guatemala.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Alexander_von_Humboldt" title="Alexander von Humboldt">Alexander von Humboldt</a> popularized the modern usage of "<a href="/wiki/Aztec" class="mw-redirect" title="Aztec">Aztec</a>" as a collective term applied to all the people linked by trade, custom, religion, and language to the <a href="/wiki/Tenochtitlan" title="Tenochtitlan">Mexica state</a> and Ēxcān Tlahtōlōyān, the <a href="/wiki/Aztec_Empire" title="Aztec Empire">Triple Alliance</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> In 1843, with the publication of the work of William H. Prescott, it was adopted by most of the world, including 19th-century Mexican scholars who considered it a way to distinguish present-day Mexicans from pre-conquest Mexicans. This usage has been the subject of debate since the late 20th century.<sup id="cite_ref-Port_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Port-54">[54]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Aztec empire was an informal or hegemonic empire because it did not exert supreme authority over the conquered territories; it was satisfied with the payment of tributes from them. It was a discontinuous empire because not all dominated territories were connected; for example, the southern peripheral zones of <a href="/wiki/Soconusco" title="Soconusco">Xoconochco</a> were not in direct contact with the center. The hegemonic nature of the Aztec empire was demonstrated by their restoration of local rulers to their former position after their city-state was conquered. The Aztec did not interfere in local affairs, as long as the tributes were paid.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Aztec of Central Mexico built a tributary empire covering most of central Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Human_sacrifice_in_Aztec_culture" title="Human sacrifice in Aztec culture">The Aztec were noted for practicing human sacrifice</a> on a large scale. Along with this practice, they avoided killing enemies on the battlefield. Their warring casualty rate was far lower than that of their Spanish counterparts, whose principal objective was immediate slaughter during battle.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> This distinct Mesoamerican cultural tradition of human sacrifice ended with the gradually Spanish conquest in the 16th century. Over the next centuries many other Mexican indigenous cultures were conquered and gradually subjected to Spanish colonial rule.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="Conquest_of_the_Aztec_Empire_.281519.E2.80.931521.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Conquest_of_the_Aztec_Empire_(1519–1521)">Conquest of the Aztec Empire (1519–1521)</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Spanish_conquest_of_Mexico" class="mw-redirect" title="Spanish conquest of Mexico">Spanish conquest of Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Cortez_%26_La_Malinche.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Cortez_%26_La_Malinche.jpg/220px-Cortez_%26_La_Malinche.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="176" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Cortez_%26_La_Malinche.jpg/330px-Cortez_%26_La_Malinche.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Cortez_%26_La_Malinche.jpg/440px-Cortez_%26_La_Malinche.jpg 2x" data-file-width="618" data-file-height="495"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Cortez_%26_La_Malinche.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Depict of <a href="/wiki/Hern%C3%A1n_Cort%C3%A9s" title="Hernán Cortés">Hernán Cortés</a> and his bilingual cultural translator, <a href="/wiki/La_Malinche" title="La Malinche">Doña Marina</a> ("Malinche"), meeting <a href="/wiki/Moctezuma_II" title="Moctezuma II">Moctezuma II</a> from the <i><a href="/wiki/Lienzo_de_Tlaxcala" class="mw-redirect" title="Lienzo de Tlaxcala">Lienzo de Tlaxcala</a></i>. This historical document was created c. 1550 by the Tlaxcalans to remind the Spanish of their loyalty and the importance of <a href="/wiki/Tlaxcala_(Nahua_state)" title="Tlaxcala (Nahua state)">Tlaxcala</a> during the conquest of the Aztec Empire.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Although the Spanish had established colonies in the Caribbean starting in 1493, it was not until the second decade of the sixteenth century that they began exploring the coast of Mexico. The Spanish first learned of Mexico during the <a href="/wiki/Juan_de_Grijalva" title="Juan de Grijalva">Juan de Grijalva</a> expedition of 1518. The natives kept "repeating: <i>Colua, Colua</i>, and <i>Mexico, Mexico</i>, but we [explorers] did not know what <i>Colua</i> or <i>Mexico</i> meant", until encountering Montezuma's governor at the mouth of the <a href="/wiki/Boca_del_R%C3%ADo,_Veracruz" title="Boca del Río, Veracruz">Rio de las Banderas</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Diaz_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Diaz-59">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>33–36</span></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Spanish_conquest_of_the_Aztec_Empire" title="Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire">Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire</a> began in February 1519 when <a href="/wiki/Hern%C3%A1n_Cort%C3%A9s" title="Hernán Cortés">Hernán Cortés</a> landed on the Gulf Coast and founded the Spanish city of <a href="/wiki/Veracruz,_Veracruz" class="mw-redirect" title="Veracruz, Veracruz">Veracruz</a>. Around 500 <a href="/wiki/Conquistador" title="Conquistador">conquistadores</a>, along with horses, cannons, swords, and long guns gave the Spanish some technological advantages over indigenous warriors, but key to the Spanish victory was making strategic alliances with disgruntled indigenous city-states (<i><a href="/wiki/Altepetl" title="Altepetl">altepetl</a></i>) who supplied the Spaniards and fought with them against the Aztec Triple Alliance. Also important to the Spanish victory was Cortés's cultural translator, Malinche, a Nahua woman enslaved in the Maya area whom the Spanish acquired as a gift. She quickly learned Spanish and gave strategic advise about how to deal with both indigenous allies and indigenous foes.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> The unconquered city-state of Tlaxcala allied with the Spanish against their enemies, the Aztecs of Tenochtitlan. The Spanish gained other indigenous allies, who also joined in the war for their own reasons. </p>
      <p>We know so much about the conquest because it is among the best documented events in world history from multiple points of view. There are accounts by the Spanish leader Cortés<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> and multiple other Spanish participants, including <a href="/wiki/Bernal_D%C3%ADaz_del_Castillo" title="Bernal Díaz del Castillo">Bernal Díaz del Castillo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> There are indigenous accounts in Spanish, Nahuatl, and pictorial narratives by allies of the Spanish, most prominently the Tlaxcalans, as well as Texcocans<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> and Huejotzincans, and the defeated Mexican themselves, recorded in the last volume of <a href="/wiki/Bernardino_de_Sahag%C3%BAn" title="Bernardino de Sahagún">Bernardino de Sahagún</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Florentine_Codex" title="Florentine Codex">General History of the Things of New Spain</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:FlorentineCodex_BK12_F54_smallpox.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/FlorentineCodex_BK12_F54_smallpox.jpg/220px-FlorentineCodex_BK12_F54_smallpox.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="170" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/FlorentineCodex_BK12_F54_smallpox.jpg/330px-FlorentineCodex_BK12_F54_smallpox.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/FlorentineCodex_BK12_F54_smallpox.jpg/440px-FlorentineCodex_BK12_F54_smallpox.jpg 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="494"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:FlorentineCodex_BK12_F54_smallpox.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Smallpox" title="Smallpox">Smallpox</a> depicted by an indigenous artist in the 1556 <a href="/wiki/Florentine_Codex" title="Florentine Codex">Florentine Codex</a> in its account of the conquest of Mexico from the point of view of the defeated Mexica.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>When the Spaniards arrived, the ruler of the Aztec empire was <a href="/wiki/Moctezuma_II" title="Moctezuma II">Moctezuma II</a>, who after a delay allowed the Spanish to proceed inland to Tenochtitlan. The Spanish captured him, holding him hostage. He died while in their custody and the Spanish retreated from Tenochtitlan in great disarray. His successor and brother <a href="/wiki/Cuitl%C3%A1huac" title="Cuitláhuac">Cuitláhuac</a> took control of the Aztec empire, but was among the first to fall from the first <a href="/wiki/Smallpox" title="Smallpox">smallpox</a> <a href="/wiki/Epidemic" title="Epidemic">epidemic</a> in the area a short time later.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> Unintentionally introduced by Spanish conquerors, among whom <a href="/wiki/Smallpox" title="Smallpox">smallpox</a>, measles, and other contagious diseases were endemic, epidemics of <a href="/wiki/Old_World" title="Old World">Old World</a> infectious diseases ravaged Mesoamerica starting in the 1520s. The exact number of deaths is disputed, but unquestionably more than 3 million natives who they had no <a href="/wiki/Immunity_(medical)" title="Immunity (medical)">immunity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> Other sources, however, mentioned that the death toll of the Aztecs might have reached 15 million (out of a population of less than 30 million) although such a high number conflicts with the 350,000 Aztecs who ruled an empire of 5 million or 10 million.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup> Severely weakened, the Aztec empire was easily defeated by Cortés and his forces on his second return with the help of state of <a href="/wiki/Tlaxcala" title="Tlaxcala">Tlaxcala</a> whose population estimate was 300,000.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> The native population declined 80–90% by 1600 to 1–2.5 million. Any population estimate of pre-Columbian Mexico is bound to be a guess but 8–12 million is often suggested for the area encompassed by the modern nation. </p>
      <p>The territory became part of the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish Empire</a> under the name of <a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">New Spain</a> in 1535.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a> was systematically rebuilt by Cortés following the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Tenochtitlan" title="Fall of Tenochtitlan">Fall of Tenochtitlan</a> in 1521. Much of the identity, traditions and architecture of Mexico developed during the 300-year colonial period from 1521 to independence in 1821.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="Viceroyalty_of_New_Spain_.281521.E2.80.931821.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Viceroyalty_of_New_Spain_(1521–1821)">Viceroyalty of New Spain (1521–1821)</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">New Spain</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Mexico#Spanish_Rule_(1521-1821)" title="History of Mexico">History of Mexico §&nbsp;Spanish Rule (1521-1821)</a>; <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_Mexico#Economy_of_New_Spain,_1521–1821" title="Economic history of Mexico">Economic history of Mexico §&nbsp;Economy of New Spain, 1521–1821</a>; and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Mexico_City#Colonial_period,_1521-1821" title="History of Mexico City">History of Mexico City §&nbsp;Colonial period, 1521-1821</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Bandera_Mexicana_-_panoramio_-_cz354x_(3).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Bandera_Mexicana_-_panoramio_-_cz354x_%283%29.jpg/220px-Bandera_Mexicana_-_panoramio_-_cz354x_%283%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Bandera_Mexicana_-_panoramio_-_cz354x_%283%29.jpg/330px-Bandera_Mexicana_-_panoramio_-_cz354x_%283%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Bandera_Mexicana_-_panoramio_-_cz354x_%283%29.jpg/440px-Bandera_Mexicana_-_panoramio_-_cz354x_%283%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1536"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Bandera_Mexicana_-_panoramio_-_cz354x_(3).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/National_Palace_(Mexico)" title="National Palace (Mexico)">National Palace</a> on the east side of <a href="/wiki/Plaza_de_la_Constituci%C3%B3n" class="mw-redirect" title="Plaza de la Constitución">Plaza de la Constitución</a> or <i><a href="/wiki/Z%C3%B3calo" title="Zócalo">Zócalo</a></i>, the main square of Mexico City; it was the residence of <a href="/wiki/List_of_viceroys_of_New_Spain" title="List of viceroys of New Spain">viceroys</a> and <a href="/wiki/Presidents_of_Mexico" class="mw-redirect" title="Presidents of Mexico">Presidents of Mexico</a> and now the seat of the Mexican government.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The 1521 capture Tenochtitlan and immediate founding of the Spanish capital <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a> on its ruins was the beginning of a 300-year-long colonial era during which Mexico was known as <i>Nueva España</i> (<a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">New Spain</a>). The <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_New_Spain" title="Kingdom of New Spain">Kingdom of New Spain</a> was created from the remnants of the Aztec empire. The two pillars of Spanish rule were the State and the Roman Catholic Church, both under the authority of the Spanish crown. In 1493 the pope had granted <a href="/wiki/Patronato_real" title="Patronato real">sweeping powers</a> to the Spanish crown, with the proviso that the crown spread Christianity in its new realms. In 1524, <a href="/wiki/Charles_V,_Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor">King Charles I</a> created the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_the_Indies" title="Council of the Indies">Council of the Indies</a> based in Spain to oversee State power its overseas territories; in New Spain the crown established a high court in Mexico City, the <i><a href="/wiki/Real_Audiencia" title="Real Audiencia">Real Audiencia</a>,</i> and then in 1535 created the viceroyalty. The viceroy was highest official of the State. In the religious sphere, the diocese of Mexico was created in 1530 and elevated to the <a href="/wiki/Archdiocese_of_Mexico" class="mw-redirect" title="Archdiocese of Mexico">Archdiocese of Mexico</a> in 1546, with the archbishop as the head of the ecclesiastical hierarchy, overseeing Roman Catholic clergy. Castilian Spanish was the language of rulers. The Catholic faith the only one permitted, with non-Catholics (Jews and Protestants) and Catholics (excluding Indians) holding unorthodox views being subject to the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Inquisition" title="Mexican Inquisition">Mexican Inquisition</a>, established in 1571.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the first half-century of Spanish rule, a network of Spanish cities was created, sometimes on pre-Hispanic sites. The capital Mexico City was and remains the premier city. Cities and towns were hubs of civil officials, ecclesiastics, business, Spanish elites, and mixed-race and indigenous artisans and workers. When deposits of silver were discovered in sparsely populated northern Mexico, far from the dense populations of central Mexico, the Spanish secured the region against fiercely resistant indigenous <a href="/wiki/Chichimeca_War" title="Chichimeca War">Chichimecas</a>. The Viceroyalty at its greatest extent included the territories of modern Mexico, Central America as far south as Costa Rica, and the western United States. The Viceregal capital Mexico City also administrated the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_West_Indies" title="Spanish West Indies">Spanish West Indies</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">Caribbean</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_East_Indies" title="Spanish East Indies">Spanish East Indies</a> (that is, the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Florida" title="Spanish Florida">Spanish Florida</a>. In 1819, the Spain signed the <a href="/wiki/Adams-On%C3%ADs_Treaty" class="mw-redirect" title="Adams-Onís Treaty">Adams-Onís Treaty</a> with the United States, setting New Spain's northern boundary.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Viceroyalty_of_the_New_Spain_1819_(without_Philippines).png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Viceroyalty_of_the_New_Spain_1819_%28without_Philippines%29.png/220px-Viceroyalty_of_the_New_Spain_1819_%28without_Philippines%29.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="164" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Viceroyalty_of_the_New_Spain_1819_%28without_Philippines%29.png/330px-Viceroyalty_of_the_New_Spain_1819_%28without_Philippines%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Viceroyalty_of_the_New_Spain_1819_%28without_Philippines%29.png/440px-Viceroyalty_of_the_New_Spain_1819_%28without_Philippines%29.png 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1192"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Viceroyalty_of_the_New_Spain_1819_(without_Philippines).png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Viceroyalty of New Spain following the signing of the 1819 Adams-Onís Treaty
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The population of Mexico was overwhelmingly indigenous and rural during the entire colonial period and beyond, despite the massive decrease in their numbers due to epidemic diseases. Diseases such as smallpox, measles, and others were introduced by Europeans and African slaves, especially in the sixteenth century. The indigenous population stabilized around one to one and a half million individuals in the 17th century from the most commonly accepted five to thirty million <a href="/wiki/Population_history_of_indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas" title="Population history of indigenous peoples of the Americas">pre-contact population</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-McCaa_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McCaa-76">[76]</a></sup> During the three hundred years of the colonial era, Mexico received between 400,000 and 500,000 Europeans,<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> between 200,000 and 250,000 African slaves.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup> and between 40,000 and 120,000 Asians.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The first census in Mexico (then known as <a href="/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_New_Spain" class="mw-redirect" title="Viceroyalty of New Spain">New Spain</a>) that included an ethnic classification was the 1793 census. Also known as the Revillagigedo census. Most of its original datasets have reportedly been lost, thus most of what is known about it nowadays comes from essays and field investigations made by academics who had access to the census data and used it as reference for their works such as German scientist <a href="/wiki/Alexander_von_Humboldt" title="Alexander von Humboldt">Alexander von Humboldt</a>. Europeans ranged from 18% to 22% of New Spain's population, Mestizos from 21% to 25%, Indians from 51% to 61% and Africans were between 6,000 and 10,000. The total population ranged from 3,799,561 to 6,122,354. It is concluded that the population growth trends of whites and mestizos were even, while the percentage of the indigenous population decreased at a rate of 13%–17% per century, mostly due to the latter having higher mortality rates from living in remote locations and being in constant war with the colonists.<sup id="cite_ref-aleph_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aleph-81">[81]</a></sup> Independent-era Mexico eliminated the legal basis of the <a href="/wiki/Castas" class="mw-redirect" title="Castas">Colonial caste system</a> which led to exclusion of racial classification in the censuses to come. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Casta_Painting_by_Luis_de_Mena.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Casta_Painting_by_Luis_de_Mena.jpg/220px-Casta_Painting_by_Luis_de_Mena.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="268" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Casta_Painting_by_Luis_de_Mena.jpg/330px-Casta_Painting_by_Luis_de_Mena.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Casta_Painting_by_Luis_de_Mena.jpg/440px-Casta_Painting_by_Luis_de_Mena.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5404" data-file-height="6586"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Casta_Painting_by_Luis_de_Mena.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Luis_de_Mena" title="Luis de Mena">Luis de Mena</a>, <a href="/wiki/Virgin_of_Guadalupe" class="mw-redirect" title="Virgin of Guadalupe">Virgin of Guadalupe</a> and <a href="/wiki/Casta" title="Casta">castas</a>, showing race mixture and hierarchy as well as fruits of the realm,<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup> ca. 1750
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Colonial <a href="/wiki/Law_in_Spain" class="mw-redirect" title="Law in Spain">law with Spanish roots</a> was introduced and attached to native customs creating a hierarchy between local jurisdiction (the <a href="/wiki/Cabildo_(council)" title="Cabildo (council)">Cabildos</a>) and the Spanish Crown. Upper administrative offices were closed to native-born people, even those of pure Spanish blood (<a href="/wiki/Criollo_people" title="Criollo people">criollos</a>). Administration was based on the <a href="/wiki/Racial_separation" class="mw-redirect" title="Racial separation">racial separation</a>. Society was organized in a racial hierarchy, with whites on top, mixed-race persons and blacks in the middle, and indigenous at the bottom. There were formal legal designations of racial categories. The Republic of Spaniards (<i>República de Españoles</i>) comprised European- and American-born Spaniards, mixed-race <a href="/wiki/Casta" title="Casta">castas</a>, and black Africans. The Republic of Indians (<i>República de Indios</i>) comprised the indigenous populations, which the Spanish lumped under the term Indian (<i>indio</i>), a Spanish colonial social construct which indigenous groups and individuals rejected as a category. Spaniards were exempt from paying tribute, Spanish men had access to higher education, could hold civil and ecclesiastical offices, were subject to the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Inquisition" title="Mexican Inquisition">Inquisition</a>, and liable for military service when the standing military was established in the late eighteenth century. Indigenous paid tribute, but were exempt from the Inquisition, indigenous men were excluded from the priesthood; and exempt from military service. </p>
      <p>Although the racial system appears fixed and rigid, there was some fluidity within it, and racial domination of whites was not complete.<sup id="cite_ref-Cope,_R._Douglas_1994_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cope,_R._Douglas_1994-83">[83]</a></sup> Since the indigenous population of New Spain was so large, there was less labor demand for expensive black slaves than other parts of Spanish America.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup> In the late eighteenth century the crown instituted <a href="/wiki/Bourbon_Reforms" title="Bourbon Reforms">reforms</a> that privileged Iberian-born Spaniards (<i>peninsulares</i>) over American-born (<i>criollos</i>), limiting their access to offices. This discrimination between the two became a sparking point of discontent for white elites in the colony.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Marian_apparition" title="Marian apparition">Marian apparition</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Virgin_of_Guadalupe" class="mw-redirect" title="Virgin of Guadalupe">Virgin of Guadalupe</a> said to have appeared to the indigenous <a href="/wiki/Juan_Diego" title="Juan Diego">Juan Diego</a> in 1531 gave impetus to the evangelization of central Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-huff_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-huff-88">[88]</a></sup> The Virgin of Guadalupe became a symbol for American-born Spaniards' (<i>criollos</i>) patriotism, seeking in her a Mexican source of pride, distinct from Spain.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> The Virgin of Guadalupe was invoked by the insurgents for independence who followed Father <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Hidalgo" class="mw-redirect" title="Miguel Hidalgo">Miguel Hidalgo</a> during the War of Independence.<sup id="cite_ref-huff_88-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-huff-88">[88]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:16th_century_Portuguese_Spanish_trade_routes.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/16th_century_Portuguese_Spanish_trade_routes.png/290px-16th_century_Portuguese_Spanish_trade_routes.png" decoding="async" width="290" height="122" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/16th_century_Portuguese_Spanish_trade_routes.png/435px-16th_century_Portuguese_Spanish_trade_routes.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/16th_century_Portuguese_Spanish_trade_routes.png/580px-16th_century_Portuguese_Spanish_trade_routes.png 2x" data-file-width="2835" data-file-height="1188"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:16th_century_Portuguese_Spanish_trade_routes.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>New Spain was essential to the Spanish global trading system. White represents the route of the Spanish <a href="/wiki/Manila_Galleon" class="mw-redirect" title="Manila Galleon">Manila Galleons</a> in the Pacific and the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_treasure_fleet" title="Spanish treasure fleet">Spanish convoys</a> in the Atlantic. (Blue represents <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_India_Armadas" title="Portuguese India Armadas">Portuguese routes.)</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The rich deposits of silver, particularly in <a href="/wiki/Zacatecas" title="Zacatecas">Zacatecas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Guanajuato" title="Guanajuato">Guanajuato</a>, resulted in silver extraction dominating the economy of New Spain. <a href="/wiki/Royal_fifth" title="Royal fifth">Taxes on silver production</a> became a major source of income for Spain. Other important industries were the <a href="/wiki/Haciendas" class="mw-redirect" title="Haciendas">haciendas</a> and mercantile activities in the main cities and ports.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> Wealth created during the colonial era spurred the development of <a href="/wiki/New_Spanish_Baroque" title="New Spanish Baroque">New Spanish Baroque</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>As a result of its trade links with Asia, the rest of the Americas, Africa and Europe and the <a href="/wiki/Global_silver_trade_from_the_16th_to_18th_centuries" class="mw-redirect" title="Global silver trade from the 16th to 18th centuries">profound effect of New World silver</a>, central Mexico was one of the first regions to be incorporated into a <a href="/wiki/Globalized" class="mw-redirect" title="Globalized">globalized</a> economy. Being at the crossroads of trade, people and cultures, Mexico City has been called the "first <a href="/wiki/World_city" class="mw-redirect" title="World city">world city</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Nao_de_China" class="mw-redirect" title="Nao de China">Nao de China</a></i> (Manila Galleons) operated for two and a half centuries and connected New Spain with Asia. Silver and the red dye <a href="/wiki/Cochineal" title="Cochineal">cochineal</a> were shipped from Veracruz to Atlantic ports in the Americas and Spain. Veracruz was also the main port of entry in mainland New Spain for European goods, immigrants from Spain, and African slaves. The <i><a href="/wiki/Camino_Real_de_Tierra_Adentro" title="Camino Real de Tierra Adentro">Camino Real de Tierra Adentro</a></i> connected Mexico City with the interior of New Spain. Mexican silver pesos became the first globally used currency. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Carlos_III_Coin.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Carlos_III_Coin.jpg/260px-Carlos_III_Coin.jpg" decoding="async" width="260" height="131" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Carlos_III_Coin.jpg/390px-Carlos_III_Coin.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Carlos_III_Coin.jpg/520px-Carlos_III_Coin.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1004" data-file-height="504"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Carlos_III_Coin.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Silver <a href="/wiki/Peso" title="Peso">peso</a> mined and minted in colonial Mexico, which became a global currency.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Spanish forces, sometimes accompanied by native allies, led expeditions to conquer territory or quell rebellions through the colonial era. Notable Amerindian revolts in sporadically populated northern New Spain include the <a href="/wiki/Chichimeca_War" title="Chichimeca War">Chichimeca War</a> (1576–1606),<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tepehu%C3%A1n_Revolt" title="Tepehuán Revolt">Tepehuán Revolt</a> (1616–1620),<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Pueblo_Revolt" title="Pueblo Revolt">Pueblo Revolt</a> (1680), the <a href="/wiki/Tzeltal_Rebellion_of_1712" title="Tzeltal Rebellion of 1712">Tzeltal Rebellion of 1712</a> was a regional Maya revolt.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup> Most rebellions were small-scale and local, posing no major threat to the ruling elites.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> To protect Mexico from the attacks of English, French, and Dutch <a href="/wiki/Pirates" class="mw-redirect" title="Pirates">pirates</a> and protect the Crown's monopoly of revenue, only two ports were open to foreign trade—Veracruz on the Atlantic and Acapulco on the Pacific. Among the best-known pirate attacks are the 1663 <a href="/wiki/Sack_of_Campeche_(1663)" title="Sack of Campeche (1663)">Sack of Campeche</a><sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup> and 1683 <a href="/wiki/Attack_on_Veracruz" title="Attack on Veracruz">Attack on Veracruz</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup> Of greater concern to the crown was of foreign invasion, especially after Britain seized in 1762 the Spanish ports of Havana, Cuba and Manila, the Philippines in the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War" title="Seven Years' War">Seven Years' War</a>. It created a standing military, increased coastal fortifications, and expanded the northern <a href="/wiki/Presidio" title="Presidio">presidios</a> and <a href="/wiki/Spanish_missions_in_California" title="Spanish missions in California">missions</a> into <a href="/wiki/Alta_California" title="Alta California">Alta California</a>. The volatility of the urban poor in Mexico City was evident in the 1692 riot in the Zócalo. The riot over the price of maize escalated to a full-scale attack on the seats of power, with the viceregal palace and the archbishop's residence attacked by the mob.<sup id="cite_ref-Cope,_R._Douglas_1994_83-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cope,_R._Douglas_1994-83">[83]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Due to the importance of New Spain administrative base, Mexico was the location of the <a href="/wiki/House_of_the_First_Print_Shop_in_the_Americas" title="House of the First Print Shop in the Americas">first printing shop</a> (1539),<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Royal_and_Pontifical_University_of_Mexico" title="Royal and Pontifical University of Mexico">first university</a> (1551),<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Alameda_Central" title="Alameda Central">first public park</a> (1592),<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Biblioteca_Palafoxiana" title="Biblioteca Palafoxiana">first public library</a> (1640) in the Americas,<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup> among other institutions. Important artists of the colonial period, include the writers <a href="/wiki/Juan_Ruiz_de_Alarc%C3%B3n" title="Juan Ruiz de Alarcón">Juan Ruiz de Alarcón</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carlos_de_Sig%C3%BCenza_y_G%C3%B3ngora" title="Carlos de Sigüenza y Góngora">Carlos de Sigüenza y Góngora</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sor_Juana_In%C3%A9s_de_la_Cruz" class="mw-redirect" title="Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz">Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz</a>, painters <a href="/wiki/Crist%C3%B3bal_de_Villalpando" title="Cristóbal de Villalpando">Cristóbal de Villalpando</a> and <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Cabrera_(painter)" title="Miguel Cabrera (painter)">Miguel Cabrera</a>, and architect <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Tols%C3%A1" title="Manuel Tolsá">Manuel Tolsá</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Academy_of_San_Carlos" title="Academy of San Carlos">Academy of San Carlos</a> (1781) was the first major school and museum of art in the Americas.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup> German scientist <a href="/wiki/Alexander_von_Humboldt" title="Alexander von Humboldt">Alexander von Humboldt</a> spent a year in Mexico, finding the scientific community in the capital active and learned. He met Mexican scientist <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Manuel_del_R%C3%ADo_Fern%C3%A1ndez" class="mw-redirect" title="Andrés Manuel del Río Fernández">Andrés Manuel del Río Fernández</a>, who discovered the element <a href="/wiki/Vanadium" title="Vanadium">vanadium</a> in 1801.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> Many Mexican cultural features including <a href="/wiki/Tequila" title="Tequila">tequila</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup> first distilled in the 16th century, <a href="/wiki/Charreria" class="mw-redirect" title="Charreria">charreria</a> (17th),<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mariachi" title="Mariachi">mariachi</a> (18th) and <a href="/wiki/Mexican_cuisine" title="Mexican cuisine">Mexican cuisine</a>, a fusion <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas" title="Indigenous peoples of the Americas">of American</a> and European (<a href="/wiki/Spanish_cuisine" title="Spanish cuisine">particularly Spanish</a>) cuisine, arose during the colonial era. </p> 
      <h3><span id="War_of_Independence_.281810.E2.80.931821.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="War_of_Independence_(1810–1821)">War of Independence (1810–1821)</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mexican_War_of_Independence" title="Mexican War of Independence">Mexican War of Independence</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:177px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Miguel_Hidalgo_con_estandarte.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Miguel_Hidalgo_con_estandarte.jpg/175px-Miguel_Hidalgo_con_estandarte.jpg" decoding="async" width="175" height="270" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Miguel_Hidalgo_con_estandarte.jpg/263px-Miguel_Hidalgo_con_estandarte.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Miguel_Hidalgo_con_estandarte.jpg/350px-Miguel_Hidalgo_con_estandarte.jpg 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="927"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Miguel_Hidalgo_con_estandarte.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Father <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Hidalgo" class="mw-redirect" title="Miguel Hidalgo">Miguel Hidalgo</a> with the banner of the Virgin of Guadalupe. <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Fabr%C3%A9s" title="Antonio Fabrés">Antonio Fabrés</a>, 1905
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>On 16 September 1810, a "loyalist revolt" against the ruling <a href="/wiki/Junta_(governing_body)" title="Junta (governing body)">junta</a> was declared by priest <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Hidalgo_y_Costilla" title="Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla">Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla</a>, in the small town of <a href="/wiki/Dolores_Hidalgo" title="Dolores Hidalgo">Dolores</a>, Guanajuato.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup> This event, known as the <a href="/wiki/Cry_of_Dolores" title="Cry of Dolores">Cry of Dolores</a> (Spanish: <i>Grito de Dolores</i>) is commemorated each year, on 16 September, as Mexico's independence day.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> The first insurgent group was formed by Hidalgo, the Spanish <a href="/wiki/Viceregal" class="mw-redirect" title="Viceregal">viceregal</a> army captain <a href="/wiki/Ignacio_Allende" title="Ignacio Allende">Ignacio Allende</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Militia" title="Militia">militia</a> captain <a href="/wiki/Juan_Aldama" title="Juan Aldama">Juan Aldama</a> and <i>La Corregidora</i> (English: "The Magistrate") <a href="/wiki/Josefa_Ortiz_de_Dom%C3%ADnguez" title="Josefa Ortiz de Domínguez">Josefa Ortiz de Domínguez</a>. Hidalgo and some of his soldiers were captured and <a href="/wiki/Executed_by_firing_squad" class="mw-redirect" title="Executed by firing squad">executed by firing squad</a> in <a href="/wiki/Chihuahua,_Chihuahua" class="mw-redirect" title="Chihuahua, Chihuahua">Chihuahua</a>, on 31 July 1811.<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-108">[108]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>17–27</span></sup> </p>
      <p>Following Hidalgo's death, the leadership was assumed by <a href="/wiki/Ignacio_L%C3%B3pez_Ray%C3%B3n" title="Ignacio López Rayón">Ignacio López Rayón</a> and then by the priest <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Mar%C3%ADa_Morelos" title="José María Morelos">José María Morelos</a>, who occupied key southern cities with the support of <a href="/wiki/Mariano_Matamoros" title="Mariano Matamoros">Mariano Matamoros</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nicol%C3%A1s_Bravo" title="Nicolás Bravo">Nicolás Bravo</a>. In one notable incident, Nicolas Bravo captured 200 royalist soldiers, whom Morelos ordered should be executed in revenge of the murder of Bravo's father. In an act of mercy, Bravo instead pardoned the prisoners, most of whom then joined the insurgent cause.<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_108-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-108">[108]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>40–41</span></sup> In 1813 the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Chilpancingo" title="Congress of Chilpancingo">Congress of Chilpancingo</a> was convened and, on 6 November, signed the "<a href="/wiki/Solemn_Act_of_the_Declaration_of_Independence_of_Northern_America" title="Solemn Act of the Declaration of Independence of Northern America">Solemn Act of the Declaration of Independence of Northern America</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_108-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-108">[108]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>35–37</span></sup> . This Act also abolished slavery and the caste system and, being a Catholic priest himself, Morelos called for Roman Catholicism to be the exclusive faith in Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_108-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-108">[108]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>44–50</span></sup> Morelos was captured and executed on 22 December 1815.<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_108-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-108">[108]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>46</span></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Abrazo_de_Acatempan.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Abrazo_de_Acatempan.JPG/220px-Abrazo_de_Acatempan.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Abrazo_de_Acatempan.JPG/330px-Abrazo_de_Acatempan.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Abrazo_de_Acatempan.JPG/440px-Abrazo_de_Acatempan.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3056" data-file-height="2292"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Abrazo_de_Acatempan.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Depiction of the <i>Abrazo de Acatempan</i> between <a href="/wiki/Agust%C3%ADn_de_Iturbide" title="Agustín de Iturbide">Agustín de Iturbide</a>, left, and <a href="/wiki/Vicente_Guerrero" title="Vicente Guerrero">Vicente Guerrero</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In subsequent years, the insurgency was near collapse, but in 1820 <a href="/wiki/Viceroy" title="Viceroy">Viceroy</a> <a href="/wiki/Juan_Ruiz_de_Apodaca" class="mw-redirect" title="Juan Ruiz de Apodaca">Juan Ruiz de Apodaca</a> sent an army under the <a href="/wiki/Criollo_people" title="Criollo people">criollo</a> general <a href="/wiki/Agust%C3%ADn_de_Iturbide" title="Agustín de Iturbide">Agustín de Iturbide</a> against the troops of <a href="/wiki/Vicente_Guerrero" title="Vicente Guerrero">Vicente Guerrero</a> who had among his trusted soldiers, <a href="/wiki/Filipino_Mexicans" class="mw-redirect" title="Filipino Mexicans">Filipino Mexicans</a> who were concentrated in <a href="/wiki/Guerrero" title="Guerrero">Guerrero</a>, a state later named after Vicente Guerrero himself and where the Mexican flag was first sewn.
