      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:NewSenateBldgMexicoCity.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/NewSenateBldgMexicoCity.jpg/200px-NewSenateBldgMexicoCity.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="137" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/NewSenateBldgMexicoCity.jpg/300px-NewSenateBldgMexicoCity.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/NewSenateBldgMexicoCity.jpg/400px-NewSenateBldgMexicoCity.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3649" data-file-height="2503"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:NewSenateBldgMexicoCity.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>New <a href="/wiki/Senate" title="Senate">Senate</a> building on <a href="/wiki/Paseo_de_la_Reforma" title="Paseo de la Reforma">Paseo de la Reforma</a> and Insurgentes in Mexico City
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The United Mexican States are a federation whose government is <a href="/wiki/Representative_democracy" title="Representative democracy">representative</a>, democratic and <a href="/wiki/Republicanism" title="Republicanism">republican</a> based on a presidential system according to the 1917 Constitution. The constitution establishes three levels of government: the federal Union, the state governments and the municipal governments. According to the constitution, all constituent states of the federation must have a republican form of government composed of three branches: the executive, represented by a governor and an appointed cabinet, the legislative branch constituted by a <a href="/wiki/List_of_Mexican_state_legislatures" title="List of Mexican state legislatures">unicameral congress</a><sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research" title="Wikipedia:No original research"><span title="The material near this tag possibly contains original research. (September 2017)">original research?</span></a></i>]</sup> and the judiciary, which will include a state Supreme Court of Justice. They also have their own civil and judicial codes. </p>
      <p>The federal <a href="/wiki/Legislature" title="Legislature">legislature</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Bicameralism" title="Bicameralism">bicameral</a> <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_the_Union" title="Congress of the Union">Congress of the Union</a>, composed of the <a href="/wiki/Senate_of_the_Republic_(Mexico)" title="Senate of the Republic (Mexico)">Senate of the Republic</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Chamber_of_Deputies_(Mexico)" title="Chamber of Deputies (Mexico)">Chamber of Deputies</a>. The Congress makes <a href="/wiki/Federal_law" title="Federal law">federal law</a>, declares war, imposes taxes, approves the national budget and international treaties, and ratifies diplomatic appointments.<sup id="cite_ref-congress_165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-congress-165">[165]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The federal Congress, as well as the state legislatures, are elected by a system of <a href="/wiki/Parallel_voting" title="Parallel voting">parallel voting</a> that includes plurality and <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">proportional representation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[166]</a></sup> The Chamber of Deputies has 500 deputies. Of these, 300 are elected by <a href="/wiki/Plurality_voting_system" class="mw-redirect" title="Plurality voting system">plurality vote</a> in <a href="/wiki/Single-member_district" title="Single-member district">single-member districts</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Federal_electoral_districts_of_Mexico" title="Federal electoral districts of Mexico">federal electoral districts</a>) and 200 are elected by proportional representation with <a href="/wiki/Closed_list" title="Closed list">closed party lists</a><sup id="cite_ref-COFIPE_congreso_167-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COFIPE_congreso-167">[167]</a></sup> for which the country is divided into five electoral constituencies.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup> The Senate is made up of 128 senators. Of these, 64 senators (two for each state and two for Mexico City) are elected by plurality vote in pairs; 32 senators are the first minority or first-runner up (one for each state and one for Mexico City), and 32 are elected by proportional representation from national closed party lists.<sup id="cite_ref-COFIPE_congreso_167-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COFIPE_congreso-167">[167]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">executive</a> is the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Mexico" title="President of Mexico">President of the United Mexican States</a>, who is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a> and <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">government</a>, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a> of the Mexican military forces. The President also appoints the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Executive_Cabinet" class="mw-redirect" title="Mexican Executive Cabinet">Cabinet</a> and other officers. The President is responsible for executing and enforcing the law, and has the power to <a href="/wiki/Veto" title="Veto">veto</a> bills.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Suprema4.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Suprema4.jpg/220px-Suprema4.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Suprema4.jpg/330px-Suprema4.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Suprema4.jpg/440px-Suprema4.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3264" data-file-height="2448"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Suprema4.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Site of the <a href="/wiki/National_Supreme_Court_of_Justice" class="mw-redirect" title="National Supreme Court of Justice">Supreme Court of Justice</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The highest organ of the <a href="/wiki/Judiciary" title="Judiciary">judicial branch</a> of government is the <a href="/wiki/National_Supreme_Court_of_Justice" class="mw-redirect" title="National Supreme Court of Justice">Supreme Court of Justice</a>, the national <a href="/wiki/Supreme_court" title="Supreme court">supreme court</a>, which has eleven judges appointed by the President and approved by the Senate. The Supreme Court of Justice interprets laws and judges cases of federal competency. Other institutions of the judiciary are the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Electoral_Tribunal" title="Federal Electoral Tribunal">Federal Electoral Tribunal</a>, collegiate, unitary and district tribunals, and the Council of the Federal Judiciary.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Mexico" title="Politics of Mexico">Politics of Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Three parties have historically been the dominant parties in Mexican politics: the <a href="/wiki/Institutional_Revolutionary_Party" title="Institutional Revolutionary Party">Institutional Revolutionary Party</a> (PRI), a <a href="/wiki/Catch-all_party" class="mw-redirect" title="Catch-all party">catch-all party</a><sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup> and member of <a href="/wiki/Socialist_International" title="Socialist International">Socialist International</a><sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup> that was founded in 1929 to unite all the factions of the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Revolution" title="Mexican Revolution">Mexican Revolution</a> and held an almost hegemonic power in Mexican politics since then; the <a href="/wiki/National_Action_Party_(Mexico)" title="National Action Party (Mexico)">National Action Party</a> (PAN), a conservative party founded in 1939 and belonging to the <a href="/wiki/Christian_Democrat_Organization_of_America" title="Christian Democrat Organization of America">Christian Democrat Organization of America</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[173]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Party_of_the_Democratic_Revolution" title="Party of the Democratic Revolution">Party of the Democratic Revolution</a> (PRD) a left-wing party,<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup> founded in 1989 as the successor of the coalition of socialists and liberal parties. PRD emerged after what has now been proven was a stolen election in 1988,<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup> and has won numerous state and local elections since then. PAN won its first governorship in 1989, and won the presidency in 2000 and 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[176]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>A new political party, <a href="/wiki/National_Regeneration_Movement" title="National Regeneration Movement">National Regeneration Movement</a> (MORENA), a leftist-populist party, emerged after the 2012 election and dominated the <a href="/wiki/2018_Mexican_general_election" title="2018 Mexican general election">2018 Mexican general election</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Unlike many Latin American countries, the military in Mexico does not participate in politics and is under civilian control.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_enforcement">Law enforcement</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Mexico" title="Law enforcement in Mexico">Law enforcement in Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:FederalPoliceDF.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/FederalPoliceDF.jpg/170px-FederalPoliceDF.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="302" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/FederalPoliceDF.jpg/255px-FederalPoliceDF.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/FederalPoliceDF.jpg/340px-FederalPoliceDF.jpg 2x" data-file-width="576" data-file-height="1024"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:FederalPoliceDF.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Federal_Police_(Mexico)" title="Federal Police (Mexico)">Federal Police</a> headquarters in <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Public security is enacted at the three levels of government, each of which has different prerogatives and responsibilities. Local and state police departments are primarily in charge of law enforcement, whereas the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Federal_Police" class="mw-redirect" title="Mexican Federal Police">Mexican Federal Police</a> are in charge of specialized duties. All levels report to the Secretaría de Seguridad Pública (Secretary of Public Security). The General Attorney's Office (Fiscalía General de la República, FGR) is a constitutional autonomous organism in charge of investigating and prosecuting crimes at the federal level, mainly those related to drug and arms trafficking,<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup> espionage, and bank robberies.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup> The FGR operates the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Ministerial_Police" title="Federal Ministerial Police">Federal Ministerial Police</a> (Policia Federal Ministerial, PMF) an investigative and preventive agency.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>While the government generally respects the human rights of its citizens, serious abuses of power have been reported in security operations in the southern part of the country and in indigenous communities and poor urban neighborhoods.<sup id="cite_ref-brit-mex_182-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brit-mex-182">[182]</a></sup> The National Human Rights Commission has had little impact in reversing this trend, engaging mostly in documentation but failing to use its powers to issue public condemnations to the officials who ignore its recommendations.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup> By law, all defendants have the rights that assure them fair trials and humane treatment; however, the system is overburdened and overwhelmed with several problems.<sup id="cite_ref-brit-mex_182-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brit-mex-182">[182]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Despite the efforts of the authorities to fight crime and fraud, most Mexicans have low confidence in the police or the judicial system, and therefore, few crimes are actually reported by the citizens.<sup id="cite_ref-brit-mex_182-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brit-mex-182">[182]</a></sup> The <i>Global Integrity Index</i> which measures the existence and effectiveness of national anti-corruption mechanisms rated Mexico 31st behind Kenya, Thailand, and Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup> In 2008, president Calderón proposed a major reform of the judicial system, which was approved by the Congress of the Union, which included oral trials, the presumption of innocence for defendants, the authority of local police to investigate crime—until then a prerogative of special police units—and several other changes intended to speed up trials.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[185]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Crime">Crime</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Crime_in_Mexico" title="Crime in Mexico">Crime in Mexico</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Drug_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Mexican Drug War">Mexican Drug War</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Human_trafficking_in_Mexico" title="Human trafficking in Mexico">Human trafficking in Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Drug cartels are a major concern in Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-Cartel_186-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cartel-186">[186]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Drug_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Mexican Drug War">Mexico's drug war</a>, ongoing since 2006, has left over 120,000 dead and perhaps another 37,000 missing.<sup id="cite_ref-cfrdeaths_34-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cfrdeaths-34">[34]</a></sup> The Mexican <a href="/wiki/Drug_cartel" title="Drug cartel">drug cartels</a> have as many as 100,000 members.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup> Mexico's <a href="/wiki/Instituto_Nacional_de_Estad%C3%ADstica_y_Geograf%C3%ADa" class="mw-redirect" title="Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Geografía">National Geography and Statistics Institute</a> estimated that in 2014, one-fifth of Mexicans were victims of some sort of crime.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup> The U.S. <a href="/wiki/Department_of_State" class="mw-redirect" title="Department of State">Department of State</a> warns its citizens to exercise increased caution when traveling in Mexico, issuing travel advisories on its website.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[189]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ayotz1napa_ohs202.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Ayotz1napa_ohs202.jpg/220px-Ayotz1napa_ohs202.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Ayotz1napa_ohs202.jpg/330px-Ayotz1napa_ohs202.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Ayotz1napa_ohs202.jpg/440px-Ayotz1napa_ohs202.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2288" data-file-height="1520"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ayotz1napa_ohs202.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Demonstration on 26 September 2015, in the first anniversary of the <a href="/wiki/2014_Iguala_mass_kidnapping" title="2014 Iguala mass kidnapping">disappearance of the 43 students</a> in the Mexican town of <a href="/wiki/Iguala" title="Iguala">Iguala</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>President <a href="/wiki/Felipe_Calder%C3%B3n" title="Felipe Calderón">Felipe Calderón</a> (2006–12) made eradicating organized crime one of the top priorities of his administration by deploying military personnel to cities where drug cartels operate. This move was criticized by the opposition parties and the National Human Rights Commission for escalating the violence,<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup> but its effects have been positively evaluated by the US State Department's <a href="/wiki/Bureau_for_International_Narcotics_and_Law_Enforcement_Affairs" class="mw-redirect" title="Bureau for International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs">Bureau for International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs</a> as having obtained "unprecedented results" with "many important successes".<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Since President Felipe Calderón launched a crackdown against cartels in 2006, more than 28,000 alleged criminals have been successfully killed.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[192]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup> Of the total drug-related violence 4% are innocent people,<sup id="cite_ref-MSNBC_194-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MSNBC-194">[194]</a></sup> mostly by-passers and people trapped in between shootings; 90% accounts for criminals and 6% for military personnel and police officers.<sup id="cite_ref-MSNBC_194-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MSNBC-194">[194]</a></sup> In October 2007, President Calderón and US president <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">George W. Bush</a> announced the <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A9rida_Initiative" title="Mérida Initiative">Mérida Initiative</a>, a plan of law enforcement cooperation between the two countries.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>More than 100 journalists and <a href="/wiki/List_of_journalists_and_media_workers_killed_in_Mexico" title="List of journalists and media workers killed in Mexico">media workers have been killed or disappeared</a> since 2000, and most of these crimes remained unsolved, improperly investigated, and with few perpetrators arrested and convicted.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/2014_Iguala_mass_kidnapping" title="2014 Iguala mass kidnapping">mass kidnapping</a> of the 43 students in <a href="/wiki/Iguala" title="Iguala">Iguala</a> on 26 September 2014 triggered nationwide protests against the government's weak response to the disappearances and widespread corruption that gives free rein to criminal organizations.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[198]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Mexico" title="Foreign relations of Mexico">Foreign relations of Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:President_Donald_J._Trump_at_the_G20_Summit_(44300765490).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/President_Donald_J._Trump_at_the_G20_Summit_%2844300765490%29.jpg/220px-President_Donald_J._Trump_at_the_G20_Summit_%2844300765490%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/President_Donald_J._Trump_at_the_G20_Summit_%2844300765490%29.jpg/330px-President_Donald_J._Trump_at_the_G20_Summit_%2844300765490%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/President_Donald_J._Trump_at_the_G20_Summit_%2844300765490%29.jpg/440px-President_Donald_J._Trump_at_the_G20_Summit_%2844300765490%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="800"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:President_Donald_J._Trump_at_the_G20_Summit_(44300765490).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>President <a href="/wiki/Enrique_Pe%C3%B1a_Nieto" title="Enrique Peña Nieto">Enrique Peña Nieto</a>, President <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a>, and Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Justin_Trudeau" title="Justin Trudeau">Justin Trudeau</a> sign the <a href="/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Mexico%E2%80%93Canada_Agreement" title="United States–Mexico–Canada Agreement">United States–Mexico–Canada Agreement</a> during the <a href="/wiki/2018_G20_Buenos_Aires_summit" title="2018 G20 Buenos Aires summit">G20 summit</a> in <a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires" title="Buenos Aires">Buenos Aires</a>, <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a>, on November 30, 2018.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The foreign relations of Mexico are directed by the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Mexico" title="President of Mexico">President of Mexico</a><sup id="cite_ref-CPEUM89_199-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CPEUM89-199">[199]</a></sup> and managed through the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Mexico)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Mexico)">Ministry of Foreign Affairs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-SRE_200-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SRE-200">[200]</a></sup> The principles of the <a href="/wiki/Foreign_policy" title="Foreign policy">foreign policy</a> are constitutionally recognized in the Article 89, Section 10, which include: respect for <a href="/wiki/International_law" title="International law">international law</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_state" title="Sovereign state">legal equality of states</a>, their <a href="/wiki/Sovereignty" title="Sovereignty">sovereignty</a> and <a href="/wiki/Independence" title="Independence">independence</a>, trend to <a href="/wiki/Non-interventionism" title="Non-interventionism">non-interventionism</a> in the domestic affairs of other countries, <a href="/wiki/Dispute_resolution" title="Dispute resolution">peaceful resolution of conflicts</a>, and promotion of <a href="/wiki/International_security" title="International security">collective security</a> through active participation in <a href="/wiki/International_organizations" class="mw-redirect" title="International organizations">international organizations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CPEUM89_199-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CPEUM89-199">[199]</a></sup> Since the 1930s, the <a href="/wiki/Estrada_Doctrine" title="Estrada Doctrine">Estrada Doctrine</a> has served as a crucial complement to these principles.<sup id="cite_ref-estradadoctrine_201-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-estradadoctrine-201">[201]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Mexico is founding member of several international organizations, most notably the United Nations,<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">Organization of American States</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Velázquez_Flores_2007,_p._145_203-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Velázquez_Flores_2007,_p._145-203">[203]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_Ibero-American_States" title="Organization of Ibero-American States">Organization of Ibero-American States</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/OPANAL" title="OPANAL">OPANAL</a><sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[205]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Rio_Group" title="Rio Group">Rio Group</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup> In 2008, Mexico contributed over 40 million <a href="/wiki/American_dollar" class="mw-redirect" title="American dollar">dollars</a> to the United Nations regular budget.<sup id="cite_ref-unbudget_207-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unbudget-207">[207]</a></sup> In addition, it was the only Latin American member of the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" class="mw-redirect" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a> since it joined in 1994 until <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a> gained full membership in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[208]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Mexico is considered a <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional power</a><sup id="cite_ref-regionalpower_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-regionalpower-210">[210]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-regionalpower2_211-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-regionalpower2-211">[211]</a></sup> hence its presence in major economic groups such as the <a href="/wiki/G8%2B5" title="G8+5">G8+5</a> and the <a href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" class="mw-redirect" title="G-20 major economies">G-20</a>. In addition, since the 1990s Mexico has sought a <a href="/wiki/Reform_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council" title="Reform of the United Nations Security Council">reform of the United Nations Security Council and its working methods</a><sup id="cite_ref-Foreign_Affairs_2005_p._215_212-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Foreign_Affairs_2005_p._215-212">[212]</a></sup> with the support of Canada, Italy, Pakistan and other nine countries, which form a group informally called the <a href="/wiki/Coffee_Club" class="mw-redirect" title="Coffee Club">Coffee Club</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-coffeeclub_213-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-coffeeclub-213">[213]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>After the <a href="/wiki/Independence_of_Mexico" class="mw-redirect" title="Independence of Mexico">War of Independence</a>, the relations of Mexico were focused primarily on the United States, its northern neighbor, <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Mexico" title="Economy of Mexico">largest trading partner</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[214]</a></sup> and the most <a href="/wiki/Superpower" title="Superpower">powerful actor in hemispheric and world affairs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[215]</a></sup> Mexico supported the <a href="/wiki/Cuban_Revolution" title="Cuban Revolution">Cuban government</a> since its establishment in the early 1960s,<sup id="cite_ref-keller_216-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-keller-216">[216]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Sandinista_National_Liberation_Front" title="Sandinista National Liberation Front">Sandinista revolution</a> in Nicaragua during the late 1970s,<sup id="cite_ref-salaverry_217-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-salaverry-217">[217]</a></sup> and leftist revolutionary groups in <a href="/wiki/El_Salvador" title="El Salvador">El Salvador</a> during the 1980s.<sup id="cite_ref-elsalvador_218-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-elsalvador-218">[218]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Felipe_Calder%C3%B3n" title="Felipe Calderón">Felipe Calderón</a>'s administration (2006–2012) put a greater emphasis on relations with Latin America and the Caribbean.<sup id="cite_ref-Calderon_FP_219-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Calderon_FP-219">[219]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Enrique_Pe%C3%B1a_Nieto" title="Enrique Peña Nieto">Enrique Peña Nieto</a> (2012–2018) emphasized economic issues and foreign investment, particularly the now-defunct <a href="/wiki/Trans-Pacific_Partnership" title="Trans-Pacific Partnership">Trans-Pacific Partnership</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[220]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Manuel_L%C3%B3pez_Obrador" title="Andrés Manuel López Obrador">Andrés Manuel López Obrador</a> has taken a cautious approach, unwilling to challenge U.S. President <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> on either trade or migration, while maintaining neutrality on <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_protests_(2014%E2%80%93present)" title="Venezuelan protests (2014–present)">Venezuela</a> and welcoming Chinese money.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[221]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Armed_Forces" title="Mexican Armed Forces">Mexican Armed Forces</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Mexico" title="Military history of Mexico">Military history of Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg/170px-Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="238" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg/255px-Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg/340px-Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1500" data-file-height="2100"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Navy" title="Mexican Navy">Mexican Navy</a> <a href="/wiki/Eurocopter" class="mw-redirect" title="Eurocopter">Eurocopter</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Mexican military "provides a unique example of a military leadership's transforming itself into a civilian political elite, simultaneously transferring the basis of power from the army to a civilian state."<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[222]</a></sup> The transformation was brought about by revolutionary generals in the 1920s and 1930s, following the demise of the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Army" title="Federal Army">Federal Army</a> following its complete defeat during the decade-long Mexican Revolution.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[223]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Mexican Armed Forces have two branches: the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Army" title="Mexican Army">Mexican Army</a> (which includes the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Air_Force" title="Mexican Air Force">Mexican Air Force</a>), and the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Navy" title="Mexican Navy">Mexican Navy</a>. The Mexican Armed Forces maintain significant infrastructure, including facilities for design, research, and testing of weapons, vehicles, aircraft, naval vessels, defense systems and electronics;<sup id="cite_ref-impreso.milenio.com_224-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-impreso.milenio.com-224">[224]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Mexican_Naval_missile_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mexican_Naval_missile-225">[225]</a></sup> military industry manufacturing centers for building such systems, and advanced naval dockyards that build heavy military vessels and advanced missile technologies.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[226]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In recent years, Mexico has improved its training techniques, military command and information structures and has taken steps to becoming more self-reliant in supplying its military by designing as well as manufacturing its own arms,<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[227]</a></sup> missiles,<sup id="cite_ref-Mexican_Naval_missile_225-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mexican_Naval_missile-225">[225]</a></sup> aircraft,<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[228]</a></sup> vehicles, heavy weaponry, electronics,<sup id="cite_ref-impreso.milenio.com_224-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-impreso.milenio.com-224">[224]</a></sup> defense systems,<sup id="cite_ref-impreso.milenio.com_224-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-impreso.milenio.com-224">[224]</a></sup> armor, heavy military industrial equipment and heavy naval vessels.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[229]</a></sup> Since the 1990s, when the military escalated its role in the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Drug_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Mexican Drug War">war on drugs</a>, increasing importance has been placed on acquiring airborne surveillance platforms, aircraft, <a href="/wiki/Helicopters" class="mw-redirect" title="Helicopters">helicopters</a>, digital war-fighting technologies,<sup id="cite_ref-impreso.milenio.com_224-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-impreso.milenio.com-224">[224]</a></sup> urban warfare equipment and rapid troop transport.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[230]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Mexico has the capabilities to manufacture nuclear weapons, but abandoned this possibility with the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Tlatelolco" title="Treaty of Tlatelolco">Treaty of Tlatelolco</a> in 1968 and pledged to only use its nuclear technology for peaceful purposes.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[231]</a></sup> In 1970, Mexico's national institute for nuclear research successfully refined weapons grade uranium<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[232]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag failed verification of its source citation(s). (March 2011)">failed verification</span></a></i>]</sup> which is used in the manufacture of nuclear weapons but in April 2010, Mexico agreed to turn over its weapons grade uranium to the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[233]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[234]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Historically, Mexico has remained neutral in international conflicts,<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[235]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mexico_in_World_War_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Mexico in World War II">with the exception of World War II</a>. However, in recent years some political parties have proposed an amendment of the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Mexico" title="Constitution of Mexico">Constitution</a> to allow the Mexican Army, Air Force or Navy to collaborate with the United Nations in <a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">peacekeeping missions</a>, or to provide military help to countries that officially ask for it.<sup id="cite_ref-neutral_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-neutral-236">[236]</a></sup> Mexico signed the UN treaty on the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Prohibition_of_Nuclear_Weapons" title="Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons">Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[237]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_divisions">Political divisions</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Mexico" title="Administrative divisions of Mexico">Administrative divisions of Mexico</a>, <a href="/wiki/States_of_Mexico" class="mw-redirect" title="States of Mexico">States of Mexico</a>, <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Mexico" title="Municipalities of Mexico">Municipalities of Mexico</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Mexican_state_legislatures" title="List of Mexican state legislatures">List of Mexican state legislatures</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The United Mexican States are a federation of 31 free and sovereign states, which form a union that exercises a degree of jurisdiction over <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-thought_238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thought-238">[238]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Each state has its own constitution, <a href="/wiki/Congress" title="Congress">congress</a>, and a judiciary, and its citizens elect by <a href="/wiki/Direct_vote" class="mw-redirect" title="Direct vote">direct voting</a> a <a href="/wiki/List_of_Mexican_state_governors" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Mexican state governors">governor</a> for a six-year term, and representatives to their respective unicameral state congresses for three-year terms.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[239]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Mexico City is a special political division that belongs to the federation as a whole and not to a particular state.<sup id="cite_ref-thought_238-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thought-238">[238]</a></sup> Formerly known as the Federal District, its autonomy was previously limited relative to that of the states.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[240]</a></sup> It dropped this designation in 2016 and is in the process of achieving greater political autonomy by becoming a federal entity with <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Assembly_of_Mexico_City" class="mw-redirect" title="Constitutional Assembly of Mexico City">its own constitution</a> and congress.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[241]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The states are divided into <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Mexico" title="Municipalities of Mexico">municipalities</a>, the smallest administrative political entity in the country, governed by a <a href="/wiki/Mayor" title="Mayor">mayor or municipal president</a> (<i lang="es" title="Spanish-language text">presidente municipal</i>), elected by its residents by plurality.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[242]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="center" style="width:auto; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;">
       <div role="img" class="noresize" style="width: 600px; line-height: 1; text-align: center; background-color: #ffffff; position: relative;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Division_politica_mexico.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Division_politica_mexico.svg/600px-Division_politica_mexico.svg.png" decoding="async" width="600" height="404" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Division_politica_mexico.svg/900px-Division_politica_mexico.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Division_politica_mexico.svg/1200px-Division_politica_mexico.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="460" data-file-height="310"></a> 
        <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:444px; top:200.8px">

         <br>Mexico
        </div>

         <br>Ocean
        </div>

         <br>America
        </div>

        </div>

        </div>

        </div> 
        <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:462px; top:346px">
         <a href="/wiki/Chiapas" title="Chiapas">Chiapas</a>
        </div>

        </div>

        </div>

        </div> 
        <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:312px; top:340px">
         <a href="/wiki/Guerrero" title="Guerrero">Guerrero</a>
        </div> 
        <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:345px; top:283px">
         <a href="/wiki/Hidalgo_(state)" title="Hidalgo (state)">HD</a>
        </div> 
        <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:234px; top:283px">
         <a href="/wiki/Jalisco" title="Jalisco">Jalisco</a>
        </div> 
        <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:324.6px; top:298px">
         <a href="/wiki/State_of_Mexico" title="State of Mexico">EM</a>
        </div> 
        <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:264px; top:300.4px">
         <a href="/wiki/Michoac%C3%A1n" title="Michoacán">Michoacán</a>
        </div> 
        <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:340.8px; top:313px">
         <a href="/wiki/Morelos" title="Morelos">MO</a>
        </div> 
        <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:210px; top:253.6px">
         <a href="/wiki/Nayarit" title="Nayarit">Nayarit</a>
        </div> 
        <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:318px; top:170.8px">
         <a href="/wiki/Nuevo_Le%C3%B3n" title="Nuevo León">Nuevo<br>León</a>
        </div> 
        <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:384px; top:346px">
         <a href="/wiki/Oaxaca" title="Oaxaca">Oaxaca</a>
        </div> 
        <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:360px; top:316px">
         <a href="/wiki/Puebla" title="Puebla">Puebla</a>
