         <td><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Flag_of_Veracruz.svg/23px-Flag_of_Veracruz.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="13" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Flag_of_Veracruz.svg/35px-Flag_of_Veracruz.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Flag_of_Veracruz.svg/46px-Flag_of_Veracruz.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="350" data-file-height="200">&nbsp;</span><a href="/wiki/Veracruz" title="Veracruz">Veracruz (VER)</a> </td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Xalapa" title="Xalapa">Xalapa</a> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Flag_of_Mexico_City%2C_Mexico.svg/23px-Flag_of_Mexico_City%2C_Mexico.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="13" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Flag_of_Mexico_City%2C_Mexico.svg/35px-Flag_of_Mexico_City%2C_Mexico.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Flag_of_Mexico_City%2C_Mexico.svg/46px-Flag_of_Mexico_City%2C_Mexico.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="350" data-file-height="200">&nbsp;</span><a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City (CDMX)</a> </td> 
         <td>Mexico City </td> 
         <td><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Flag_of_Yucatan.svg/23px-Flag_of_Yucatan.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Flag_of_Yucatan.svg/35px-Flag_of_Yucatan.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Flag_of_Yucatan.svg/45px-Flag_of_Yucatan.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="400">&nbsp;</span><a href="/wiki/Yucat%C3%A1n" title="Yucatán">Yucatán (YUC)</a> </td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/M%C3%A9rida,_Yucat%C3%A1n" title="Mérida, Yucatán">Mérida</a> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Flag_of_Michoacan.svg/23px-Flag_of_Michoacan.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="13" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Flag_of_Michoacan.svg/35px-Flag_of_Michoacan.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Flag_of_Michoacan.svg/46px-Flag_of_Michoacan.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="350" data-file-height="200">&nbsp;</span><a href="/wiki/Michoac%C3%A1n" title="Michoacán">Michoacán (MICH)</a> </td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Morelia" title="Morelia">Morelia</a> </td> 
         <td><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Flag_of_Zacatecas.svg/23px-Flag_of_Zacatecas.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="13" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Flag_of_Zacatecas.svg/35px-Flag_of_Zacatecas.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Flag_of_Zacatecas.svg/46px-Flag_of_Zacatecas.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="350" data-file-height="200">&nbsp;</span><a href="/wiki/Zacatecas" title="Zacatecas">Zacatecas (ZAC)</a> </td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Zacatecas_City" title="Zacatecas City">Zacatecas</a> </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Mexico" title="Economy of Mexico">Economy of Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_Mexico" title="Economic history of Mexico">Economic history of Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Mexico_Product_Export_Treemap.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Mexico_Product_Export_Treemap.jpg/290px-Mexico_Product_Export_Treemap.jpg" decoding="async" width="290" height="226" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Mexico_Product_Export_Treemap.jpg/435px-Mexico_Product_Export_Treemap.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Mexico_Product_Export_Treemap.jpg/580px-Mexico_Product_Export_Treemap.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1107" data-file-height="862"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Mexico_Product_Export_Treemap.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A proportional representation of Mexico's exports. The country has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_economic_complexity" title="List of countries by economic complexity">most complex economy</a> in Latin America.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>As of April 2018, Mexico has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">15th largest</a> nominal GDP (US$1.15 trillion)<sup id="cite_ref-invest_243-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-invest-243">[243]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">11th largest</a> by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a> (US$2.45 trillion). GDP annual average growth was 2.9% in 2016 and 2% in 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-invest_243-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-invest-243">[243]</a></sup> Agriculture has comprised 4% of the economy over the last two decades, while industry contributes 33% (mostly automotive, oil, and electronics) and services (notably financial services and tourism) contribute 63%.<sup id="cite_ref-invest_243-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-invest-243">[243]</a></sup> Mexico's GDP in PPP per capita was US$18,714.05. The World Bank reported in 2009 that the country's <a href="/wiki/Gross_National_Income" class="mw-redirect" title="Gross National Income">Gross National Income</a> in market exchange rates was the second highest in Latin America, after <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a> at US$1,830.392&nbsp;billion,<sup id="cite_ref-GNI_244-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GNI-244">[244]</a></sup> which led to the highest <a href="/wiki/Gross_National_Income" class="mw-redirect" title="Gross National Income">income per capita</a> in the region at $15,311.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[245]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-GNIPC_246-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GNIPC-246">[246]</a></sup> Mexico is now firmly established as an upper middle-income country. After the slowdown of 2001 the country has recovered and has grown 4.2, 3.0 and 4.8 percent in 2004, 2005 and 2006,<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[247]</a></sup> even though it is considered to be well below Mexico's potential growth.<sup id="cite_ref-Hufbauer_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hufbauer-248">[248]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> predicts growth rates of 2.3% and 2.7% for 2018 and 2019, respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-invest_243-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-invest-243">[243]</a></sup> By 2050, Mexico could potentially become the world's fifth or seventh largest economy.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[249]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[250]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Although multiple international organizations coincide and classify Mexico as an upper middle income country, or a middle class country<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[251]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BloombergEcon_252-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BloombergEcon-252">[252]</a></sup> Mexico's <a href="/wiki/National_Council_for_the_Evaluation_of_Social_Development_Policy_(CONEVAL)" title="National Council for the Evaluation of Social Development Policy (CONEVAL)">National Council for the Evaluation of Social Development Policy</a> (CONEVAL), which is the organization in charge to measure the country's poverty reports that a huge percentage of Mexico's population lives in poverty. According to said council, from 2006 to 2010 (year on which the CONEVAL published its first nationwide report of poverty) the portion of Mexicans who live in poverty rose from 18%–19%<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[253]</a></sup> to 46% (52 million people).<sup id="cite_ref-CONEVAL_254-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CONEVAL-254">[254]</a></sup> However, rather than Mexico's economy crashing, international economists attribute the huge increase in the percentage of population living below the country's poverty line to the CONEVAL using new standards to define it, as now besides people who lives below the economic welfare line, people who lacks at least one "social need" such as complete education, access to healthcare, access to regular food, housing services and goods, social security etc. were considered to be living in poverty (several countries do collect information regarding the persistence of said vulnerabilities on their population, but Mexico is the only one that classifies people lacking one or more of those needs as living below its national poverty line). Said economists do point out that the percentage of people living in poverty according to Mexico's national poverty line is around 40 times higher than the one reported by the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank's</a> international poverty line (with said difference being the biggest in the world) and ponder if it would not be better for countries in the situation of Mexico to adopt internationalized standards to measure poverty so the numbers obtained could be used to make accurate international comparisons.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">[255]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" class="mw-redirect" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">OECD</a>'s own poverty line (defined as the percentage of a country's population who earns 60%<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[256]</a></sup> or less of the national median income) 20% of Mexico's population lives in a situation of poverty.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">[257]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Torre_Axtel_y_Bolsa_de_Valores.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Torre_Axtel_y_Bolsa_de_Valores.jpg/180px-Torre_Axtel_y_Bolsa_de_Valores.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="240" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Torre_Axtel_y_Bolsa_de_Valores.jpg/270px-Torre_Axtel_y_Bolsa_de_Valores.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Torre_Axtel_y_Bolsa_de_Valores.jpg/360px-Torre_Axtel_y_Bolsa_de_Valores.jpg 2x" data-file-width="768" data-file-height="1024"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Torre_Axtel_y_Bolsa_de_Valores.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Mexican_Stock_Exchange" title="Mexican Stock Exchange">Mexican Stock Exchange</a> building
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Among the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" class="mw-redirect" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">OECD</a> countries, Mexico has the second-highest degree of economic disparity between the extremely poor and extremely rich, after Chile&nbsp;– although it has been falling over the last decade, being one of few countries in which this is the case.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[258]</a></sup> The bottom ten percent in the income hierarchy disposes of 1.36% of the country's resources, whereas the upper ten percent dispose of almost 36%. The OECD also notes that Mexico's budgeted expenses for poverty alleviation and social development is only about a third of the OECD average.<sup id="cite_ref-OECDREFORMA_259-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECDREFORMA-259">[259]</a></sup> This is also reflected by the fact that infant mortality in Mexico is three times higher than the average among OECD nations whereas its literacy levels are in the median range of OECD nations. Nevertheless, according to <a href="/wiki/Goldman_Sachs" title="Goldman Sachs">Goldman Sachs</a>, by 2050 Mexico will have the 5th largest economy in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[260]</a></sup> According to a 2008 UN report the average income in a typical urbanized area of Mexico was $26,654, while the average income in rural areas just miles away was only $8,403.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[261]</a></sup> Daily minimum wages are set annually being set at $102.68 <a href="/wiki/Mexican_peso" title="Mexican peso">Mexican pesos</a> (US$5.40) in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">[262]</a></sup> All of the indices of social development for the Mexican Indigenous population are considerably lower than the national average, which is motive of concern for the government.<sup id="cite_ref-inegi.org.mx_263-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-inegi.org.mx-263">[263]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The electronics industry of Mexico has grown enormously within the last decade. Mexico has the sixth largest electronics industry in the world after <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>, United States, <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korea</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>. Mexico is the second-largest exporter of electronics to the United States where it exported $71.4 billion worth of electronics in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-prnewswire.com_264-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-prnewswire.com-264">[264]</a></sup> The Mexican electronics industry is dominated by the manufacture and OEM design of televisions, displays, computers, mobile phones, circuit boards, semiconductors, electronic appliances, communications equipment and LCD modules. The Mexican electronics industry grew 20% between 2010 and 2011, up from its constant growth rate of 17% between 2003 and 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-prnewswire.com_264-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-prnewswire.com-264">[264]</a></sup> Currently electronics represent 30% of Mexico's exports.<sup id="cite_ref-prnewswire.com_264-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-prnewswire.com-264">[264]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Mexico produces the most automobiles of any North American nation.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">[265]</a></sup> The industry produces technologically complex components and engages in some research and development activities.<sup id="cite_ref-Gereffi_266-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gereffi-266">[266]</a></sup> The "Big Three" (<a href="/wiki/General_Motors" title="General Motors">General Motors</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ford" class="mw-redirect" title="Ford">Ford</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chrysler" title="Chrysler">Chrysler</a>) have been operating in Mexico since the 1930s, while <a href="/wiki/Volkswagen" title="Volkswagen">Volkswagen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nissan" title="Nissan">Nissan</a> built their plants in the 1960s.<sup id="cite_ref-Hufbauer_Auto_267-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hufbauer_Auto-267">[267]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Puebla,_Puebla" class="mw-redirect" title="Puebla, Puebla">Puebla</a> alone, 70 industrial part-makers cluster around Volkswagen.<sup id="cite_ref-Gereffi_266-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gereffi-266">[266]</a></sup> In the 2010s expansion of the sector was surging. In 2014 alone, more than $10 billion in investment was committed. In September 2016 Kia motors opened a $1 billion factory in <a href="/wiki/Nuevo_Le%C3%B3n" title="Nuevo León">Nuevo León</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[268]</a></sup> with Audi also opening an assembling plant in Puebla the same year.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[269]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/BMW" title="BMW">BMW</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz" title="Mercedes-Benz">Mercedes-Benz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nissan" title="Nissan">Nissan</a> currently have plants in constructuion.<sup id="cite_ref-KiaMexico_270-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KiaMexico-270">[270]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The domestic car industry is represented by <a href="/wiki/DINA_S.A." title="DINA S.A.">DINA S.A.</a>, which has built buses and trucks since 1962,<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[271]</a></sup> and the new <a href="/wiki/Mastretta" title="Mastretta">Mastretta</a> company that builds the high-performance <a href="/wiki/Mastretta_MXT" title="Mastretta MXT">Mastretta MXT</a> sports car.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">[272]</a></sup> In 2006, trade with the United States and Canada accounted for almost 50% of Mexico's exports and 45% of its imports.<sup id="cite_ref-cia.gov_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia.gov-11">[11]</a></sup> During the first three quarters of 2010, the United States had a $46.0 billion <a href="/wiki/Trade_deficit" class="mw-redirect" title="Trade deficit">trade deficit</a> with Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[273]</a></sup> In August 2010 Mexico surpassed France to become the 9th largest holder of US debt.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[274]</a></sup> The commercial and financial dependence on the US is a cause for concern.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[275]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The remittances from Mexican citizens working in the United States account for 0.2% of Mexico's GDP<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[276]</a></sup> which was equal to US$20 billion per year in 2004 and is the tenth largest source of foreign income after oil, industrial exports, manufactured goods, electronics, heavy industry, automobiles, construction, food, banking and financial services.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[277]</a></sup> According to Mexico's central bank, remittances in 2008 amounted to $25bn.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[278]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Communications">Communications</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_Mexico" class="mw-redirect" title="Telecommunications in Mexico">Telecommunications in Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Torre_de_tel%C3%A9fonos_de_Telmex.jpeg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Torre_de_tel%C3%A9fonos_de_Telmex.jpeg/200px-Torre_de_tel%C3%A9fonos_de_Telmex.jpeg" decoding="async" width="200" height="133" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Torre_de_tel%C3%A9fonos_de_Telmex.jpeg/300px-Torre_de_tel%C3%A9fonos_de_Telmex.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Torre_de_tel%C3%A9fonos_de_Telmex.jpeg/400px-Torre_de_tel%C3%A9fonos_de_Telmex.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="3456" data-file-height="2304"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Torre_de_tel%C3%A9fonos_de_Telmex.jpeg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Telmex" title="Telmex">Telmex</a> Tower, Mexico City.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The telecommunications industry is mostly dominated by <a href="/wiki/Telmex" title="Telmex">Telmex</a> (<i>Teléfonos de México</i>), privatized in 1990. By 2006, Telmex had expanded its operations to Colombia, Peru, Chile, Argentina, Brazil, Uruguay, and the United States. Other players in the domestic industry are <a href="/wiki/Axtel" title="Axtel">Axtel</a>, Maxcom, Alestra, Marcatel, AT&amp;T Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-budde_279-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-budde-279">[279]</a></sup> Because of Mexican <a href="/wiki/Orography" title="Orography">orography</a>, providing a landline telephone service at remote mountainous areas is expensive, and the penetration of line-phones per capita is low compared to other Latin American countries, at 40 percent; however, 82% of Mexicans over the age of 14 own a mobile phone. Mobile telephony has the advantage of reaching all areas at a lower cost, and the total number of mobile lines is almost two times that of landlines, with an estimation of 63 million lines.<sup id="cite_ref-ciacom_280-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ciacom-280">[280]</a></sup> The telecommunication industry is regulated by the government through <a href="/wiki/Cofetel" class="mw-redirect" title="Cofetel">Cofetel</a> (<i>Comisión Federal de Telecomunicaciones</i>). </p>
      <p>The Mexican satellite system is domestic and operates 120 earth stations. There is also extensive microwave radio relay network and considerable use of fiber-optic and coaxial cable.<sup id="cite_ref-ciacom_280-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ciacom-280">[280]</a></sup> Mexican satellites are operated by <i>Satélites Mexicanos</i> (<a href="/wiki/Satmex" title="Satmex">Satmex</a>), a private company, leader in Latin America and servicing both North and South America.<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[281]</a></sup> It offers broadcast, telephone and telecommunication services to 37 countries in the Americas, from Canada to <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a>. Through business partnerships Satmex provides high-speed connectivity to ISPs and Digital Broadcast Services.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[282]</a></sup> Satmex maintains its own satellite fleet with most of the fleet being designed and built in Mexico. </p>
      <p>Major players in the broadcasting industry are <a href="/wiki/Televisa" title="Televisa">Televisa</a>, the largest Mexican media company in the Spanish-speaking world,<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_283-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-283">[283]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/TV_Azteca" title="TV Azteca">TV Azteca</a> and <a href="/wiki/Imagen_Televisi%C3%B3n" title="Imagen Televisión">Imagen Televisión</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Electricity_sector_in_Mexico" title="Electricity sector in Mexico">Electricity sector in Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_Central_E%C3%B3lica_Sureste_I,_Fase_II.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_Central_E%C3%B3lica_Sureste_I%2C_Fase_II.jpg/220px-Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_Central_E%C3%B3lica_Sureste_I%2C_Fase_II.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_Central_E%C3%B3lica_Sureste_I%2C_Fase_II.jpg/330px-Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_Central_E%C3%B3lica_Sureste_I%2C_Fase_II.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_Central_E%C3%B3lica_Sureste_I%2C_Fase_II.jpg/440px-Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_Central_E%C3%B3lica_Sureste_I%2C_Fase_II.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1654" data-file-height="1104"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_Central_E%C3%B3lica_Sureste_I,_Fase_II.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The Central Eólica Sureste I, Fase II in Oaxaca. The Isthmus of Tehuantepec is the region of Mexico with the highest capacity for wind energy. (see <i><a href="/wiki/Tehuantepecer" title="Tehuantepecer">Tehuantepecer</a></i>, a strong wind that affects the region)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Energy production in Mexico is managed by the state-owned companies <a href="/wiki/Comisi%C3%B3n_Federal_de_Electricidad" title="Comisión Federal de Electricidad">Federal Commission of Electricity</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pemex" title="Pemex">Pemex</a>. </p>
      <p>Pemex, the public company in charge of exploration, extraction, transportation and marketing of crude oil and natural gas, as well as the refining and distribution of petroleum products and petrochemicals, is one of the largest companies in the world by revenue, making US$86 billion in sales a year.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">[284]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-fortune_285-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fortune-285">[285]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[286]</a></sup> Mexico is the sixth-largest oil producer in the world, with 3.7 million barrels per day.<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[287]</a></sup> In 1980 oil exports accounted for 61.6% of total exports; by 2000 it was only 7.3%.<sup id="cite_ref-Gereffi_266-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gereffi-266">[266]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The largest hydro plant in Mexico is the 2,400 MW <a href="/wiki/Chicoas%C3%A9n_Dam" title="Chicoasén Dam">Manuel Moreno Torres Dam</a> in Chicoasén, <a href="/wiki/Chiapas" title="Chiapas">Chiapas</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Grijalva_River" title="Grijalva River">Grijalva River</a>. This is the world's fourth most productive hydroelectric plant.<sup id="cite_ref-EIA_288-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EIA-288">[288]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Mexico is the country with the world's third largest solar potential.<sup id="cite_ref-S&amp;G_289-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-S&amp;G-289">[289]</a></sup> The country's gross solar potential is estimated at 5kWh/m2 daily, which corresponds to 50 times national electricity generation.<sup id="cite_ref-ER_290-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ER-290">[290]</a></sup> Currently, there is over 1 million square meters of <a href="/wiki/Solar_thermal" class="mw-redirect" title="Solar thermal">solar thermal</a> panels<sup id="cite_ref-SENER_2009b_291-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SENER_2009b-291">[291]</a></sup> installed in Mexico, while in 2005, there were 115,000 square meters of <a href="/wiki/Solar_PV" class="mw-redirect" title="Solar PV">solar PV</a> (photo-voltaic). It is expected that in 2012 there will be 1,8 million square meters of installed solar thermal panels.<sup id="cite_ref-SENER_2009b_291-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SENER_2009b-291">[291]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The project named <a href="/wiki/SEGH-CFE_1" title="SEGH-CFE 1">SEGH-CFE 1</a>, located in Puerto Libertad, Sonora, Northwest of Mexico, will have capacity of 46.8 MW from an array of 187,200 solar panels when complete in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-Sonora_Energy_Group_Hermosillo_292-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sonora_Energy_Group_Hermosillo-292">[292]</a></sup> All of the electricity will be sold directly to the CFE and absorbed into the utility's transmission system for distribution throughout their existing network. At an installed capacity of 46.8 MWp, when complete in 2013, the project will be the first utility scale project of its kind in Mexico and the largest solar project of any kind in Latin America. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_science_and_technology_in_Mexico" title="History of science and technology in Mexico">History of science and technology in Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Museo_planetario_Alfa_Monterrey.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Museo_planetario_Alfa_Monterrey.jpg/200px-Museo_planetario_Alfa_Monterrey.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Museo_planetario_Alfa_Monterrey.jpg/300px-Museo_planetario_Alfa_Monterrey.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Museo_planetario_Alfa_Monterrey.jpg/400px-Museo_planetario_Alfa_Monterrey.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="768"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Museo_planetario_Alfa_Monterrey.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Alfa_Planetarium" title="Alfa Planetarium">Alfa Planetarium</a> this institution was created by <a href="/wiki/ALFA_(Mexico)" title="ALFA (Mexico)">ALFA</a> (Mexico) in 1978 to promote science and technology in Latin America
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/National_Autonomous_University_of_Mexico" title="National Autonomous University of Mexico">National Autonomous University of Mexico</a> was officially established in 1910,<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">[293]</a></sup> and the university became one of the most important institutes of higher learning in Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[294]</a></sup> UNAM provides world class education in science, medicine, and engineering.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[295]</a></sup> Many scientific institutes and new institutes of higher learning, such as <a href="/wiki/National_Polytechnic_Institute" class="mw-redirect" title="National Polytechnic Institute">National Polytechnic Institute</a> (founded in 1936),<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">[296]</a></sup> were established during the first half of the 20th century. Most of the new research institutes were created within UNAM. Twelve institutes were integrated into UNAM from 1929 to 1973.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[297]</a></sup> In 1959, the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Academy_of_Sciences" title="Mexican Academy of Sciences">Mexican Academy of Sciences</a> was created to coordinate scientific efforts between academics. </p>
      <p>In 1995, the Mexican chemist <a href="/wiki/Mario_J._Molina" class="mw-redirect" title="Mario J. Molina">Mario J. Molina</a> shared the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Chemistry" title="Nobel Prize in Chemistry">Nobel Prize in Chemistry</a> with <a href="/wiki/Paul_J._Crutzen" title="Paul J. Crutzen">Paul J. Crutzen</a> and <a href="/wiki/F._Sherwood_Rowland" title="F. Sherwood Rowland">F. Sherwood Rowland</a> for their work in atmospheric chemistry, particularly concerning the formation and decomposition of ozone.<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">[298]</a></sup> Molina, an alumnus of UNAM, became the first Mexican citizen to win the Nobel Prize in science.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">[299]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In recent years, the largest scientific project being developed in Mexico was the construction of the <a href="/wiki/Large_Millimeter_Telescope" title="Large Millimeter Telescope">Large Millimeter Telescope</a> (Gran Telescopio Milimétrico, GMT), the world's largest and most sensitive single-aperture telescope in its frequency range.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">[300]</a></sup> It was designed to observe regions of space obscured by stellar dust. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Mexico" title="Tourism in Mexico">Tourism in Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Cancun_aerial_photo_by_safa.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Cancun_aerial_photo_by_safa.jpg/220px-Cancun_aerial_photo_by_safa.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Cancun_aerial_photo_by_safa.jpg/330px-Cancun_aerial_photo_by_safa.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Cancun_aerial_photo_by_safa.jpg/440px-Cancun_aerial_photo_by_safa.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1248" data-file-height="832"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Cancun_aerial_photo_by_safa.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Cancun" class="mw-redirect" title="Cancun">Cancun</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Riviera_Maya" title="Riviera Maya">Riviera Maya</a> is the most visited region in Latin America
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>As of 2017, Mexico was the 6th most visited country in the world and had the 15th highest income from tourism in the world which is also the highest in Latin America.<sup id="cite_ref-WTO_Tourism_Highlights_2018_Edition_301-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTO_Tourism_Highlights_2018_Edition-301">[301]</a></sup> The vast majority of tourists come to Mexico from the United States and Canada followed by Europe and Asia. A smaller number also come from other Latin American countries.<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">[302]</a></sup> In the 2017 <a href="/wiki/Travel_and_Tourism_Competitiveness_Report" title="Travel and Tourism Competitiveness Report">Travel and Tourism Competitiveness Report</a>, Mexico was ranked 22nd in the world, which was 3rd in the Americas.<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">[303]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The coastlines of Mexico harbor many stretches of beaches that are frequented by sunbathers and other visitors. <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Mexico#Article_27" title="Constitution of Mexico">According to national law</a>, the entirety of the coastlines are under federal ownership, that is, all beaches in the country are <a href="/wiki/Public_property" title="Public property">public</a>. On the Yucatán peninsula, one of the most popular beach destinations is the resort town of <a href="/wiki/Canc%C3%BAn" title="Cancún">Cancún</a>, especially among <a href="/wiki/University" title="University">university</a> <a href="/wiki/Student" title="Student">students</a> during <a href="/wiki/Spring_break" title="Spring break">spring break</a>. Just offshore is the beach island of <a href="/wiki/Isla_Mujeres" title="Isla Mujeres">Isla Mujeres</a>, and to the east is the <a href="/wiki/Isla_Holbox" title="Isla Holbox">Isla Holbox</a>. To the south of Cancun is the coastal strip called <a href="/wiki/Riviera_Maya" title="Riviera Maya">Riviera Maya</a> which includes the beach town of <a href="/wiki/Playa_del_Carmen" title="Playa del Carmen">Playa del Carmen</a> and the ecological parks of <a href="/wiki/Xcaret" title="Xcaret">Xcaret</a> and Xel-Há. A day trip to the south of Cancún is the historic port of <a href="/wiki/Tulum" title="Tulum">Tulum</a>. In addition to its beaches, the town of Tulum is notable for its cliff-side <a href="/wiki/Maya_civilization" title="Maya civilization">Mayan</a> ruins. </p>
      <p>On the <a href="/wiki/Pacific" class="mw-redirect" title="Pacific">Pacific</a> coast is the notable tourist destination of <a href="/wiki/Acapulco" title="Acapulco">Acapulco</a>. Once the destination for the rich and famous, the beaches have become crowded and the shores are now home to many multi-story hotels and vendors. Acapulco is home to renowned cliff divers: trained divers who leap from the side of a vertical cliff into the surf below. </p>
      <p>At the southern tip of the <a href="/wiki/Baja_California_peninsula" class="mw-redirect" title="Baja California peninsula">Baja California peninsula</a> is the resort town of <a href="/wiki/Cabo_San_Lucas" title="Cabo San Lucas">Cabo San Lucas</a>, a town noted for its beaches and <a href="/wiki/Marlin" title="Marlin">marlin</a> <a href="/wiki/Fishing" title="Fishing">fishing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">[304]</a></sup> Further north along the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Cort%C3%A9s" class="mw-redirect" title="Sea of Cortés">Sea of Cortés</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%ADa_Concepci%C3%B3n,_Baja_California_Sur" title="Bahía Concepción, Baja California Sur">Bahía de La Concepción</a>, another beach town known for its sports fishing. Closer to the United States border is the weekend draw of <a href="/wiki/San_Felipe,_Baja_California" title="San Felipe, Baja California">San Felipe, Baja California</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transportation_in_Mexico" title="Transportation in Mexico">Transportation in Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Puente_Baluarte,_Mexico1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Puente_Baluarte%2C_Mexico1.jpg/220px-Puente_Baluarte%2C_Mexico1.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Puente_Baluarte%2C_Mexico1.jpg/330px-Puente_Baluarte%2C_Mexico1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Puente_Baluarte%2C_Mexico1.jpg/440px-Puente_Baluarte%2C_Mexico1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="3456"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Puente_Baluarte,_Mexico1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Baluarte_Bridge" title="Baluarte Bridge">Baluarte Bridge</a> is the highest cable-stayed bridge in the world, the fifth-highest bridge overall and the highest bridge in the Americas.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The roadway network in Mexico is extensive and all areas in the country are covered by it.<sup id="cite_ref-nations_305-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nations-305">[305]</a></sup> The roadway network in Mexico has an extent of 366,095&nbsp;km (227,481&nbsp;mi),<sup id="cite_ref-sctroad_306-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sctroad-306">[306]</a></sup> of which 116,802&nbsp;km (72,577&nbsp;mi) are paved.<sup id="cite_ref-sctroad-2_307-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sctroad-2-307">[307]</a></sup> Of these, 10,474&nbsp;km (6,508&nbsp;mi) are multi-lane <a href="/wiki/Controlled-access_highway" title="Controlled-access highway">expressways</a>: 9,544&nbsp;km (5,930&nbsp;mi) are four-lane highways and the rest have 6 or more lanes.<sup id="cite_ref-sctroad-2_307-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sctroad-2-307">[307]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Starting in the late nineteenth century, Mexico was one of the first Latin American countries to promote railway development,<sup id="cite_ref-brit-mex_182-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brit-mex-182">[182]</a></sup> and the network covers 30,952&nbsp;km (19,233&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-encnations_308-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-encnations-308">[308]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Secretariat_of_Communications_and_Transportation_(Mexico)" title="Secretariat of Communications and Transportation (Mexico)">Secretary of Communications and Transport</a> of Mexico proposed a high-speed rail link that will transport its passengers from <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a> to <a href="/wiki/Guadalajara" title="Guadalajara">Guadalajara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jalisco" title="Jalisco">Jalisco</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-azcentral.com_309-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-azcentral.com-309">[309]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">[310]</a></sup> The train, which will travel at 300 kilometres per hour (190 miles per hour),<sup id="cite_ref-systra.com_311-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-systra.com-311">[311]</a></sup> will allow passengers to travel from Mexico City to Guadalajara in just 2&nbsp;hours.<sup id="cite_ref-systra.com_311-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-systra.com-311">[311]</a></sup> The whole project was projected to cost 240&nbsp;billion <a href="/wiki/MXN" class="mw-redirect" title="MXN">pesos</a>, or about 25&nbsp;billion US$<sup id="cite_ref-azcentral.com_309-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-azcentral.com-309">[309]</a></sup> and is being paid for jointly by the Mexican government and the local private sector including the wealthiest man in the world, Mexico's billionaire business tycoon <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Slim" title="Carlos Slim">Carlos Slim</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">[312]</a></sup> The government of the state of <a href="/wiki/Yucat%C3%A1n" title="Yucatán">Yucatán</a> is also funding the construction of a high speed line connecting the cities of <a href="/wiki/Cozumel" title="Cozumel">Cozumel</a> to <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A9rida,_Yucat%C3%A1n" title="Mérida, Yucatán">Mérida</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chichen_Itza" title="Chichen Itza">Chichen Itza</a> and Cancún.<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">[313]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Mexico has 233 airports with paved runways; of these, 35 carry 97% of the passenger traffic.<sup id="cite_ref-encnations_308-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-encnations-308">[308]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City_International_Airport" title="Mexico City International Airport">Mexico City International Airport</a> remains the busiest in Latin America and the 36th busiest in the world<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">[314]</a></sup> transporting 45 million passengers a year.<sup id="cite_ref-aicmstats_315-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aicmstats-315">[315]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Water_supply_and_sanitation">Water supply and sanitation</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Mexico" title="Water supply and sanitation in Mexico">Water supply and sanitation in Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Presa_de_El_Caj%C3%B3n.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Presa_de_El_Caj%C3%B3n.jpg/200px-Presa_de_El_Caj%C3%B3n.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Presa_de_El_Caj%C3%B3n.jpg/300px-Presa_de_El_Caj%C3%B3n.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Presa_de_El_Caj%C3%B3n.jpg/400px-Presa_de_El_Caj%C3%B3n.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1536"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Presa_de_El_Caj%C3%B3n.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/El_Caj%C3%B3n_Dam_(Mexico)" title="El Cajón Dam (Mexico)">El Cajon Dam</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Among the achievements is a significant increase in access to piped water supply in urban areas (96.4%) as well as in rural areas (69.4%) as of 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">[316]</a></sup> Other achievements include the existence of a functioning national system to finance water and sanitation infrastructure with a National Water Commission as its apex institution. </p>
      <p>The challenges include water scarcity in the northern and central parts of the country; inadequate water service quality (drinking water quality; 11% of Mexicans receiving water only intermittently as of 2014);<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">[317]</a></sup> poor technical and commercial efficiency of most utilities (with an average level of <a href="/wiki/Non-revenue_water" title="Non-revenue water">non-revenue water</a> of 43.2% in 2010);<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">[318]</a></sup> increasing the national percentage of fully sanitized water which at 57%,<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">[319]</a></sup> is considered to not be enough, as the country's theoretically available percentage of water per capita is 60% lower than it was 60 years ago;<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">[320]</a></sup> and the improvement of adequate access in rural areas. In addition to on-going investments to expand access, the government has embarked on a large investment program to improve wastewater treatment. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Mexico" title="Demographics of Mexico">Demographics of Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <table class="toccolours" style="width:15em;border-top-width:0;border-spacing: 0;float:right;clear:right;margin:0.5em 0 1em 0.5em;">
       <caption style="border-top:1px #aaa solid;border-left:1px #aaa solid;border-right:1px #aaa solid;background-color:lavender;padding:0.25em;font-weight:bold">
        Historical population
       </caption>
       <tbody>
        <tr style="font-size:95%">

        </tr>

        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1900 </th>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">13,607,272</td>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+1.39%</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1910 </th>
