         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">−0.51%</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">1930 </th>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">16,552,722</td>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">+1.61%</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1940 </th>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">19,653,552</td>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+1.73%</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1950 </th>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">25,791,017</td>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+2.75%</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1960 </th>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">34,923,129</td>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+3.08%</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1970 </th>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">48,225,238</td>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+3.28%</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">1980 </th>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">66,846,833</td>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">+3.32%</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1990 </th>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">81,249,645</td>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+1.97%</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">2000 </th>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">97,483,412</td>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+1.84%</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">2010 </th>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">112,336,538</td>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+1.43%</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">2020 </th>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">126,014,024</td>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+1.16%</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td colspan="3" style="border-top:1px solid black;font-size:85%;text-align:left">Source: <a href="/wiki/INEGI" class="mw-redirect" title="INEGI">INEGI</a></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>Throughout the 19th century, the population of Mexico had barely doubled. This trend continued during the first two decades of the 20th century, and even in the 1921 census there was a loss of about 1 million inhabitants. The phenomenon can be explained because during the decade from 1910 to 1921 the Mexican Revolution took place. The growth rate increased dramatically between the 1930s and the 1980s, when the country registered growth rates of over 3% (1950–1980). The Mexican population doubled in twenty years, and at that rate it was expected that by the year 2000 there would be 120 million Mexicans. Life expectancy went from 36 years (in 1895) to 72 years (in the year 2000). According to estimations made by Mexico's <a href="/wiki/Instituto_Nacional_de_Estad%C3%ADstica_y_Geograf%C3%ADa" class="mw-redirect" title="Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Geografía">National Geography and Statistics Institute</a>, as of 2017 Mexico has 123.5 million inhabitants<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">[321]</a></sup> making it the most populous Spanish-speaking country in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-Spanishhistory_322-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Spanishhistory-322">[322]</a></sup> Between 2005 and 2010, the Mexican population grew at an average of 1.70% per year, up from 1.16% per year between 2000 and 2005. </p>
      <p>Even though Mexico is a very ethnically diverse country, research about ethnicity has largely been a forgotten field, in consequence of the post-revolutionary efforts of Mexico's government to unify all non-indigenous Mexicans under a single ethnic identity (that of the "Mestizo"). As a result, since 1930 the only explicit ethnic classification that has been included in Mexican censuses has been that of "Indigenous peoples".<sup id="cite_ref-EL_MESTIZAJE_Y_LAS_CULTURAS_REGIONALES_323-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EL_MESTIZAJE_Y_LAS_CULTURAS_REGIONALES-323">[323]</a></sup> Even then, across the years the government has used different criteria to count Indigenous peoples, with each of them returning considerably different numbers ranging from 5.4% to 23% of the country's population. It is not until very recently that the Mexican government begun conducting surveys that considered other ethnic groups that live in the country such as Afro-Mexicans who amount to 2% of Mexico's population<sup id="cite_ref-beta.inegi.org.mx_324-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-beta.inegi.org.mx-324">[324]</a></sup> or White Mexicans<sup id="cite_ref-ElUniversal_325-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ElUniversal-325">[325]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Forbes_326-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Forbes-326">[326]</a></sup> which amount to 47% of Mexico's population (with the criteria being based on appearance rather than on self-declared of ancestry).<sup id="cite_ref-Marzo_DiaIntElimDiscRacial_INACCSS_2017_327-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Marzo_DiaIntElimDiscRacial_INACCSS_2017-327">[327]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-conapred.org.mx_328-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-conapred.org.mx-328">[328]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-DISC-RACIAL_2011_329-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DISC-RACIAL_2011-329">[329]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-MMSI1_330-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MMSI1-330">[330]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ENADIS2017_331-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ENADIS2017-331">[331]</a></sup> Less numerous groups in Mexico such as Asians and Middle Easterners are also accounted for, with numbers of around 1% each. </p>
      <p>As of 2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mexico&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, it is estimated that 1.2 million foreigners have settled in the country,<sup id="cite_ref-UN2017_332-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN2017-332">[332]</a></sup> up from nearly 1 million in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333">[333]</a></sup> The vast majority of migrants come from the United States (900,000), making Mexico the top destination for <a href="/wiki/American_immigration_to_Mexico" title="American immigration to Mexico">U.S. citizens abroad</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">[334]</a></sup> The second largest group comes from neighboring <a href="/wiki/Guatemala" title="Guatemala">Guatemala</a> (54,500), followed by <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a> (27,600).<sup id="cite_ref-UN2017_332-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN2017-332">[332]</a></sup> Other major sources of migration are fellow Latin American countries, which include <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a> (20,600), <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a> (19,200) and <a href="/wiki/Cuba" title="Cuba">Cuba</a> (18,100).<sup id="cite_ref-UN2017_332-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN2017-332">[332]</a></sup> Historically, the <a href="/wiki/Lebanese_Mexicans" title="Lebanese Mexicans">Lebanese diaspora</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Mennonites_in_Mexico" title="Mennonites in Mexico">German-born Mennonite migration</a> have left a notorious impact in the country's culture, particularly in its cuisine and traditional music.<sup id="cite_ref-Garcia_2005_335-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Garcia_2005-335">[335]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336">[336]</a></sup> At the turn of the 21st century, several trends have increased the number of foreigners residing in the country such as the <a href="/wiki/2008%E2%80%932014_Spanish_financial_crisis" title="2008–2014 Spanish financial crisis">2008–2014 Spanish financial crisis</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">[337]</a></sup> increasing gang-related violence in the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Triangle_of_Central_America" title="Northern Triangle of Central America">Northern Triangle of Central America</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338">[338]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Crisis_in_Venezuela" title="Crisis in Venezuela">ongoing political and economic crisis in Venezuela</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">[339]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">[340]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_Mexico" title="Automotive industry in Mexico">automotive industry boom</a> led by Japanese and South Korean investment.<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">[341]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">[342]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnicity_and_race">Ethnicity and race</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Casta_painting_all.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Casta_painting_all.jpg/200px-Casta_painting_all.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="282" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Casta_painting_all.jpg/300px-Casta_painting_all.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Casta_painting_all.jpg/400px-Casta_painting_all.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1419" data-file-height="2000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Casta_painting_all.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><i lang="es" title="Spanish-language text">Las castas</i>. Casta painting showing 16 racial groupings. Anonymous, 18th century, oil on canvas, 148×104 cm, <span lang="es" style="font-style: normal;" title="Spanish-language text">Museo Nacional del Virreinato</span>, <span lang="nah" style="font-style: normal;" title="Nahuatl languages collective text"><a href="/wiki/Tepotzotl%C3%A1n" title="Tepotzotlán">Tepotzotlán</a></span>, Mexico.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Regardless of ethnicity, the majority of Mexicans are united under the same national identity.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated115_343-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated115-343">[343]</a></sup> This is the product of an ideology strongly promoted by Mexican academics such as <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Gamio" title="Manuel Gamio">Manuel Gamio</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Vasconcelos" title="José Vasconcelos">José Vasconcelos</a> known as <a href="/wiki/Mestizaje" class="mw-redirect" title="Mestizaje">mestizaje</a>, whose goal was that of Mexico becoming a <a href="/wiki/La_Raza_C%C3%B3smica" class="mw-redirect" title="La Raza Cósmica">racially</a> and <a href="/wiki/Indigenismo" title="Indigenismo">culturally</a> homogeneous country.<sup id="cite_ref-Knight,_Alan_1990._pp._78_344-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Knight,_Alan_1990._pp._78-344">[344]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated115_343-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated115-343">[343]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-census_345-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-census-345">[345]</a></sup> The ideology's influence was reflected in Mexico's national censuses of 1921 and 1930: in the former, which was Mexico's first-ever national census (but second-ever if the census made in colonial times is taken into account)<sup id="cite_ref-aleph_81-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aleph-81">[81]</a></sup> that considered race, approximately 60% of Mexico's population identified as Mestizos,<sup id="cite_ref-somosprimos.com_346-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-somosprimos.com-346">[346]</a></sup> and in the latter, Mexico's government declared that all Mexicans were now Mestizos, for which racial classifications would be dropped in favor of language-based ones in future censuses.<sup id="cite_ref-EL_MESTIZAJE_Y_LAS_CULTURAS_REGIONALES_323-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EL_MESTIZAJE_Y_LAS_CULTURAS_REGIONALES-323">[323]</a></sup> During most of the 20th century these censuses' results were taken as fact, with extraofficial international publications often using them as a reference to estimate Mexico's racial composition,<sup id="cite_ref-Factbook_347-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Factbook-347">[347]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-brit-mex_182-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brit-mex-182">[182]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348">[348]</a></sup> but in recent time historians and academics have claimed that said results are not accurate, as on its efforts to homogenize Mexico the government inflated the Mestizo label's percentage by classifying a good number of people as such regardless of whether they were of actual mixed ancestry or not,<sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">[349]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Mexicosinmestizaje_350-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mexicosinmestizaje-350">[350]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-redalyc_351-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-redalyc-351">[351]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Bartolomé_1996:2_352-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bartolomé_1996:2-352">[352]</a></sup> pointing out that an alteration so drastic of population trends compared to earlier censuses such as New Spain's 1793 census (on which Europeans were estimated to be 18% to 22% of the population, Mestizos 21% to 25% and Indigenous peoples 51% to 61%)<sup id="cite_ref-aleph_81-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aleph-81">[81]</a></sup> is not possible and that the frequency of marriages between people of different ancestries in colonial and early independent Mexico was low.<sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353">[353]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-MexicoRacista1_354-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MexicoRacista1-354">[354]</a></sup> it is also observed that when asked directly about their ethno-racial identification, many Mexicans nowadays do not identify as Mestizos<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">[355]</a></sup> and that "static" ethnoracial labels such as "White" or "Indian" are far more prominent in contemporary Mexican society than the "Mestizo" one is, whose use is mostly limited to intellectual circles, result of the label's constantly-changing and subjective definition.<sup id="cite_ref-mestizajeenmexico_356-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mestizajeenmexico-356">[356]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The total percentage of Mexico's <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_Mexico" title="Indigenous peoples of Mexico">indigenous peoples</a> tends to vary depending on the criteria used by the government on its censuses: it is 5.4% if the ability to speak an indigenous language is used as the criteria to define a person as indigenous,<sup id="cite_ref-inegiindigenous_357-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-inegiindigenous-357">[357]</a></sup> if racial self-identification is used it is 14.9%<sup id="cite_ref-CDI1_358-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CDI1-358">[358]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">[a]</a></sup> and if people who consider themselves part indigenous are also included it amounts to 23%.<sup id="cite_ref-beta.inegi.org.mx_324-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-beta.inegi.org.mx-324">[324]</a></sup> Nonetheless, all the censuses conclude that the majority of Mexico's indigenous population is concentrated in rural areas of the southern and south-eastern Mexican states.<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">[361]</a></sup> with the highest percentages being found in Yucatán at 59% of the population, Oaxaca with 48%, Quintana Roo with 39%, Chiapas with 28% and Campeche with 27%.<sup id="cite_ref-inegi.org.mx_263-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-inegi.org.mx-263">[263]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CDI_363-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CDI-363">[362]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Similarly to Mestizo and indigenous peoples, estimates of the percentage of <a href="/wiki/Mexicans_of_European_descent" class="mw-redirect" title="Mexicans of European descent">European-descended Mexicans</a> vary considerably depending of the criteria used: recent nationwide field surveys that account for different phenotypical traits (hair color, skin color etc.) report a percentage between 18%<sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364">[363]</a></sup>-23%<sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">[364]</a></sup> if the criteria is the presence of <a href="/wiki/Blond" title="Blond">blond hair</a>, and of 47% if the criteria is skin color, with the later surveys having been conducted by Mexico's government itself.<sup id="cite_ref-Marzo_DiaIntElimDiscRacial_INACCSS_2017_327-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Marzo_DiaIntElimDiscRacial_INACCSS_2017-327">[327]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-conapred.org.mx_328-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-conapred.org.mx-328">[328]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-DISC-RACIAL_2011_329-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DISC-RACIAL_2011-329">[329]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ENADIS2017_331-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ENADIS2017-331">[331]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-MMSI2_366-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MMSI2-366">[365]</a></sup> While during the colonial era, most of the European migration into Mexico was <a href="/wiki/Spaniards_in_Mexico" title="Spaniards in Mexico">Spanish</a>, in the 19th and 20th centuries a substantial number of non-Spanish Europeans immigrated to the country,<sup id="cite_ref-fnavarrete_367-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fnavarrete-367">[366]</a></sup> with Europeans often being the most numerous ethnic group in colonial Mexican cities.<sup id="cite_ref-EnsayospoblaciónMéxico_368-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EnsayospoblaciónMéxico-368">[367]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369">[368]</a></sup> Nowadays Mexico's northern and western regions have the highest percentages of European populations, with the majority of the people not having native admixture or being of predominantly European ancestry.<sup id="cite_ref-UnitedStatesandMexico_370-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UnitedStatesandMexico-370">[369]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Capilla_de_San_Francisco_Puebla.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Capilla_de_San_Francisco_Puebla.jpg/220px-Capilla_de_San_Francisco_Puebla.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="293" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Capilla_de_San_Francisco_Puebla.jpg/330px-Capilla_de_San_Francisco_Puebla.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Capilla_de_San_Francisco_Puebla.jpg/440px-Capilla_de_San_Francisco_Puebla.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3227" data-file-height="4303"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Capilla_de_San_Francisco_Puebla.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Puebla_City" class="mw-redirect" title="Puebla City">Puebla de Zaragoza</a> is the most populated city of <a href="/wiki/Puebla" title="Puebla">Puebla</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Afro-Mexican population (1,381,853 individuals as of 2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mexico&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>)<sup id="cite_ref-Encuesta_Intercensal_371-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encuesta_Intercensal-371">[370]</a></sup> is an ethnic group made up of descendants of Colonial-era slaves and recent immigrants of sub-Saharan African descent. Mexico had an active slave trade during the colonial period, and some 200,000 Africans were taken there, primarily in the 17th century. The creation of a national Mexican identity, especially after the Mexican Revolution, emphasized Mexico's indigenous and European past; it passively eliminated the African ancestors and contributions. Most of the African-descended population was absorbed into the surrounding Mestizo (mixed European/indigenous) and indigenous populations through unions among the groups. Evidence of this long history of intermarriage with Mestizo and indigenous Mexicans is also expressed in the fact that in the 2015 inter-census, 64.9% (896,829) of Afro-Mexicans also identified as indigenous. It was also reported that 9.3% of Afro-Mexicans speak an indigenous language.<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">[371]</a></sup> The states with the highest self-report of Afro-Mexicans were Guerrero (6.5% of the population), Oaxaca (4.95%) and Veracruz (3.28%).<sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">[372]</a></sup> Afro-Mexican culture is strongest in the communities of the <a href="/wiki/Costa_Chica_of_Oaxaca" class="mw-redirect" title="Costa Chica of Oaxaca">Costa Chica of Oaxaca</a> and <a href="/wiki/Costa_Chica_of_Guerrero" title="Costa Chica of Guerrero">Costa Chica of Guerrero</a>. </p>
      <p>During the early 20th century, a substantial number of <a href="/wiki/Arab_Mexicans" title="Arab Mexicans">Arabs</a> (mostly <a href="/wiki/Arab_Christians" title="Arab Christians">Christians</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">[373]</a></sup> began arriving from the crumbling <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>. The largest group were the Lebanese and an estimated 400,000 Mexicans have some <a href="/wiki/Lebanese_Mexicans" title="Lebanese Mexicans">Lebanese ancestry</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">[374]</a></sup> Smaller ethnic groups in Mexico include <a href="/wiki/Asian_Mexicans" title="Asian Mexicans">South and East Asians</a>, present since the colonial era. During the colonial era Asians were termed <i>Chino</i> (regardless of ethnicity), and arrived as merchants, artisans and slaves.<sup id="cite_ref-Seijas_376-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Seijas-376">[375]</a></sup> A study by Juan Esteban Rodríguez, a graduate student at the National Laboratory of Genomics for Biodiversity, indicated that up to one third of people sampled from <a href="/wiki/Guerrero" title="Guerrero">Guerrero</a> state had significantly more Asian ancestry than most Mexicans, primarily <a href="/wiki/Filipino_immigration_to_Mexico" title="Filipino immigration to Mexico">Filipino</a> or <a href="/wiki/Native_Indonesians" title="Native Indonesians">Indonesian</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">[376]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378">[377]</a></sup> Modern Asian immigration began in the late 19th century, and at one point in the early 20th century the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_immigration_to_Mexico" title="Chinese immigration to Mexico">Chinese</a> were the second largest immigrant group.<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">[378]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Emigration">Emigration</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Emigration_from_Mexico" title="Emigration from Mexico">Emigration from Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <p>In the early 1960s, around 600,000 Mexicans lived abroad, which increased sevenfold by the 1990s to 4.4 million.<sup id="cite_ref-Migration_Yearbook_380-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Migration_Yearbook-380">[379]</a></sup> At the turn of the 21st century, this figure more than doubled to 9.5 million.<sup id="cite_ref-Migration_Yearbook_380-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Migration_Yearbook-380">[379]</a></sup> As of 2017, it is estimated that 12.9 million Mexicans live abroad, primarily in the United States, which concentrates nearly 98% of the expatriate population.<sup id="cite_ref-Migration_Yearbook_380-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Migration_Yearbook-380">[379]</a></sup> The majority of Mexicans have settled in states such as <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a>, <a href="/wiki/Texas" title="Texas">Texas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Illinois" title="Illinois">Illinois</a>, particularly around the metropolitan areas of <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_metropolitan_area" class="mw-redirect" title="Los Angeles metropolitan area">Los Angeles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chicago_metropolitan_area" title="Chicago metropolitan area">Chicago</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greater_Houston" title="Greater Houston">Houston</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dallas%E2%80%93Fort_Worth_metroplex" title="Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex">Dallas-Fort Worth</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">[380]</a></sup> As a result of these major migration flows in recent decades, around 36 million U.S. residents, or 11.2% of the country's population, identified as being of full or partial Mexican ancestry.<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">[381]</a></sup> The remaining 2% of expatriates have settled in <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canada</a> (86,000), primarily in the provinces of <a href="/wiki/Ontario" title="Ontario">Ontario</a> and <a href="/wiki/Quebec" title="Quebec">Quebec</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">[382]</a></sup> followed by <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a> (49,000) and <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a> (18,000), both European destinations represent almost two-thirds of the Mexican population living in the continent.<sup id="cite_ref-Migration_Yearbook_380-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Migration_Yearbook-380">[379]</a></sup> As for Latin America, it is estimated that 69,000 Mexicans live in the region, <a href="/wiki/Guatemala" title="Guatemala">Guatemala</a> (18,000) being the top destination for expatriates, followed by <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a> (10,000) and <a href="/wiki/Panama" title="Panama">Panama</a> (5,000).<sup id="cite_ref-Migration_Yearbook_380-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Migration_Yearbook-380">[379]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Mexico" title="Languages of Mexico">Languages of Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Paz0.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Paz0.jpg/200px-Paz0.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="292" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/3e/Paz0.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="249" data-file-height="364"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Paz0.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Octavio_Paz" title="Octavio Paz">Octavio Paz</a> was awarded the 1981 <a href="/wiki/Miguel_de_Cervantes_Prize" title="Miguel de Cervantes Prize">Miguel de Cervantes Prize</a>, the 1982 <a href="/wiki/Neustadt_International_Prize_for_Literature" title="Neustadt International Prize for Literature">Neustadt International Prize for Literature</a>, and the 1990 <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel Prize in Literature</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a> is the <i><a href="/wiki/De_facto" title="De facto">de facto</a></i> national language spoken by the vast majority of the population, making Mexico the world's most populous <a href="/wiki/Hispanophone" title="Hispanophone">Hispanophone</a> country.<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">[383]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Spanishhistory_322-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Spanishhistory-322">[322]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Spanish" title="Mexican Spanish">Mexican Spanish</a> refers to the <a href="/wiki/Variety_(linguistics)" title="Variety (linguistics)">varieties</a> of the language spoken in the country, which differ from one region to another in sound, structure, and vocabulary.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWerner2001443,_444,_445_385-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWerner2001443,_444,_445-385">[384]</a></sup> In general, Mexican Spanish does not make any phonetic <a href="/wiki/Seseo" class="mw-redirect" title="Seseo">distinction among the letters <i>s</i> and <i>z</i></a>, as well as <i>c</i> when preceding the vowels <i>e</i> and <i>i</i>, as opposed to <a href="/wiki/Peninsular_Spanish" title="Peninsular Spanish">Peninsular Spanish</a>. The letters <i>b</i> and <i>v</i> have the same pronunciation as well.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWerner2001443,_444,_445_385-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWerner2001443,_444,_445-385">[384]</a></sup> Furthermore, the usage of <i><a href="/wiki/Voseo" title="Voseo">vos</a></i>, the <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_person" title="Grammatical person">second person</a> <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_number" title="Grammatical number">singular</a> <a href="/wiki/Pronoun" title="Pronoun">pronoun</a>, found in several Latin American varieties, is replaced by <i><a href="/wiki/T-V_distinction#Spanish" class="mw-redirect" title="T-V distinction">tú</a></i>; whereas <i><a href="/wiki/Vosotros" class="mw-redirect" title="Vosotros">vosotros</a></i>, the second person plural pronoun, fell out of use and was effectively replaced by <i>ustedes</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWerner2001443,_444,_445_385-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWerner2001443,_444,_445-385">[384]</a></sup> In written form, the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Royal_Academy" class="mw-redirect" title="Spanish Royal Academy">Spanish Royal Academy</a> serves as the primary guideline for spelling, except for words of Amerindian origin that retain their original phonology such as <i><a href="/wiki/Northern_mockingbird" title="Northern mockingbird">cenzontle</a></i> instead of <i>sinzontle</i> and <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Mexico" title="Name of Mexico"><i>México</i> not <i>Méjico</i></a>. Words of foreign origin also maintain their original spelling such as whisky and film, as opposed to <i>güisqui</i> and <i>filme</i> as the Royal Academy suggests.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWerner2001443,_444,_445_385-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWerner2001443,_444,_445-385">[384]</a></sup> The letter <i>x</i> is distinctly used in Mexican Spanish, which may be pronounced as <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[ks]</span> (as in <i>oxígeno</i> or <i>taxi</i>), as <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[ʃ]</span> particularly in Amerindian words (e.g. <i>mixiote</i>, <i>Xola</i> and <i>uxmal</i>) and as the <a href="/wiki/Voiceless_velar_fricative" title="Voiceless velar fricative">voiceless velar fricative</a> <span class="IPA nowrap" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[<a href="/wiki/Voiceless_velar_fricative" title="Voiceless velar fricative">x</a>]</span> (such as <i>Texas</i> and <i>Oaxaca</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWerner2001443,_444,_445_385-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWerner2001443,_444,_445-385">[384]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The federal government officially recognizes <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Mexico#Indigenous_languages" title="Languages of Mexico">sixty-eight linguistic groups and 364 varieties of indigenous languages</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">[385]</a></sup> It is estimated that around 8.3 million citizens speak these languages,<sup id="cite_ref-Indigenous_Languages_387-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Indigenous_Languages-387">[386]</a></sup> with <a href="/wiki/Nahuatl" title="Nahuatl">Nahuatl</a> being the most widely spoken by more than 1.7 million, followed by <a href="/wiki/Yucatec_Maya_language" title="Yucatec Maya language">Yucatec Maya</a> used daily by nearly 850,000 people, <a href="/wiki/Tzeltal_language" title="Tzeltal language">Tzeltal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tzotzil_language" title="Tzotzil language">Tzotzil</a>, two variants of the <a href="/wiki/Mayan_languages" title="Mayan languages">Mayan languages</a>, are spoken by around half a million people each, primarily in the southern state of <a href="/wiki/Chiapas" title="Chiapas">Chiapas</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Indigenous_Languages_387-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Indigenous_Languages-387">[386]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mixtec_languages" class="mw-redirect" title="Mixtec languages">Mixtec</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zapotec_languages" title="Zapotec languages">Zapotec</a>, both with estimated 500,000 native speakers each, are two other well-known language groups.<sup id="cite_ref-Indigenous_Languages_387-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Indigenous_Languages-387">[386]</a></sup> Since its creation in March 2003, the <a href="/wiki/Instituto_Nacional_de_Lenguas_Ind%C3%ADgenas" title="Instituto Nacional de Lenguas Indígenas">National Indigenous Languages Institute</a> has been in charge of promoting and protecting the use of the country's indigenous languages, through the <a href="/wiki/Ley_General_de_Derechos_Ling%C3%BC%C3%ADsticos_de_los_Pueblos_Ind%C3%ADgenas" title="Ley General de Derechos Lingüísticos de los Pueblos Indígenas">General Law of Indigenous Peoples' Linguistic Rights</a>, which recognizes them <i><a href="/wiki/De_jure" title="De jure">de jure</a></i> as "national languages" with status equal to that of Spanish.<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">[387]</a></sup> Notwithstanding, in practice, indigenous peoples often face discrimination and are unable to have proper access to public services such as education and healthcare, as well as the justice system, as Spanish is the prominent language.<sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">[388]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Aside from indigenous languages, there are several minority languages spoken in Mexico due to international migration such as <a href="/wiki/Low_German" title="Low German">Low German</a> by the 80,000-strong <a href="/wiki/Mennonites_in_Mexico" title="Mennonites in Mexico">Menonite population</a>, primarily settled in the northern states, fuelled by the tolerance of the federal government towards this community by allowing them to set their own educational system compatible with their customs and traditions.<sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">[389]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Chipilo_Venetian_dialect" title="Chipilo Venetian dialect">Chipilo dialect</a>, a variance of the <a href="/wiki/Venetian_language" title="Venetian language">Venetian language</a>, is spoken in the town of <a href="/wiki/Chipilo" title="Chipilo">Chipilo</a>, located in the central state of <a href="/wiki/Puebla" title="Puebla">Puebla</a>, by around 2,500 people, mainly descendants of Venetians that migrated to the area in the late 19th century.<sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391">[390]</a></sup> Furthermore, <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a> is the most commonly taught <a href="/wiki/Foreign_language" title="Foreign language">foreign language</a> in Mexico. It is estimated that nearly 24 million, or around a fifth of the population, study the language through public schools, private institutions or self-access channels.<sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">[391]</a></sup> However, a high level of English proficiency is limited to only 5% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">[392]</a></sup> Moreover, <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a> is the second most widely taught foreign language, as every year between 200,000 and 250,000 Mexican students enroll in language courses.<sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">[393]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">[394]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396">[395]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urban_areas">Urban areas</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_areas_of_Mexico" title="Metropolitan areas of Mexico">Metropolitan areas of Mexico</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Mexico" title="List of cities in Mexico">List of cities in Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The 20 largest cities in Mexico as of the 2010 census. <a href="/wiki/Ecatepec" class="mw-redirect" title="Ecatepec">Ecatepec</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ciudad_Nezahualc%C3%B3yotl" title="Ciudad Nezahualcóyotl">Nezahualcóyotl</a> are part of Metropolitan Mexico City; <a href="/wiki/Ciudad_Ju%C3%A1rez" title="Ciudad Juárez">Juárez</a> is northern border city, directly across from <a href="/wiki/El_Paso,_Texas" title="El Paso, Texas">El Paso, Texas</a>; <a href="/wiki/Tijuana" title="Tijuana">Tijuana</a> is across from <a href="/wiki/San_Diego,_California" class="mw-redirect" title="San Diego, California">San Diego, California</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Mexicali" title="Mexicali">Mexicali</a> is across from <a href="/wiki/Calexico,_California" title="Calexico, California">Calexico, California</a>. </p> 
      <table class="navbox"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="10" class="navbox-title">

        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">6</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Tijuana" title="Tijuana">Tijuana</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Baja_California" title="Baja California">Baja California</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">1,300,983</td> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">16</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Aguascalientes_City" title="Aguascalientes City">Aguascalientes</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Aguascalientes" title="Aguascalientes">Aguascalientes</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">722,250 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">7</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Le%C3%B3n,_Guanajuato" title="León, Guanajuato">León</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Guanajuato" title="Guanajuato">Guanajuato</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">1,238,962</td> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">17</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Hermosillo" title="Hermosillo">Hermosillo</a></td>

         <td style="text-align:right;">715,061 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">8</td>

         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">18</td>

         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">9</td>

         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">10</td>

         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">20</td>

        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Mexico" title="Religion in Mexico">Religion in Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="barbox tright" style="overflow-x: auto;"> 
       <div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:auto; background: white;"> 
        <table style="text-align:left; border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;"> 
         <tbody>
          <tr style="background:#ddd">
           <th style="text-align:center;" colspan="5"><a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Mexico" title="Religion in Mexico">Religion in Mexico</a> (2010 census)<sup id="cite_ref-2010-census_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2010-census-1">[1]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CIA_397-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-397">[396]</a></sup></th>
          </tr> 
          <tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;"> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; text-align:left;"></td> 
           <td style="width:100px; text-align:left;"></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; text-align:right;"></td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Roman Catholicism</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:gold; width:82.7%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">82.7%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Protestantism</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:skyblue; width:6.6%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">6.6%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Jehovah's Witness</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:YellowGreen; width:1.4%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">1.4%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Other Religion</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:Pink; width:1.9%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">1.9%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">No religion</a></td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:black; width:4.7%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">4.7%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Unspecified</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:gray; width:2.7%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">2.7%</td> 
          </tr> 
         </tbody>
        </table> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>The 2010 census by the <a href="/wiki/Instituto_Nacional_de_Estad%C3%ADstica_y_Geograf%C3%ADa" class="mw-redirect" title="Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Geografía">Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Geografía</a> (National Institute of Statistics and Geography) gave <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism_in_Mexico" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholicism in Mexico">Roman Catholicism</a> as the main religion, with 82.7% of the population, while 10% (10,924,103) belong to other Christian denominations, including <a href="/wiki/Evangelicals" class="mw-redirect" title="Evangelicals">Evangelicals</a> (5%); <a href="/wiki/Pentecostals" class="mw-redirect" title="Pentecostals">Pentecostals</a> (1.6%); other Protestant or Reformed (0.7%); <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah's Witnesses">Jehovah's Witnesses</a> (1.4%); <a href="/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church" title="Seventh-day Adventist Church">Seventh-day Adventists</a> (0.6%); and members of <a href="/wiki/The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints" title="The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints">The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints</a> (0.3%).<sup id="cite_ref-2010-census_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2010-census-1">[1]</a></sup> 172,891 (or less than 0.2% of the total) belonged to other, non-Christian religions; 4.7% declared having <a href="/wiki/Irreligion_in_Mexico" title="Irreligion in Mexico">no religion</a>; 2.7% were unspecified.<sup id="cite_ref-2010-census_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2010-census-1">[1]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Nueva_Bas%C3%ADlica_de_Nuestra_Se%C3%B1ora_de_Guadalupe_(JC)_01.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Nueva_Bas%C3%ADlica_de_Nuestra_Se%C3%B1ora_de_Guadalupe_%28JC%29_01.JPG/180px-Nueva_Bas%C3%ADlica_de_Nuestra_Se%C3%B1ora_de_Guadalupe_%28JC%29_01.JPG" decoding="async" width="180" height="240" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Nueva_Bas%C3%ADlica_de_Nuestra_Se%C3%B1ora_de_Guadalupe_%28JC%29_01.JPG/270px-Nueva_Bas%C3%ADlica_de_Nuestra_Se%C3%B1ora_de_Guadalupe_%28JC%29_01.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Nueva_Bas%C3%ADlica_de_Nuestra_Se%C3%B1ora_de_Guadalupe_%28JC%29_01.JPG/360px-Nueva_Bas%C3%ADlica_de_Nuestra_Se%C3%B1ora_de_Guadalupe_%28JC%29_01.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3672" data-file-height="4896"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Nueva_Bas%C3%ADlica_de_Nuestra_Se%C3%B1ora_de_Guadalupe_(JC)_01.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Our_Lady_of_Guadalupe" title="Our Lady of Guadalupe">Our Lady of Guadalupe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Patron_saint" title="Patron saint">patron saint</a> of Mexico. This painting of her at the <a href="/wiki/Basilica_of_Our_Lady_of_Guadalupe" title="Basilica of Our Lady of Guadalupe">Basilica of Guadalupe</a> is among her most notable depictions; scientists still debate if it should be dated 1531, the year of the first apparition,<sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398">[397]</a></sup> or the 1550s.<sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399">[398]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The 92,924,489<sup id="cite_ref-2010-census_1-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2010-census-1">[1]</a></sup> Catholics of Mexico constitute in absolute terms the second largest Catholic community in the world, after <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a>'s.<sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400">[399]</a></sup> 47% percent of them attend church services weekly.<sup id="cite_ref-401" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-401">[400]</a></sup> The feast day of <a href="/wiki/Our_Lady_of_Guadalupe" title="Our Lady of Guadalupe">Our Lady of Guadalupe</a>, the patron saint of Mexico, is celebrated on 12 December and is regarded by many Mexicans as the most important religious holiday of their country.<sup id="cite_ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402">[401]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The denominations <a href="/wiki/Pentecostalism" title="Pentecostalism">Pentecostal</a> also have an important presence, especially in the cities of the border and in the indigenous communities. In fact, Pentecostal churches together have more than 1.3 million adherents, which in net numbers place them as the second Christian creed in Mexico. The situation changes when the different Pentecostal denominations are considered as separate entities. The third-largest Christian group is the <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah's Witnesses">Jehovah's Witnesses</a>, which totals more than 1&nbsp;million adherents. In the same census <a href="/wiki/The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints" title="The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints">The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints</a>, whose members are known as <a href="/wiki/Mormons" title="Mormons">Mormons</a>, reported 314,932 members,<sup id="cite_ref-2010-census_1-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2010-census-1">[1]</a></sup> though the church claimed in 2009 to have over one million registered members.<sup id="cite_ref-lds-Mexico_403-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lds-Mexico-403">[402]</a></sup> Other groups are growing, such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Iglesia_apost%C3%B3lica_de_la_Fe_en_Cristo_Jes%C3%BAs&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Iglesia apostólica de la Fe en Cristo Jesús (page does not exist)">Iglesia apostólica de la Fe en Cristo Jesús</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mennonites_in_Mexico" title="Mennonites in Mexico">Mennonites</a> and <a href="/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church" title="Seventh-day Adventist Church">Seventh-day Adventist Church</a> and <a href="/wiki/La_Luz_del_Mundo" title="La Luz del Mundo">Church of the La Luz del Mundo</a>, which has its center in "<a href="/w/index.php?title=La_Hermosa_Provincia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="La Hermosa Provincia (page does not exist)">La Hermosa Provincia</a>", a colony of <a href="/wiki/Guadalajara" title="Guadalajara">Guadalajara</a>. Migratory phenomena have led to the spread of different aspects of Christianity, including branches <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestants</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches" title="Eastern Catholic Churches">Eastern Catholic Churches</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cristianismosorientales_404-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cristianismosorientales-404">[403]</a></sup> The presence of <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Mexico" title="History of the Jews in Mexico">Jews in Mexico</a> dates back to 1521, when Hernán Cortés conquered the Aztecs, accompanied by several <a href="/wiki/Converso" title="Converso">Conversos</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">[404]</a></sup> According to the 2010 census, there are 67,476 Jews in Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-2010-census_1-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2010-census-1">[1]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Mexico" title="Islam in Mexico">Islam in Mexico</a> is practiced mostly by <a href="/wiki/Arab_Mexican" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab Mexican">Arab Mexicans</a>. In the 2010 census 18,185 Mexicans reported belonging to an <a href="/wiki/Eastern_religion" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern religion">Eastern religion</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-2010-census_1-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2010-census-1">[1]</a></sup> a category which includes a tiny <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Mexico" title="Buddhism in Mexico">Buddhist</a> population. </p>
      <p>According to <a href="/wiki/Jacobo_Grinberg" title="Jacobo Grinberg">Jacobo Grinberg</a> (in texts edited by the <a href="/wiki/National_Autonomous_University_of_Mexico" title="National Autonomous University of Mexico">National Autonomous University of Mexico</a>), the survival of magic-religious rituals of the old <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples" title="Indigenous peoples">indigenous</a> groups is remarkable, not only in the current indigenous population but also in the <a href="/wiki/Mestizo" title="Mestizo">mestizo</a> and <a href="/wiki/White_people" title="White people">white</a> population that make up the Mexican rural and urban society. There is often a <a href="/wiki/Syncretism" title="Syncretism">syncretism</a> between <a href="/wiki/Shamanism" title="Shamanism">shamanism</a> and Catholic traditions. Another religion of popular syncretism in Mexico (especially in recent years) is the <a href="/wiki/Santer%C3%ADa" title="Santería">Santería</a>. This is mainly due to the large number of Cubans who settled in the territory after the <a href="/wiki/Cuban_Revolution" title="Cuban Revolution">Cuban Revolution</a> (mainly in states such as <a href="/wiki/Veracruz" title="Veracruz">Veracruz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yucat%C3%A1n" title="Yucatán">Yucatán</a>). Even though Mexico was also a recipient of black slaves from <a href="/wiki/Africa" title="Africa">Africa</a> in the 16th century, the apogee of these cults is relatively new.<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">[405]</a></sup> In general, popular religiosity is viewed with bad eyes by institutionally structured religions. One of the most exemplary cases of popular religiosity is the cult of <a href="/wiki/Santa_Muerte" title="Santa Muerte">Holy Dead</a> (Santa Muerte). The Catholic hierarchy insists on describing it as a satanic cult. However, most of the people who profess this cult declare themselves to be Catholic believers, and consider that there is no contradiction between the tributes they offer to the <a href="/wiki/Christ_Child" title="Christ Child">Christ Child</a> and the adoration of God. Other examples are the representations of the <a href="/wiki/Stations_of_the_Cross" title="Stations of the Cross">Passion of Christ</a> and the celebration of <a href="/wiki/Day_of_the_Dead" title="Day of the Dead">Day of the Dead</a>, which take place within the framework of the Catholic Christian imaginary, but under a very particular reinterpretation of its protagonists.<sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">[406]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In certain regions, the profession of a creed other than the Catholic is seen as a threat to community unity. It is argued that the Catholic religion is part of the ethnic identity, and that the Protestants are not willing to participate in the traditional customs and practices (the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tequio&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tequio (page does not exist)">tequio</a> or community work, participation in the festivities and similar issues). The refusal of the Protestants is because their religious beliefs do not allow them to participate in the cult of images. In extreme cases, tension between Catholics and Protestants has led to the expulsion or even murder of Protestants in several villages. The best known cases are those of <a href="/wiki/San_Juan_Chamula" class="mw-redirect" title="San Juan Chamula">San Juan Chamula</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408">[407]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409">[408]</a></sup> in Chiapas, and San Nicolás, in <a href="/wiki/Ixmiquilpan" title="Ixmiquilpan">Ixmiquilpan</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410">[409]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hidalgo_(state)" title="Hidalgo (state)">Hidalgo</a>. </p>
      <p>A similar argument was presented by a committee of anthropologists to request the government of the Republic to expel the <a href="/wiki/SIL_International" title="SIL International">Summer Linguistic Institute</a> (SIL), in the year 1979, which was accused of promoting the division of indigenous peoples by translating the <a href="/wiki/Bible" title="Bible">Bible</a> into vernacular languages and evangelizing in a Protestant creed that threatened the integrity of popular cultures. The Mexican government paid attention to the call of the anthropologists and canceled the agreement that had held with the SIL.<sup id="cite_ref-WP_411-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WP-411">[410]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Mexico" title="Healthcare in Mexico">Healthcare in Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Mexico_df_-_Centro_M%C3%A9dico_Nacional_Siglo_XXI.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Mexico_df_-_Centro_M%C3%A9dico_Nacional_Siglo_XXI.JPG/250px-Mexico_df_-_Centro_M%C3%A9dico_Nacional_Siglo_XXI.JPG" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Mexico_df_-_Centro_M%C3%A9dico_Nacional_Siglo_XXI.JPG/375px-Mexico_df_-_Centro_M%C3%A9dico_Nacional_Siglo_XXI.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Mexico_df_-_Centro_M%C3%A9dico_Nacional_Siglo_XXI.JPG/500px-Mexico_df_-_Centro_M%C3%A9dico_Nacional_Siglo_XXI.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4189" data-file-height="2793"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Mexico_df_-_Centro_M%C3%A9dico_Nacional_Siglo_XXI.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/General_Hospital_of_Mexico" title="General Hospital of Mexico">General Hospital of Mexico</a> in Mexico City.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Since the early 1990s, Mexico entered a transitional stage in the health of its population and some indicators such as mortality patterns are identical to those found in highly developed countries like Germany or Japan.<sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">[411]</a></sup> Mexico's medical infrastructure is highly rated for the most part and is usually excellent in major cities,<sup id="cite_ref-Health_Care_in_Mexico_413-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Health_Care_in_Mexico-413">[412]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414">[413]</a></sup> but rural communities still lack equipment for advanced medical procedures, forcing patients in those locations to travel to the closest urban areas to get specialized medical care.<sup id="cite_ref-brit-mex_182-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brit-mex-182">[182]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Social_determinants_of_health_in_Mexico" title="Social determinants of health in Mexico">Social determinants of health</a> can be used to evaluate the state of health in Mexico. </p>
      <p>State-funded institutions such as <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Social_Security_Institute" title="Mexican Social Security Institute">Mexican Social Security Institute</a> (IMSS) and the <a href="/wiki/Institute_for_Social_Security_and_Services_for_State_Workers" title="Institute for Social Security and Services for State Workers">Institute for Social Security and Services for State Workers</a> (ISSSTE) play a major role in health and social security. Private health services are also very important and account for 13% of all medical units in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415">[414]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Medical training is done mostly at public universities with much specializations done in vocational or internship settings. Some public universities in Mexico, such as the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Guadalajara" title="University of Guadalajara">University of Guadalajara</a>, have signed agreements with the U.S. to receive and train American students in Medicine. Health care costs in private institutions and prescription drugs in Mexico are on average lower than that of its North American economic partners.<sup id="cite_ref-Health_Care_in_Mexico_413-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Health_Care_in_Mexico-413">[412]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Biblioteca_Central..jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Biblioteca_Central..jpg/220px-Biblioteca_Central..jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="164" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Biblioteca_Central..jpg/330px-Biblioteca_Central..jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Biblioteca_Central..jpg/440px-Biblioteca_Central..jpg 2x" data-file-width="2557" data-file-height="1910"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Biblioteca_Central..jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Central_Library_(UNAM)" title="Central Library (UNAM)">Central Library</a> of the <a href="/wiki/National_Autonomous_University_of_Mexico" title="National Autonomous University of Mexico">National Autonomous University of Mexico</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Mexico" title="Education in Mexico">Education in Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2004, the literacy rate was at 97%<sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416">[415]</a></sup> for youth under the age of 14, and 91% for people over 15,<sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417">[416]</a></sup> placing Mexico at 24th place in the world according to <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418">[417]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/National_Autonomous_University_of_Mexico" title="National Autonomous University of Mexico">National Autonomous University of Mexico</a> ranks 103rd in the <a href="/wiki/QS_World_University_Rankings" title="QS World University Rankings">QS World University Rankings</a>, making it the best university in Mexico. After it comes the <a href="/wiki/Monterrey_Institute_of_Technology_and_Higher_Education" title="Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education">Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education</a> as the best private school in Mexico and 158th worldwide in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419">[418]</a></sup> Private business schools also stand out in international rankings. <a href="/wiki/IPADE" class="mw-redirect" title="IPADE">IPADE</a> and <a href="/wiki/EGADE" class="mw-redirect" title="EGADE">EGADE</a>, the business schools of <a href="/wiki/Universidad_Panamericana" class="mw-redirect" title="Universidad Panamericana">Universidad Panamericana</a> and of <a href="/wiki/Monterrey_Institute_of_Technology_and_Higher_Education" title="Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education">Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education</a> respectively, were ranked in the top 10 in a survey conducted by <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a></i> among recruiters outside the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420">[419]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Women">Women</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Women_in_Mexico" title="Women in Mexico">Women in Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Olga_S%C3%A1nchez_Cordero_-_rostro.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Olga_S%C3%A1nchez_Cordero_-_rostro.jpg/170px-Olga_S%C3%A1nchez_Cordero_-_rostro.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="209" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Olga_S%C3%A1nchez_Cordero_-_rostro.jpg/255px-Olga_S%C3%A1nchez_Cordero_-_rostro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Olga_S%C3%A1nchez_Cordero_-_rostro.jpg/340px-Olga_S%C3%A1nchez_Cordero_-_rostro.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3531" data-file-height="4337"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Olga_S%C3%A1nchez_Cordero_-_rostro.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Olga_S%C3%A1nchez_Cordero" title="Olga Sánchez Cordero">Olga Sánchez Cordero</a>, Minister of the Interior (<i>Gobernacion</i>) in President López Obrador's cabinet
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Until the twentieth century, Mexico was an overwhelmingly rural country, with rural women's status defined within the context of the family and local community. With urbanization beginning in the sixteenth century, following the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_conquest_of_the_Aztec_empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Spanish conquest of the Aztec empire">Spanish conquest of the Aztec empire</a>, cities have provided economic and social opportunities not possible within rural villages. Beginning in the late nineteenth century, women including middle-class women began working outside the home in offices and factories, and the gained access to education.<sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421">[420]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422">[421]</a></sup> Women were granted <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_suffrage_in_Mexico" title="Women's suffrage in Mexico">suffrage</a> in 1953.<sup id="cite_ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423">[422]</a></sup> In the 21st century, Mexican women are prominent in politics, academia, journalism, literature, and visual arts among other fields. In President <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Manuel_L%C3%B3pez_Obrador" title="Andrés Manuel López Obrador">Andrés Manuel López Obrador</a>'s first cabinet following his 2018 election, he appointed women in equal numbers as men.<sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424">[423]</a></sup> However, a wave of feminism in 2020 has criticized the president for his tone-deaf response to murders of women in Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425">[424]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Mexico is among the countries that treat particular murders of women as <a href="/wiki/Femicide" title="Femicide">femicide</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">[425]</a></sup> In 2014, Mexico had the 16th highest rate of homicides committed against women in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-femicide_427-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-femicide-427">[426]</a></sup> The remains of the victims were frequently mutilated.<sup id="cite_ref-hp_8Jan2015_428-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hp_8Jan2015-428">[427]</a></sup> According to a 1997 study, domestic abuse in Mexican culture "is embedded in gender and marital relations fostered in Mexican women's dependence on their spouses for subsistence and for self-esteem, sustained by ideologies of romantic love, by family structure and residential arrangements".<sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429">[428]</a></sup> The perpetrators are often the boyfriend, father-in-law, ex-husbands or husbands but only 1.6% of the murder cases led to an arrest and sentencing in 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-hp_8Jan2015_428-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hp_8Jan2015-428">[427]</a></sup> After a particularly well-publicized gruesome femicide followed by that of a kidnapped little girl, women began protesting more vociferously, falling on deaf ears, including those of President López Obrador. This is the first new and major movement with which his presidency has had to deal. On <a href="/wiki/International_Women%27s_Day" title="International Women's Day">International Women's Day</a> (8 March) in 2020, women staged a massive demonstration in Mexico City with some 80,000 participants. On Monday, 9 March 2020, the second day of action was marked by the absence of women at work, in class, shopping and other public activities. The "Day Without Women" (<i>Día Sin Nosotras</i>) was reported in the international press along with the previous day's demonstrations.<sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430">[429]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431">[430]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Mexico" title="Culture of Mexico">Culture of Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Talaveraarmando.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Talaveraarmando.jpg/220px-Talaveraarmando.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="220" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Talaveraarmando.jpg/330px-Talaveraarmando.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Talaveraarmando.jpg/440px-Talaveraarmando.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2828" data-file-height="2828"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Talaveraarmando.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Talavera_pottery" title="Talavera pottery">Talavera pottery</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Mexican culture reflects the complexity of the <a href="/wiki/History_of_Mexico" title="History of Mexico">country's history</a> through the blending of indigenous cultures and the <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Spain" title="Culture of Spain">culture of Spain</a>, imparted during Spain's 300-year colonial rule of Mexico. Exogenous cultural elements have been incorporated into Mexican culture as time has passed. </p>
      <p>The Porfirian era (<i>el <a href="/wiki/Porfirio_D%C3%ADaz" title="Porfirio Díaz">Porfiriato</a></i>), in the last quarter of the 19th century and the first decade of the 20th century, was marked by economic progress and peace. After four decades of civil unrest and war, Mexico saw the development of philosophy and the arts, promoted by President Díaz himself. Since that time, as accentuated during the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Revolution" title="Mexican Revolution">Mexican Revolution</a>, cultural identity has had its foundation in the <i>mestizaje</i>, of which the indigenous (i.e. Amerindian) element is the core. In light of the various ethnicities that formed the Mexican people, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Vasconcelos" title="José Vasconcelos">José Vasconcelos</a> in <i>La Raza Cósmica</i> (The Cosmic Race) (1925) defined Mexico to be the melting pot of all races (thus extending the definition of the <i>mestizo</i>) not only biologically but culturally as well.<sup id="cite_ref-vasconcelos160_432-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vasconcelos160-432">[431]</a></sup> Other Mexican intellectuals grappled with the idea of <i>Lo Mexicano</i>, which seeks "to discover the national ethos of Mexican culture."<sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433">[432]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Nobel_laureate" class="mw-redirect" title="Nobel laureate">Nobel laureate</a> <a href="/wiki/Octavio_Paz" title="Octavio Paz">Octavio Paz</a> explores the notion of a Mexican national character in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Labyrinth_of_Solitude" title="The Labyrinth of Solitude">The Labyrinth of Solitude</a></i>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Painting">Painting</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mexican_art" title="Mexican art">Mexican art</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes_de_Noche.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes_de_Noche.jpg/250px-Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes_de_Noche.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes_de_Noche.jpg/375px-Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes_de_Noche.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes_de_Noche.jpg/500px-Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes_de_Noche.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5616" data-file-height="3744"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes_de_Noche.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes" title="Palacio de Bellas Artes">Palacio de Bellas Artes</a> (Palace of Fine Arts)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Murales_Rivera_-_Ausbeutung_durch_die_Spanier_1_perspective.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Murales_Rivera_-_Ausbeutung_durch_die_Spanier_1_perspective.jpg/220px-Murales_Rivera_-_Ausbeutung_durch_die_Spanier_1_perspective.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="195" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Murales_Rivera_-_Ausbeutung_durch_die_Spanier_1_perspective.jpg/330px-Murales_Rivera_-_Ausbeutung_durch_die_Spanier_1_perspective.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Murales_Rivera_-_Ausbeutung_durch_die_Spanier_1_perspective.jpg/440px-Murales_Rivera_-_Ausbeutung_durch_die_Spanier_1_perspective.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2684" data-file-height="2384"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Murales_Rivera_-_Ausbeutung_durch_die_Spanier_1_perspective.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Mexican_Muralism" class="mw-redirect" title="Mexican Muralism">Mexican Muralism</a>. A cultural expression starting in the 1920s created by a group of Mexican painters after the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Revolution" title="Mexican Revolution">Mexican Revolution</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Painting" title="Painting">Painting</a> is one of the oldest arts in Mexico. Cave painting in Mexican territory is about 7500 years old and has been found in the caves of the <a href="/wiki/Baja_California_Peninsula" title="Baja California Peninsula">Baja California Peninsula</a>. Pre-Hispanic Mexico is present in buildings and caves, in <a href="/wiki/Aztec_codices" title="Aztec codices">Aztec codices</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Ceramics" class="mw-redirect" title="Ceramics">ceramics</a>, in garments, etc. .; examples of this are the <a href="/wiki/Maya_civilization" title="Maya civilization">Maya</a> mural paintings of <a href="/wiki/Bonampak" title="Bonampak">Bonampak</a>, or those of <a href="/wiki/Teotihuac%C3%A1n" class="mw-redirect" title="Teotihuacán">Teotihuacán</a>, those of <a href="/wiki/Cacaxtla" title="Cacaxtla">Cacaxtla</a> and those of <a href="/wiki/Monte_Alb%C3%A1n" title="Monte Albán">Monte Albán</a>. </p>
      <p>Mural painting with religious themes had an important flowering during the 16th century; the same in religious constructions as in houses of lineage; such is the case of the convents of <a href="/wiki/Acolman" title="Acolman">Acolman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Actopan,_Hidalgo" title="Actopan, Hidalgo">Actopan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Huejotzingo" title="Huejotzingo">Huejotzingo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tecamachalco,_Puebla" title="Tecamachalco, Puebla">Tecamachalco</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zinacantepec" class="mw-redirect" title="Zinacantepec">Zinacantepec</a>. These were also manifested in illustrated manuscripts such as the 1576 <a href="/wiki/Florentine_codex" class="mw-redirect" title="Florentine codex">Florentine codex</a> overseen by Franciscan <a href="/wiki/Bernardino_de_Sahag%C3%BAn" title="Bernardino de Sahagún">Bernardino de Sahagún</a>. Most art in the colonial era was religious, but starting in the late seventeenth century and most prominently in the eighteenth century, secular portraits and <a href="/wiki/Casta" title="Casta">casta painting</a> appeared. Important painters of the late colonial period were <a href="/wiki/Juan_Correa" title="Juan Correa">Juan Correa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crist%C3%B3bal_de_Villalpando" title="Cristóbal de Villalpando">Cristóbal de Villalpando</a> and <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Cabrera_(painter)" title="Miguel Cabrera (painter)">Miguel Cabrera</a>. </p>
      <p>Nineteenth-century painting had a marked romantic influence; landscapes and portraits were the greatest expressions of this era. <a href="/wiki/Hermenegildo_Bustos" title="Hermenegildo Bustos">Hermenegildo Bustos</a> is one of the most appreciated painters of the <a href="/wiki/Historiography" title="Historiography">historiography</a> of Mexican art. Other painters include <a href="https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santiago_Rebull" class="extiw" title="es:Santiago Rebull">Santiago Rebull</a>, <a href="/wiki/F%C3%A9lix_Parra" title="Félix Parra">Félix Parra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eugenio_Landesio" title="Eugenio Landesio">Eugenio Landesio</a>, and his noted pupil, the landscape artist <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Mar%C3%ADa_Velasco_G%C3%B3mez" title="José María Velasco Gómez">José María Velasco</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-434" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-434">[433]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Mexican_art" title="Mexican art">Mexican painting</a> of the 20th century has achieved world renown with figures such as <a href="/wiki/David_Alfaro_Siqueiros" title="David Alfaro Siqueiros">David Alfaro Siqueiros</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Clemente_Orozco" title="José Clemente Orozco">José Clemente Orozco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joaqu%C3%ADn_Clausell" title="Joaquín Clausell">Joaquín Clausell</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frida_Kahlo" title="Frida Kahlo">Frida Kahlo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Diego_Rivera" title="Diego Rivera">Diego Rivera</a>, a generation of idealists who marked the image of modern Mexico in the face of strong social and economic criticism. The Oaxacan School quickly gained fame and prestige, diffusion of ancestral and modern culture.
