Freedom of design is observed in relation to the color and texture of the canvases and murals as a period of transition between the 20th century and the 21st century. <a href="/wiki/Federico_Cant%C3%BA_Garza" title="Federico Cantú Garza">Federico Cantú Garza</a>, <a href="/wiki/Juan_O%27Gorman" title="Juan O'Gorman">Juan O'Gorman</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rufino_Tamayo" title="Rufino Tamayo">Rufino Tamayo</a> are also important artists. Diego Rivera, the most well-known figure of <a href="/wiki/Mexican_muralism" title="Mexican muralism">Mexican muralism</a>, painted the <a href="/wiki/Man_at_the_Crossroads" title="Man at the Crossroads">Man at the Crossroads</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Rockefeller_Center" title="Rockefeller Center">Rockefeller Center</a> in New York City, a huge mural that was destroyed by the Rockefellers the next year because of the inclusion of a portrait of Russian communist leader <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">Lenin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-435" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-435">[434]</a></sup> Some of Rivera's murals are displayed at the Mexican <a href="/wiki/National_Palace_(Mexico)" title="National Palace (Mexico)">National Palace</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes" title="Palacio de Bellas Artes">Palace of Fine Arts</a>. </p>
      <p>Some of the most outstanding painters in the late 20th century and early 21st century: <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Toledo" title="Francisco Toledo">Francisco Toledo</a> was a Mexican Zapotec painter, sculptor, and graphic artist. In a career that spanned seven decades, Toledo produced thousands of works of art and became widely regarded as one of Mexico's most important contemporary artists. <a href="/wiki/Ver%C3%B3nica_Ruiz_de_Velasco" title="Verónica Ruiz de Velasco">Verónica Ruiz de Velasco</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Neofigurative" class="mw-redirect" title="Neofigurative">neofigurative</a> painter and muralist. Both <a href="/wiki/Ver%C3%B3nica_Ruiz_de_Velasco" title="Verónica Ruiz de Velasco">Verónica Ruiz de Velasco</a> and <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Toledo" title="Francisco Toledo">Francisco Toledo</a> were students of <a href="/wiki/Rufino_Tamayo" title="Rufino Tamayo">Rufino Tamayo</a>. <a href="/wiki/Gilberto_Aceves_Navarro" title="Gilberto Aceves Navarro">Gilberto Aceves Navarro</a> is also considered an important contemporary artist. </p>
      <p>Throughout history several prominent painters of different nationalities have expressed in their works the face of Mexico. Among the most outstanding we can mention are <a href="/wiki/Claudio_Linati" title="Claudio Linati">Claudio Linati</a>, <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Thomas_Egerton" title="Daniel Thomas Egerton">Daniel Thomas Egerton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carl_Nebel" title="Carl Nebel">Carl Nebel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Moran" title="Thomas Moran">Thomas Moran</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Leonora_Carrington" title="Leonora Carrington">Leonora Carrington</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sculpture">Sculpture</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sculpture_in_Mexico" title="Sculpture in Mexico">Sculpture in Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:102px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:El_apoteosis_de_Padre_de_la_Patria_DF_MEX.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/El_apoteosis_de_Padre_de_la_Patria_DF_MEX.JPG/100px-El_apoteosis_de_Padre_de_la_Patria_DF_MEX.JPG" decoding="async" width="100" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/El_apoteosis_de_Padre_de_la_Patria_DF_MEX.JPG/150px-El_apoteosis_de_Padre_de_la_Patria_DF_MEX.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/El_apoteosis_de_Padre_de_la_Patria_DF_MEX.JPG/200px-El_apoteosis_de_Padre_de_la_Patria_DF_MEX.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2144" data-file-height="3216"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:El_apoteosis_de_Padre_de_la_Patria_DF_MEX.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>View of the <a href="/wiki/Apotheosis" title="Apotheosis">Apotheosis</a> sculptural group at the <a href="/wiki/Angel_of_Independence" title="Angel of Independence">Angel of Independence</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Sculpture was an integral part of pre-Hispanic <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerica" title="Mesoamerica">Mesoamerican</a> civilizations, (<a href="/wiki/Maya_civilization" title="Maya civilization">Mayans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Olmec" class="mw-redirect" title="Olmec">Olmecs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Toltec" title="Toltec">Toltecs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mixtec" title="Mixtec">Mixtecs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aztec" class="mw-redirect" title="Aztec">Aztecs</a>), and others, usually religious in nature. From the Spanish conquest in 1521, civil and religious sculpture was created by indigenous artists, with guidance from Spaniards, so some pre-Hispanic features are evident. Since the 17th century, white and <a href="/wiki/Mestizo" title="Mestizo">mestizo</a> sculptors have created works with a marked influence of European classicism. After independence in 1821, sculpture was influenced by Romanticism, which tended to break the strict norms and models of classicism, while it pursued ideas influenced by realism and nationalism. Religious sculpture was reduced to a sporadic imagery, while the secular sculpture continued in portraits and monumental art of a civic nature. Between 1820 and 1880 the predominant themes were, successively: religious images, biblical scenes, allegories to the symbols of the independence insurgency, scenes and personages of pre-Hispanic history, and busts of the old aristocracy, of the nascent bourgeoisie and commanders of the pre-revolution. During the 20th century, some important exponents of Mexican sculpture are <a href="/wiki/Juan_Soriano_(artist)" title="Juan Soriano (artist)">Juan Soriano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Luis_Cuevas" title="José Luis Cuevas">José Luis Cuevas</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sebasti%C3%A1n_(sculptor)" title="Sebastián (sculptor)">Enrique Carbajal</a> (also known as Sebastián).<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Mexico" title="Architecture of Mexico">Architecture of Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:SSA41434.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/SSA41434.JPG/220px-SSA41434.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/SSA41434.JPG/330px-SSA41434.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/SSA41434.JPG/440px-SSA41434.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="768"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:SSA41434.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Teotihuac%C3%A1n" class="mw-redirect" title="Teotihuacán">Teotihuacán</a>, <a href="/wiki/State_of_Mexico" title="State of Mexico">State of Mexico</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The presence of the humans in the Mexican territory has left important archaeological findings of great importance for the explanation of the habitat of primitive man and contemporary man. The Mesoamerican civilizations managed to have great stylistic development and proportion on the human and urban scale, the form was evolving from simplicity to aesthetic complexity; in the north of the country the adobe and stone architecture is manifested, the multifamily housing as we can see in <a href="/wiki/Casas_Grandes" title="Casas Grandes">Casas Grandes</a>; and the troglodyte dwelling in caves of the Sierra Madre Occidental. Urbanism had a great development in pre-Hispanic cultures, where we can see the magnitude of the cities of <a href="/wiki/Teotihuac%C3%A1n" class="mw-redirect" title="Teotihuacán">Teotihuacán</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tula_(Mesoamerican_site)" title="Tula (Mesoamerican site)">Tollan-Xicocotitlan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tenochtitlan" title="Tenochtitlan">México-Tenochtitlan</a>, within the environmentalist urbanism highlight the Mayan cities to be incorporated into the monumentality of its buildings with the thickness of the jungle and complex networks of roads called <i>sakbés</i>. <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerican_architecture" title="Mesoamerican architecture">Mesoamerican architecture</a> is noted for its pyramids which are the largest such structures outside of Ancient Egypt.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Spanish_Colonial_architecture" title="Spanish Colonial architecture">Spanish Colonial architecture</a> is marked by the contrast between the simple, solid construction demanded by the new environment and the Baroque ornamentation exported from Spain. Mexico, as the center of New Spain has some of the most renowned buildings built in this style. With the arrival of the Spaniards, architectural theories of the Greco-Roman order with Arab influences were introduced. Due to the process of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Evangelization_in_New_Spain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Evangelization in New Spain (page does not exist)">evangelization</a>, when the first monastic temples and monasteries were built, their own models were projected, such as the <a href="/wiki/Mendicant_monasteries_in_Mexico" title="Mendicant monasteries in Mexico">mendicant monasteries</a>, unique in their type in architecture. The interaction between Spaniards and natives gave rise to artistic styles such as the so-called <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tequitqui&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tequitqui (page does not exist)">tequitqui</a></i> (from <a href="/wiki/Nahuatl" title="Nahuatl">Nahuatl</a>: worker). Years later the baroque and mannerism were imposed in large cathedrals and civil buildings, while rural areas are built <a href="/wiki/Hacienda" title="Hacienda">haciendas</a> or stately farms with Mozarabic tendencies.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ext_06Museo_Soumaya_FREE_Fernando_Romero_EnterprisE_photo_by_Adam_Wiseman.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Ext_06Museo_Soumaya_FREE_Fernando_Romero_EnterprisE_photo_by_Adam_Wiseman.jpg/180px-Ext_06Museo_Soumaya_FREE_Fernando_Romero_EnterprisE_photo_by_Adam_Wiseman.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="271" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Ext_06Museo_Soumaya_FREE_Fernando_Romero_EnterprisE_photo_by_Adam_Wiseman.jpg/270px-Ext_06Museo_Soumaya_FREE_Fernando_Romero_EnterprisE_photo_by_Adam_Wiseman.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Ext_06Museo_Soumaya_FREE_Fernando_Romero_EnterprisE_photo_by_Adam_Wiseman.jpg/360px-Ext_06Museo_Soumaya_FREE_Fernando_Romero_EnterprisE_photo_by_Adam_Wiseman.jpg 2x" data-file-width="479" data-file-height="720"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ext_06Museo_Soumaya_FREE_Fernando_Romero_EnterprisE_photo_by_Adam_Wiseman.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Museo_Soumaya" title="Museo Soumaya">Museo Soumaya</a> in Mexico City building
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In the 19th century the neoclassical movement arose as a response to the objectives of the republican nation, one of its examples are the <a href="/wiki/Hospicio_Caba%C3%B1as" title="Hospicio Cabañas">Hospicio Cabañas</a> where the strict plastic of the classical orders are represented in their architectural elements, new religious buildings also arise, civilian and military that demonstrate the presence of neoclassicism. Romanticists from a past seen through archeology show images of medieval Europe, Islamic and pre-Hispanic Mexico in the form of architectural elements in the construction of international exhibition pavilions looking for an identity typical of the national culture. The <i>art nouveau</i>, and the <i>art deco</i> were styles introduced into the design of the <a href="/wiki/Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes" title="Palacio de Bellas Artes">Palacio de Bellas Artes</a> to mark the identity of the Mexican nation with Greek-Roman and pre-Hispanic symbols.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Modern architecture in Mexico has an important development in the plasticity of form and space, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Villagr%C3%A1n_Garc%C3%ADa" title="José Villagrán García">José Villagrán García</a> develops a theory of form that sets the pattern of teaching in many schools of architecture in the country within functionalism. The emergence of the new <a href="/wiki/Mexican_architecture" class="mw-redirect" title="Mexican architecture">Mexican architecture</a> was born as a formal order of the policies of a nationalist state that sought modernity and the differentiation of other nations. The development of a Mexican modernist architecture was perhaps mostly fully manifested in the mid-1950s construction of the <a href="/wiki/Ciudad_Universitaria,_Mexico_City" title="Ciudad Universitaria, Mexico City">Ciudad Universitaria, Mexico City</a>, the main campus of the <a href="/wiki/National_Autonomous_University_of_Mexico" title="National Autonomous University of Mexico">National Autonomous University of Mexico</a>. Designed by the most prestigious architects of the era, including <a href="/wiki/Mario_Pani" title="Mario Pani">Mario Pani</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eugenio_Peschard" title="Eugenio Peschard">Eugenio Peschard</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Enrique_del_Moral" title="Enrique del Moral">Enrique del Moral</a>, the buildings feature murals by artists <a href="/wiki/Diego_Rivera" title="Diego Rivera">Diego Rivera</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Alfaro_Siqueiros" title="David Alfaro Siqueiros">David Alfaro Siqueiros</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Ch%C3%A1vez_Morado" title="José Chávez Morado">José Chávez Morado</a>. It has since been recognized as a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" class="mw-redirect" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-436" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-436">[435]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Juan_O%27Gorman" title="Juan O'Gorman">Juan O'Gorman</a> was one of the first environmental architects in Mexico, developing the "organic" theory, trying to integrate the building with the landscape within the same approaches of <a href="/wiki/Frank_Lloyd_Wright" title="Frank Lloyd Wright">Frank Lloyd Wright</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-437" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-437">[436]</a></sup> In the search for a new architecture that does not resemble the styles of the past, it achieves a joint manifestation with the mural painting and the <a href="/wiki/Landscaping" title="Landscaping">landscaping</a>. </p>
      <p>The Jalisco School was a proposal of those socio-political movements that the country demanded. <a href="/wiki/Luis_Barrag%C3%A1n" title="Luis Barragán">Luis Barragán</a> combined the shape of the space with forms of rural vernacular architecture of Mexico and Mediterranean countries (Spain-Morocco), integrating an impressive color that handles light and shade in different tones and opens a look at the international <a href="/wiki/Minimalism" title="Minimalism">minimalism</a>. He won the 1980 <a href="/wiki/Pritzker_Prize" class="mw-redirect" title="Pritzker Prize">Pritzker Prize</a>, the highest award in architecture.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Mexican architecture is a cultural phenomenon born of the ideology of nationalist governments of the 20th century, which was shaping the identity image by its colorful and variegated ornamental elements inherited from ancestral cultures, classical and monumental forms and, subsequently, the incorporation of modernism and cutting-edge international trends.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Photography">Photography</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Mexican_art#Photography_in_Mexico" title="Mexican art">Mexican art §&nbsp;Photography in Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:David_Alfaro_Siqueiros_(El_Coronelazo).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/David_Alfaro_Siqueiros_%28El_Coronelazo%29.jpg/170px-David_Alfaro_Siqueiros_%28El_Coronelazo%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="244" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/David_Alfaro_Siqueiros_%28El_Coronelazo%29.jpg/255px-David_Alfaro_Siqueiros_%28El_Coronelazo%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/David_Alfaro_Siqueiros_%28El_Coronelazo%29.jpg/340px-David_Alfaro_Siqueiros_%28El_Coronelazo%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="495" data-file-height="711"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:David_Alfaro_Siqueiros_(El_Coronelazo).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/David_Alfaro_Siqueiros" title="David Alfaro Siqueiros">David Alfaro Siqueiros</a> by <a href="/wiki/H%C3%A9ctor_Garc%C3%ADa_Cobo" title="Héctor García Cobo">Héctor García Cobo</a> at <a href="/wiki/Palacio_de_Lecumberri" title="Palacio de Lecumberri">Lecumberri prison</a>, Mexico City, 1960.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Mexico has been photographed since the nineteenth century, when the technology was first developed. During the Porfiriato, Díaz realized the importance of photography in shaping the understanding of his regime and its accomplishments. The government hired <a href="/wiki/Guillermo_Kahlo" title="Guillermo Kahlo">Guillermo Kahlo</a> (father of painter <a href="/wiki/Frida_Kahlo" title="Frida Kahlo">Frida Kahlo</a>) to create photographic images of Mexico's new industrial structures as well as its pre-Hispanic and colonial past. Photographer <a href="/wiki/Hugo_Brehme" title="Hugo Brehme">Hugo Brehme</a> specialized in images of "picturesque" Mexico, with images of Mexican places and often rural people. During the Mexican Revolution, photographers chronicled the conflict, usually in the aftermath of a battle, since large and heavy equipment did not permit action shots. <a href="/wiki/Agust%C3%ADn_Casasola" title="Agustín Casasola">Agustín Victor Casasola</a> is the most famous of photographer of the revolutionary era, and he collected other photographers' images in the <a href="/wiki/Casasola_Archive" title="Casasola Archive">Casasola Archive</a>; his vast collection was purchased by the Mexican government and is now part of the government photographic repository, the Fototeca.<sup id="cite_ref-438" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-438">[437]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-439" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-439">[438]</a></sup> After the revolution, Mexican photographers created photographs as art images.<sup id="cite_ref-440" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-440">[439]</a></sup> Among others, notable Mexican photographers include <a href="/wiki/Manuel_%C3%81lvarez_Bravo" title="Manuel Álvarez Bravo">Manuel Álvarez Bravo</a>, <a href="/wiki/H%C3%A9ctor_Garc%C3%ADa_Cobo" title="Héctor García Cobo">Héctor García Cobo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Graciela_Iturbide" title="Graciela Iturbide">Graciela Iturbide</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Mexican_literature" title="Mexican literature">Mexican literature</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerican_literature" title="Mesoamerican literature">Mesoamerican literature</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Sor_Juana_by_Miguel_Cabrera.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Sor_Juana_by_Miguel_Cabrera.png/170px-Sor_Juana_by_Miguel_Cabrera.png" decoding="async" width="170" height="238" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Sor_Juana_by_Miguel_Cabrera.png/255px-Sor_Juana_by_Miguel_Cabrera.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Sor_Juana_by_Miguel_Cabrera.png/340px-Sor_Juana_by_Miguel_Cabrera.png 2x" data-file-width="635" data-file-height="888"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Sor_Juana_by_Miguel_Cabrera.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz, "The Tenth Muse." Posthmous portrait <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Cabrera_(painter)" title="Miguel Cabrera (painter)">Juan Cabrera</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Mexican literature has its antecedents in the literature of the indigenous settlements of Mesoamerica. Poetry had a rich cultural tradition in prehispanic Mexico, being divided into two broad categories—secular and religious. Aztec poetry was sung, chanted, or spoken, often to the accompanyment of a drum or a harp. While Tenochtitlan was the political capital, <a href="/wiki/Texcoco_(altepetl)" title="Texcoco (altepetl)">Texcoco</a> was the cultural center; the Texcocan language was considered the most melodious and refined. The best well-known prehispanic poet is <a href="/wiki/Nezahualcoyotl_(tlatoani)" title="Nezahualcoyotl (tlatoani)">Nezahualcoyotl</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-441" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-441">[440]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Literature during the 16th century consisted largely of histories of Spanish conquests, and most of the writers at this time were from Spain. <a href="/wiki/Bernal_D%C3%ADaz_del_Castillo" title="Bernal Díaz del Castillo">Bernal Díaz del Castillo's</a> <a href="/wiki/Historia_verdadera_de_la_conquista_de_la_Nueva_Espa%C3%B1a" title="Historia verdadera de la conquista de la Nueva España">True History of the Conquest of Mexico</a> is still widely read today. Spanish-born poet <a href="/wiki/Bernardo_de_Balbuena" title="Bernardo de Balbuena">Bernardo de Balbuena</a> extolled the virtues of Mexico in <i>Grandeza mexicana</i> (Mexican grandeur) (1604); <a href="https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francisco_de_Terrazas" class="extiw" title="es:Francisco de Terrazas">Francisco de Terrazas</a> was the first Mexican-born poet to attain renown.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_442-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-442">[441]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Baroque_literature" class="mw-redirect" title="Baroque literature">Baroque literature</a> flourished in the 17th century; the most notable writers of this period were <a href="/wiki/Juan_Ruiz_de_Alarc%C3%B3n" title="Juan Ruiz de Alarcón">Juan Ruiz de Alarcón</a> and <a href="/wiki/Juana_In%C3%A9s_de_la_Cruz" title="Juana Inés de la Cruz">Juana Inés de la Cruz</a>. Sor Juana was famous in her own time, called the "Ten Muse."<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_442-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-442">[441]</a></sup> The 18th and early 19th centuries gave us <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Joaqu%C3%ADn_Fern%C3%A1ndez_de_Lizardi" title="José Joaquín Fernández de Lizardi">José Joaquín Fernández de Lizardi</a>, whose <i><a href="/wiki/The_Mangy_Parrot" title="The Mangy Parrot">The Mangy Parrot</a></i> ("El Periquillo Sarniento"), is said to be the first Latin American novel. Several <a href="/wiki/Society_of_Jesus" title="Society of Jesus">Jesuit</a> humanists wrote at this time, and they were among the first to call for independence from Spain.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_442-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-442">[441]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Other writers include <a href="/wiki/Ignacio_Manuel_Altamirano" title="Ignacio Manuel Altamirano">Ignacio Manuel Altamirano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Octavio_Paz" title="Octavio Paz">Octavio Paz</a> (Nobel Laureate), <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Fuentes" title="Carlos Fuentes">Carlos Fuentes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alfonso_Reyes" title="Alfonso Reyes">Alfonso Reyes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Renato_Leduc" title="Renato Leduc">Renato Leduc</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Monsiv%C3%A1is" title="Carlos Monsiváis">Carlos Monsiváis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elena_Poniatowska" title="Elena Poniatowska">Elena Poniatowska</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mariano_Azuela" title="Mariano Azuela">Mariano Azuela</a> (<i>Los de abajo</i>) and <a href="/wiki/Juan_Rulfo" title="Juan Rulfo">Juan Rulfo</a> (<i>Pedro Páramo</i>). <a href="/wiki/Bruno_Traven" class="mw-redirect" title="Bruno Traven">Bruno Traven</a> wrote<i>Canasta de cuentos mexicano</i> (A basket of Mexican tales) and <i>El tesoro de la Sierra Madre</i> (Treasure of the Sierra Madre), <a href="/wiki/Luis_Spota" title="Luis Spota">Luis Spota</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jaime_Sabines" title="Jaime Sabines">Jaime Sabines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mart%C3%ADn_Luis_Guzm%C3%A1n" title="Martín Luis Guzmán">Martín Luis Guzmán</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nellie_Campobello" title="Nellie Campobello">Nellie Campobello</a>, (<i><a href="/wiki/Cartucho" title="Cartucho">Cartucho</a></i>), and <a href="/wiki/Valeria_Luiselli" title="Valeria Luiselli">Valeria Luiselli</a> (<i>Faces in the Crowd</i>) are also noteworthy.<sup id="cite_ref-443" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-443">[442]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema">Cinema</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Mexico" title="Cinema of Mexico">Cinema of Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Dolores_del_R%C3%ADo.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Dolores_del_R%C3%ADo.jpg/170px-Dolores_del_R%C3%ADo.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="227" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Dolores_del_R%C3%ADo.jpg/255px-Dolores_del_R%C3%ADo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f8/Dolores_del_R%C3%ADo.jpg 2x" data-file-width="340" data-file-height="453"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Dolores_del_R%C3%ADo.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Actress <a href="/wiki/Dolores_del_R%C3%ADo" title="Dolores del Río">Dolores del Río</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hollywood" title="Hollywood">Hollywood</a> star in the 1920s and 1930s and prominent figure of the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Age_of_Mexican_cinema" title="Golden Age of Mexican cinema">Golden Age of Mexican cinema</a> in the 1940s and 1950s
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Mexico" title="Cinema of Mexico">Mexican films</a> from the <i><a href="/wiki/Golden_Age_of_Mexican_cinema" title="Golden Age of Mexican cinema">Golden Age</a></i> in the 1940s and 1950s are the greatest examples of Latin American cinema, with a huge industry comparable to the Hollywood of those years. Mexican films were exported and exhibited in all of Latin America and Europe. <i><a href="/wiki/Mar%C3%ADa_Candelaria" title="María Candelaria">María Candelaria</a></i> (1943) by <a href="/wiki/Emilio_Fern%C3%A1ndez" title="Emilio Fernández">Emilio Fernández</a>, was one of the first films awarded a <a href="/wiki/Palme_d%27Or" title="Palme d'Or">Palme d'Or</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Cannes_Film_Festival" title="Cannes Film Festival">Cannes Film Festival</a> in 1946, the first time the event was held after World War II. The famous Spanish-born director <a href="/wiki/Luis_Bu%C3%B1uel" title="Luis Buñuel">Luis Buñuel</a> realized in Mexico between 1947 and 1965 some of his masterpieces like <i><a href="/wiki/Los_Olvidados" title="Los Olvidados">Los Olvidados</a></i> (1949) and <i><a href="/wiki/Viridiana" title="Viridiana">Viridiana</a></i> (1961). Famous actors and actresses from this period include <a href="/wiki/Mar%C3%ADa_F%C3%A9lix" title="María Félix">María Félix</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pedro_Infante" title="Pedro Infante">Pedro Infante</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dolores_del_R%C3%ADo" title="Dolores del Río">Dolores del Río</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jorge_Negrete" title="Jorge Negrete">Jorge Negrete</a> and the comedian <a href="/wiki/Cantinflas" title="Cantinflas">Cantinflas</a>. </p>
      <p>More recently, films such as <i><a href="/wiki/Like_Water_for_Chocolate_(film)" title="Like Water for Chocolate (film)">Como agua para chocolate</a></i> (1992), <i><a href="/wiki/Cronos_(film)" title="Cronos (film)">Cronos</a></i> (1993), <i><a href="/wiki/Y_tu_mam%C3%A1_tambi%C3%A9n" title="Y tu mamá también">Y tu mamá también</a></i> (2001), and <i><a href="/wiki/Pan%27s_Labyrinth" title="Pan's Labyrinth">Pan's Labyrinth</a></i> (2006) have been successful in creating universal stories about contemporary subjects, and were internationally recognized, as in the prestigious Cannes Film Festival. Mexican directors <a href="/wiki/Alejandro_Gonz%C3%A1lez_I%C3%B1%C3%A1rritu" title="Alejandro González Iñárritu">Alejandro González Iñárritu</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Amores_perros" title="Amores perros">Amores perros</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Babel_(film)" title="Babel (film)">Babel</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Birdman_(film)" title="Birdman (film)">Birdman</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Revenant_(2015_film)" title="The Revenant (2015 film)">The Revenant</a></i>), <a href="/wiki/Alfonso_Cuar%C3%B3n" title="Alfonso Cuarón">Alfonso Cuarón</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Children_of_Men" title="Children of Men">Children of Men</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban" title="Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban">Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Gravity_(2013_film)" title="Gravity (2013 film)">Gravity</a></i>), <a href="/wiki/Guillermo_del_Toro" title="Guillermo del Toro">Guillermo del Toro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Carrera" title="Carlos Carrera">Carlos Carrera</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/El_crimen_del_Padre_Amaro" class="mw-redirect" title="El crimen del Padre Amaro">The Crime of Father Amaro</a></i>), screenwriter <a href="/wiki/Guillermo_Arriaga" title="Guillermo Arriaga">Guillermo Arriaga</a> and photographer <a href="/wiki/Emmanuel_Lubezki" title="Emmanuel Lubezki">Emmanuel Lubezki</a> are some of the most known present-day film makers. Numerous Mexican actors have achieved recognition as Hollywood stars.<sup id="cite_ref-444" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-444">[443]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Mexican_television" class="mw-redirect" title="Mexican television">Mexican television</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_Mexico" title="List of newspapers in Mexico">List of newspapers in Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <p>There are three major television companies in Mexico that own the primary networks and broadcast covering all nation, <a href="/wiki/Televisa" title="Televisa">Televisa</a>, <a href="/wiki/TV_Azteca" title="TV Azteca">TV Azteca</a> and <a href="/wiki/Imagen_Television" class="mw-redirect" title="Imagen Television">Imagen Television</a>. Televisa is also the largest producer of Spanish-language content in the world and also the world's largest Spanish-language media network.<sup id="cite_ref-445" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-445">[444]</a></sup> Media company <a href="/wiki/Grupo_Imagen" title="Grupo Imagen">Grupo Imagen</a> is another national coverage television broadcaster in Mexico, that also owns the newspaper <a href="/wiki/Exc%C3%A9lsior" title="Excélsior">Excélsior</a>. <a href="/wiki/Grupo_Multimedios" title="Grupo Multimedios">Grupo Multimedios</a> is another media conglomerate with Spanish-language broadcasting in Mexico, Spain, and the United States. The <i><a href="/wiki/Telenovela" title="Telenovela">telenovelas</a></i> are very traditional in Mexico and are translated to many languages and seen all over the world with renowned names like <a href="/wiki/Ver%C3%B3nica_Castro" title="Verónica Castro">Verónica Castro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luc%C3%ADa_M%C3%A9ndez" title="Lucía Méndez">Lucía Méndez</a> and <a href="/wiki/Thal%C3%ADa" title="Thalía">Thalía</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mexican_cuisine">Mexican cuisine</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mexican_cuisine" title="Mexican cuisine">Mexican cuisine</a>
      </div>
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Mexican_wine" title="Mexican wine">Mexican wine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Comida_en_la_Feria_del_Mole_2014_12.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Comida_en_la_Feria_del_Mole_2014_12.JPG/220px-Comida_en_la_Feria_del_Mole_2014_12.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Comida_en_la_Feria_del_Mole_2014_12.JPG/330px-Comida_en_la_Feria_del_Mole_2014_12.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Comida_en_la_Feria_del_Mole_2014_12.JPG/440px-Comida_en_la_Feria_del_Mole_2014_12.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4320" data-file-height="3240"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Comida_en_la_Feria_del_Mole_2014_12.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><i><a href="/wiki/Mole_sauce" title="Mole sauce">Mole sauce</a></i>, which has dozens of varieties across the Republic, is seen as a symbol of <i>Mexicanidad</i><sup id="cite_ref-Mole_446-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mole-446">[445]</a></sup> and is considered Mexico's national dish.<sup id="cite_ref-Mole_446-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mole-446">[445]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2005, Mexico presented the candidature of its gastronomy for <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a> of UNESCO, being the first occasion in which a country had presented its gastronomic tradition for this purpose.<sup id="cite_ref-447" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-447">[446]</a></sup> However, in a first instance the result was negative, because the committee did not place the proper emphasis on the importance of <a href="/wiki/Corn" class="mw-redirect" title="Corn">corn</a> in Mexican cuisine.<sup id="cite_ref-448" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-448">[447]</a></sup> Finally, on 16 November 2010 Mexican gastronomy was recognized as <a href="/wiki/Intangible_cultural_heritage" title="Intangible cultural heritage">Intangible cultural heritage</a> by <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-GastronomiaPatrimonio_449-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GastronomiaPatrimonio-449">[448]</a></sup> In addition, <a href="/wiki/Daniela_Soto-Innes" title="Daniela Soto-Innes">Daniela Soto-Innes</a> was named the best female chef in the world by <i>The World's Best 50 Restaurants</i> in April 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-450" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-450">[449]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The origin of the current Mexican cuisine is established during the Spanish colonial era, a mixture of the foods of <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a> with native indigenous ingredients.<sup id="cite_ref-451" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-451">[450]</a></sup> Of foods originated in Mexico is the <a href="/wiki/Corn" class="mw-redirect" title="Corn">corn</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Capsicum" title="Capsicum">pepper vegetables</a> (together with Central and South America), <a href="/wiki/Calabaza" title="Calabaza">calabazas</a> (together with the Americas), <a href="/wiki/Avocado" title="Avocado">avocados</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sweet_potato" title="Sweet potato">sweet potato</a> (together with Central and South America), the <a href="/wiki/Turkey_as_food" title="Turkey as food">turkey</a> (together with the Americas) and other fruits and spices. Other Indigenous products are many <a href="/wiki/Beans" class="mw-redirect" title="Beans">beans</a>. Similarly, some cooking techniques used today are inherited from pre-Hispanic peoples, such as the <a href="/wiki/Nixtamalization" title="Nixtamalization">nixtamalization</a> of corn, the cooking of food in ovens at ground level, grinding in <a href="/wiki/Molcajete" title="Molcajete">molcajete</a> and <a href="/wiki/Metate" title="Metate">metate</a>. With the Spaniards came the pork, beef and chicken meats; <a href="/wiki/Piper_(plant)" title="Piper (plant)">peppercorn</a>, sugar, milk and all its derivatives, wheat and rice, citrus fruits and another constellation of ingredients that are part of the daily diet of Mexicans. </p>
      <p>From this meeting of millennia old two culinary traditions, were born <a href="/wiki/Pozole" title="Pozole">pozole</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mole_sauce" title="Mole sauce">mole sauce</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barbacoa" title="Barbacoa">barbacoa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tamale" title="Tamale">tamale</a> is in its current forms, the <a href="/wiki/Chocolate" title="Chocolate">chocolate</a>, a large range of <a href="/wiki/Mexican_breads" title="Mexican breads">breads</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taco" title="Taco">tacos</a>, and the broad repertoire of <a href="/wiki/Mexican_street_food" title="Mexican street food">Mexican street foods</a>. Beverages such as <a href="/wiki/Atole" title="Atole">atole</a>, <a href="/wiki/Champurrado" title="Champurrado">champurrado</a>, milk chocolate and <a href="/wiki/Aguas_frescas" class="mw-redirect" title="Aguas frescas">aguas frescas</a> were born; desserts such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Acitr%C3%B3n&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Acitrón (page does not exist)">acitrón</a> and the full range of crystallized sweets, <a href="/wiki/Rompope" title="Rompope">rompope</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cajeta" title="Cajeta">cajeta</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jericaya&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jericaya (page does not exist)">jericaya</a> and the wide repertoire of delights created in the convents of nuns in all parts of the country. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Mexico" title="Music of Mexico">Music of Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:MariachiFestivalSanJuanLagos.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/MariachiFestivalSanJuanLagos.jpg/220px-MariachiFestivalSanJuanLagos.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="169" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/MariachiFestivalSanJuanLagos.jpg/330px-MariachiFestivalSanJuanLagos.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/MariachiFestivalSanJuanLagos.jpg/440px-MariachiFestivalSanJuanLagos.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3378" data-file-height="2592"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:MariachiFestivalSanJuanLagos.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Mariachi" title="Mariachi">Mariachi</a> group playing.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Mexican society enjoys a vast array of music genres, showing the diversity of Mexican culture. Traditional music includes <a href="/wiki/Mariachi" title="Mariachi">mariachi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Banda_music" title="Banda music">banda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Norte%C3%B1o_(music)" title="Norteño (music)">norteño</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ranchera" title="Ranchera">ranchera</a> and <a href="/wiki/Corrido" title="Corrido">corridos</a>; on an everyday basis most Mexicans listen to contemporary music such as <a href="/wiki/Mexican_pop_music" title="Mexican pop music">pop</a>, rock, etc. in both English and Spanish. Mexico has the largest media industry in Latin America, producing Mexican artists who are famous in Central and South America and parts of Europe, especially Spain. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Mexico" title="Sport in Mexico">Sport in Mexico</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Estadio_Azteca1706p2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Estadio_Azteca1706p2.jpg/250px-Estadio_Azteca1706p2.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="121" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Estadio_Azteca1706p2.jpg/375px-Estadio_Azteca1706p2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Estadio_Azteca1706p2.jpg/500px-Estadio_Azteca1706p2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6008" data-file-height="2909"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Estadio_Azteca1706p2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Estadio_Azteca" title="Estadio Azteca">Estadio Azteca</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Pelota_mixteca_de_forro_ball_1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Pelota_mixteca_de_forro_ball_1.jpg/150px-Pelota_mixteca_de_forro_ball_1.jpg" decoding="async" width="150" height="113" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Pelota_mixteca_de_forro_ball_1.jpg/225px-Pelota_mixteca_de_forro_ball_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Pelota_mixteca_de_forro_ball_1.jpg/300px-Pelota_mixteca_de_forro_ball_1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="768"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Pelota_mixteca_de_forro_ball_1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Mesoamerican_ballgame" title="Mesoamerican ballgame">Mesoamerican ballgame</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Mexico's most popular sport is association football. It is commonly believed that football was introduced in Mexico by <a href="/wiki/Cornish_people" title="Cornish people">Cornish</a> miners at the end of the 19th century. By 1902 a five-team league had emerged with a strong British influence.<sup id="cite_ref-452" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-452">[451]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-453" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-453">[452]</a></sup> Mexico's top clubs are <a href="/wiki/Club_Am%C3%A9rica" title="Club América">América</a> with 12 championships, <a href="/wiki/Club_Deportivo_Guadalajara" class="mw-redirect" title="Club Deportivo Guadalajara">Guadalajara</a> with 11, and <a href="/wiki/Deportivo_Toluca_F.C." title="Deportivo Toluca F.C.">Toluca</a> with 10.<sup id="cite_ref-454" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-454">[453]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Carbajal" title="Antonio Carbajal">Antonio Carbajal</a> was the first player to appear in five World Cups,<sup id="cite_ref-455" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-455">[454]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Hugo_S%C3%A1nchez" title="Hugo Sánchez">Hugo Sánchez</a> was named best <a href="/wiki/CONCACAF" title="CONCACAF">CONCACAF</a> player of the 20th century by IFFHS.<sup id="cite_ref-456" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-456">[455]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rafael_M%C3%A1rquez" title="Rafael Márquez">Rafael Márquez</a> is the only Mexican to have won the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League" title="UEFA Champions League">Champions League</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-sports_457-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sports-457">[456]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Mexican professional baseball league is named the <a href="/wiki/Liga_Mexicana_de_Beisbol" class="mw-redirect" title="Liga Mexicana de Beisbol">Liga Mexicana de Beisbol</a>. While usually not as strong as the United States, the Caribbean countries and Japan, <a href="/wiki/Mexico_national_baseball_team" title="Mexico national baseball team">Mexico</a> has nonetheless achieved several international baseball titles.<sup id="cite_ref-458" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-458">[457]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-459" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-459">[458]</a></sup> Mexican teams have won the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_Series" title="Caribbean Series">Caribbean Series</a> nine times. Mexico has had several players signed by Major League teams, the most famous of them being Dodgers pitcher <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Valenzuela" title="Fernando Valenzuela">Fernando Valenzuela</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-sports_457-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sports-457">[456]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Mexico City hosted the <a href="/wiki/1968_Summer_Olympics" title="1968 Summer Olympics">XIX Olympic Games</a> in 1968, making it the first Latin American city to do so.<sup id="cite_ref-460" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-460">[459]</a></sup> The country has also hosted the <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">FIFA World Cup</a> twice, in <a href="/wiki/1970_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1970 FIFA World Cup">1970</a> and <a href="/wiki/1986_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1986 FIFA World Cup">1986</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-461" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-461">[460]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2013, <a href="/wiki/Mexico%27s_basketball_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Mexico's basketball team">Mexico's basketball team</a> won the <a href="/wiki/2013_FIBA_Americas_Championship" title="2013 FIBA Americas Championship">Americas Basketball Championship</a> and qualified for the <a href="/wiki/2014_Basketball_World_Cup" class="mw-redirect" title="2014 Basketball World Cup">2014 Basketball World Cup</a> where it reached the playoffs. Because of these achievements the country earned the hosting rights for the <a href="/wiki/2015_FIBA_Americas_Championship" title="2015 FIBA Americas Championship">2015 FIBA Americas Championship</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-462" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-462">[461]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Bullfighting" title="Bullfighting">Bullfighting</a> (Spanish: corrida de toros) came to Mexico 500 years ago with the arrival of the Spanish. Despite efforts by animal rights activists to outlaw it, bullfighting remains a popular sport in the country, and almost all large cities have bullrings. <a href="/wiki/Plaza_M%C3%A9xico" class="mw-redirect" title="Plaza México">Plaza México</a> in Mexico City, which seats 45,000 people, is the largest bullring in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-463" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-463">[462]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Mexico is an international power in <a href="/wiki/Professional_boxing" title="Professional boxing">professional boxing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-sports_457-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sports-457">[456]</a></sup> Thirteen <a href="/wiki/Mexico_at_the_Olympics" title="Mexico at the Olympics">Olympic boxing medals</a> have been won by Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-464" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-464">[463]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Professional wrestling (or <a href="/wiki/Lucha_libre" title="Lucha libre">Lucha libre</a> in Spanish) is a major crowd draw with national promotions such as <a href="/wiki/Lucha_Libre_AAA_World_Wide" class="mw-redirect" title="Lucha Libre AAA World Wide">AAA</a>, <a href="/wiki/Consejo_Mundial_de_Lucha_Libre" title="Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre">CMLL</a> and others.<sup id="cite_ref-sports_457-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sports-457">[456]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r936637989">.mw-parser-output .portal{border:solid #aaa 1px;padding:0}.mw-parser-output .portal.tleft{margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portal.tright{margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul{display:table;box-sizing:border-box;padding:0.1em;max-width:175px;background:#f9f9f9;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li{display:table-row}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li>span:first-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li>span:last-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}</style>
      <div role="navigation" aria-label="Portals" class="noprint portal plainlist tright"> 
       <ul> 
        <li><span><img alt="flag" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Flag_of_Mexico.svg/32px-Flag_of_Mexico.svg.png" decoding="async" width="32" height="18" class="noviewer thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Flag_of_Mexico.svg/48px-Flag_of_Mexico.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Flag_of_Mexico.svg/64px-Flag_of_Mexico.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="980" data-file-height="560"></span><span><a href="/wiki/Portal:Mexico" title="Portal:Mexico">Mexico portal</a></span></li>
       </ul>
      </div> 
      <ul>
       <li><a href="/wiki/Index_of_Mexico-related_articles" title="Index of Mexico-related articles">Index of Mexico-related articles</a></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_Mexico" title="Outline of Mexico">Outline of Mexico</a></li> 
       <li class="mw-empty-elt"></li>
      </ul> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2> 
      <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;"> 
       <div class="mw-references-wrap">
        <ol class="references"> 
         <li id="cite_note-361"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-361">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Defined as persons who live in a household where an indigenous language is spoken by one of the adult family members, and or people who self-identified as indigenous ("Criteria del hogar: De esta manera, se establece, que los hogares indígenas son aquellos en donde el jefe y/o el cónyuge y/o padre o madre del jefe y/o suegro o suegra del jefe hablan una lengua indígena y también aquellos que declararon pertenecer a un grupo indígena."<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">[359]</a></sup>) AND persons who speak an indigenous language but who do not live in such a household ("Por lo antes mencionado, la Comisión Nacional Para el Desarrollo de los Pueblos Indígenas de México (CDI) considera población indígena (PI) a todas las personas que forman parte de un hogar indígena, donde el jefe(a) del hogar, su cónyuge y/o alguno de los ascendientes (madre o padre, madrastra o padrastro, abuelo(a), bisabuelo(a), tatarabuelo(a), suegro(a)) declaro ser hablante de lengua indígena. Además, también incluye a personas que declararon hablar alguna lengua indígena y que no forman parte de estos hogares."<sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360">[360]</a></sup>)</span> </li> 
        </ol>
       </div>
      </div>

Routledge. pp.&nbsp;455–462. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-135-97370-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-135-97370-4"><bdi>978-1-135-97370-4</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Military%3A+Bourbon+New+Spain&amp;rft.btitle=Concise+Encyclopedia+of+Mexico&amp;rft.pages=455-462&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-135-97370-4&amp;rft.aulast=Archer&amp;rft.aufirst=Christon+I.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DMOI4CQAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA455&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMexico" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-hist-17"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-hist_17-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-hist_17-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.history.com/topics/mexico/history-of-mexico">"History of Mexico"</a>. <i>The History Channel</i>. 9 November 2009<span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-Principles2-32"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Principles2_32-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFN._Gregory_Mankiw2007" class="citation book cs1">N.          <li id="cite_note-51"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-51">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFCowgill1997" class="citation journal cs1">Cowgill, George L. (21 October 1997).          <li id="cite_note-72"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-72">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-91"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-91">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSempa" class="citation web cs1">Sempa, Francis P. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://thediplomat.com/2017/01/china-spanish-america-and-the-birth-of-globalization/">"China, Spanish America, and the 'Birth of Globalization<span class="cs1-kern-right">'</span>"</a>. <i>The Diplomat</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">7 February</span> 2017</span>. <q>Mexico City, the authors [Peter Gordon, Juan Jose Morales] note, was the 'first world city,' the precursor to London, New York, and Hong Kong, where 'Asia, Europe, and the Americas all met, and where people intermingled and exchanged everything from genes to textiles'.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Diplomat&amp;rft.atitle=China%2C+Spanish+America%2C+and+the+%27Birth+of+Globalization%27&amp;rft.aulast=Sempa&amp;rft.aufirst=Francis+P.&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fthediplomat.com%2F2017%2F01%2Fchina-spanish-america-and-the-birth-of-globalization%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMexico" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-92"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-92">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFAngel_Miranda_Basurto2002" class="citation book cs1">Angel Miranda Basurto (2002). <i>La Evolucíon de Mėxico</i> [<i>The Evolution of Mexico</i>] (in Spanish) (6th&nbsp;ed.).          <li id="cite_note-109"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-109">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://muse.jhu.edu/article/456194/pdf">"Filipinos in Nueva España: Filipino-Mexican Relations, Mestizaje, and Identity in Colonial and Contemporary Mexico"</a>. p.&nbsp;414. <q>According to Ricardo Pinzon, these two Filipino soldiers—Francisco Mongoy and Isidoro Montes de Oca—were so distinguished in battle that they are regarded as folk heroes in Mexico. General Vicente Guerrero later became the first president of Mexico of African descent. See Floro L. Mercene, “Central America: Filipinos in Mexican History,” (Ezilon Infobase, 28 January 2005)</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Filipinos+in+Nueva+Espa%C3%B1a%3A+Filipino-Mexican+Relations%2C+Mestizaje%2C+and+Identity+in+Colonial+and+Contemporary+Mexico&amp;rft.pages=414&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fmuse.jhu.edu%2Farticle%2F456194%2Fpdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMexico" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20061113175736/http://constitucion.gob.mx/index.php?idseccion=12">"Articles 50 to 79"</a>. <i>Political Constitution of the United Mexican States</i>.          <li id="cite_note-166"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-166">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20071025020343/http://normateca.ife.org.mx/normanet/files_otros/COFIPE/cofipe.pdf">"Third Title, First Chapter, About Electoral systems"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Código Federal de Instituciones y Procedimientos Electorales (Federal Code of Electoral Institutions and Procedures)</i> (in Spanish). Congress of the Union of the United Mexican States. 15 August 1990.          <li id="cite_note-COFIPE_congreso-167"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-COFIPE_congreso_167-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-COFIPE_congreso_167-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-estradadoctrine-201"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-estradadoctrine_201-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFPalacios_Treviño" class="citation web cs1">Palacios Treviño, Jorge. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20090206085102/http://diplomaticosescritores.org/obras/DOCTRINAESTRADA.pdf">"La Doctrina Estrada y el Principio de la No-Intervención"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> (in Spanish).            <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFEnergy_Information_Administration" class="citation web cs1">Energy Information Administration. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070216112638/http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/cabs/topworldtables1_2.html">"Top World Oil Net Exporters and Producers"</a>.            <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.nationsencyclopedia.com/economies/Americas/Mexico-INFRASTRUCTURE-POWER-AND-COMMUNICATIONS.html">"Infrastructure, Power and Communications, Mexic"</a>.          <li id="cite_note-EL_MESTIZAJE_Y_LAS_CULTURAS_REGIONALES-323"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-EL_MESTIZAJE_Y_LAS_CULTURAS_REGIONALES_323-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-EL_MESTIZAJE_Y_LAS_CULTURAS_REGIONALES_323-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130823015618/http://www.nacionmulticultural.unam.mx/Portal/Izquierdo/BANCO/Mxmulticultural/Elmestizajeylasculturas-elmestizaje.html">"en el censo de 1930 el gobierno mexicano dejó de clasificar a la población del país en tres categorías raciales, blanco, mestizo e indígena, y adoptó una nueva clasificación étnica que distinguía a los hablantes de lenguas indígenas del resto de la población, es decir de los hablantes de español"</a>.          <li id="cite_note-ElUniversal-325"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ElUniversal_325-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFFuentes-Nieva2017" class="citation news cs1">Fuentes-Nieva, Ricardo (6 July 2017). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.eluniversal.com.mx/entrada-de-opinion/articulo/ricardo-fuentes-nieva/nacion/2017/07/6/ser-blanco">"Ser blanco"</a> [Be white]. <i>El Universal</i> (in Spanish).</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=El+Universal&amp;rft.atitle=Ser+blanco&amp;rft.date=2017-07-06&amp;rft.aulast=Fuentes-Nieva&amp;rft.aufirst=Ricardo&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.eluniversal.com.mx%2Fentrada-de-opinion%2Farticulo%2Fricardo-fuentes-nieva%2Fnacion%2F2017%2F07%2F6%2Fser-blanco&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMexico" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-Knight,_Alan_1990._pp._78-344"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Knight,_Alan_1990._pp._78_344-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Knight, Alan. 1990.          <li id="cite_note-census-345"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-census_345-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFHall_SteckelR._Haines2000" class="citation book cs1">Hall Steckel, Richard; R.          <li id="cite_note-362"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-362">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20041115115005/http://www.cdi.gob.mx/index.php?id_seccion=91">"Indicadores socioeconómicos de los pueblos indígenas"</a> [Socio-economic indicators of indigenous peoples]. <i>Información</i> (in Spanish).          <li id="cite_note-CDI-363"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-CDI_363-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-429"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-429">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFFinkler1997" class="citation journal cs1">Finkler, Kaja (1997).            <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation cs2"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.donquijote.org/es/cultura-mexicana/tradiciones/toros/">"LOS TOROS EN MÉXICO"</a> [Bullfighting in Mexico], <i>Don Quijote</i> (in Spanish)<span class="reference-accessdate">, retrieved <span class="nowrap">11 July</span> 2019</span></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Don+Quijote&amp;rft.atitle=LOS+TOROS+EN+M%C3%89XICO&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.donquijote.org%2Fes%2Fcultura-mexicana%2Ftradiciones%2Ftoros%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMexico" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-464"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-464">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation cs2"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://mexico.as.com/mexico/2016/08/16/album/1471303609_523251.html">"Los medallistas que ha tenido el Box Olímpico mexicano"</a> [The Mexican Olympic boxing medal winners], <i>Caliente.mx</i> (in Spanish), 15 August 2016<span class="reference-accessdate">, retrieved <span class="nowrap">11 July</span> 2019</span></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Caliente.mx&amp;rft.atitle=Los+medallistas+que+ha+tenido+el+Box+Ol%C3%ADmpico+mexicano&amp;rft.date=2016-08-15&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fmexico.as.com%2Fmexico%2F2016%2F08%2F16%2Falbum%2F1471303609_523251.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMexico" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
        </ol>
